description:
I've been coming here at least annually, but usually 4-5 times a year, for 15 years now. Is it "authentic" Chinese food? Authentic enough for me. (China is an enormous country, and, gasp!, they do incorporate elements from other cultures' cuisines, like every other national cuisine on the planet) The place is clean, blindingly fast, with a friendly wait staff. The food is also really delicious.

My faves: Shanghai tofu (actually a must-have for our entire family every time), avocado rolls, mushu vegetables (and, yes, they use flour tortillas for the mu shu wrappers lol), and Buddha's delight. (I'm a vegetarian so have only tried the relevant menu items, but my omnivorous family and friends like the sesame chicken and prawn dishes, too)
author: Jason M.

description:
I stopped by Eric's with a friend after it came highly recommended. We were quite disappointed by the food itself, but the service was friendly and fast, and the ambience was nice. The restaurant is on a quiet little street and is full of beautiful windows and natural light. Our server was attentive and friendly, and brought us tea/water immediately. 

The experience really fell short when it came to the food. We ordered several dishes- lemon chicken, mongolian beef, chow mein, potstickers, and streamed rice. The only dish worth noting was the mongolian beef- beyond that, everything was bland and underwhelming. Even the texture of the beef was somewhat rubbery. The cost for all of these dishes was less than $50, so it is definitely on the cheaper end of the spectrum, which is good, considering how they lacked flavor. 

Overall, I would say Eric's is a good place to try if you are looking for something cheap but are willing to sacrifice taste- otherwise, take your business elsewhere.
author: Ayushi A.

description: My favorite Chinese food in SF.  Best hot & sour soup and generals chicken.  Good value on the lunch special too.  Only complaint is that they never give an itemized receipt - and have questioned them on the cost a few times.  Food is great though.
author: George M.

description: Eric's is a really good whole in the wall Chinese restaurant. This is my go to restaurant.The food is really authentic and not like any other Chinese restaurant in sf. Make sure to come early for dinner because the place is not to big, but no need for reservations. Parking is excruciating because its really hard to find parking. It's a hit or miss. Over all review is that Eric's is a great restaurant and it's in a safe neighborhood.
author: Conner C.

description: Ok so I came back to Eric's a couple more times so I thought I would update the review. The curry chicken and mango beef are my favorite lunch specials to get. They're always consistent and flavorful. If you go during lunch time, you get a free soup which is nice. Their egg rolls are crunchy and tasty. Their food is still reasonably priced and I'm glad I gave Eric's another chance.
author: Jasmine V.

description: I love it!!! The food is so yummy. I just couldn't stop eating. And the staff is very nice. The prices so reasonable. Could go there every night.
author: Käthe R.

description:
Erics is a good Noe valley spot . Been coming for years .
Pluses , it's airy and open
Service is usually very good .
Prices are very fair .
Food is good & some better then others .
For some reason the last two times in , Kung pao chicken , had such a diff look , the chicken pieces shaped like small shrimp ??
It's never been served like this & it seriously has me thinking of not returning .
Maybe the ownership has changed ?? 
I would of normally said solid 4 stars , but I think the quality is slightly slipping , hopefully just a fluke .
author: Ellie O.

description: We came here on a Saturday date night. It was the first time I had come in. From the outside you get that this is a local  hangout where people have been coming for years. The clientele is all older folks from the community. It is great for groups because it is very big and spacious. The ceilings are high. The tables are big and put together easily to accommodate large groups. The staff are super friendly. The food is simple. Nothing fancy. Yet it doesn't disappoint and is really affordable. They give you free jasmine tea when you arrive. I got the mushu vegetables. It was very fresh and delicious. My boyfriend got the wonton soup was pretty good. We also shared the steamed dumplings which were warm and full of pork. They gave us fortune cookies at the end. Overall it was a really nice experience and I can see why locals keep coming back!
author: Anne S.

description:
This was our first time exploring Noe Valley. My bf's name is Eric so I thought it'd be fun to take him to Eric's. 

The first thing we noticed was that they had Szechuan dishes, Japanese dishes, and wine on their menu, meaning it probably wasn't very authentic Chinese food.

We ordered steamed dumplings and mapo bean curd with white rice. The complimentary lemon water and hot tea were served very quickly. We didn't wait too long before our steamed dumplings came out. The dumplings were decent but the skin broke too easily. The mapo bean curd was flavorful but we were disappointed by the lack of spiciness and numbing sensation. 

Since we were questioning the authenticity of Eric's Restaurant, the post-meal dessert was the moment of truth. Were they going to bring us fortune cookies or fruits? Surprisingly, they gave us both!
author: Julia C.

description:
Finding good Chineese Food in The City is difficult, NOT! But finding the ideal Chineese spot in the neighborhood you are in is a bit more of a task. Eric's (yes it's Chineese) is the spot in Noe Valley. 
It's a low-key but popular Noe Valley Chinese restaurant serving large portions of classic dishes.

Potstickers, Mu - Shu Pork, and all the regular dudes you come to expect are there. The one dish I highly recommend is the General Tso's Chicken. 
Over the top seasoned perfectly, chicken to die for. 

If there are 6 or more in your party I recommend 2 orders. Service is excellent and they are very accommodating to making your dining experience mist memorable.
author: Damon D.

description:
VEGETARIAN REVIEW


Came here for dinner twice so far, both experiences were good. The chow mein comes with vegetables that are seasoned nicely in a sauce, but for some reason the noodles underneath remain plain and unseasoned. I'd definitely prefer they also add seasoning to the noodles, but it's still pretty tasty. The second veggie dish I tried was the eggplant in garlic sauce, this was my favorite. The eggplant is seasoned and fried/cooked so well. 


Take-out review 

Although, many months before dining in the restaurant, I first tried the food here by doing a take out order of veg. chow mein and eggplant in spicy garlic sauce. They charged me $2 for tofu in my chow mein without telling me it was extra. At least always inform your customer something will be extra if they ask to add something. That, I really didn't appreciate.
author: Shruti D.

description:
Just had a bad takeout experience.    Ordered 3 dishes.   Got them home.    Started eating.   Heard a funny noise and found a glass marble in the food.   Called the restaurant.    They did not handle it well.   Just offered to replace one dish.   

Not sure how a marble got in my food.    Guess it could have been worse but yuck.   

Anyway, I took the food back and for a full refund.   Lots of waisted time.
author: Kevin D.

description:
Started going to this neighborhood restaurant in 1998. Now that we live in the East Bay, we can not even drive by the city without jumping off the freeway to get Eric's to go. Not fancy, but no special occasion or family- friendly city jaunt is complete without a stop at Eric's.  

The fortunes seem magical and always appropriate. After hiking for five hours on Mt Tam and a proposal from my brand-new fiancé, his fortune read "you and your wife will be happy in your life together".  Make sure you pick the cookie that is pointing to you and nobody touches them or passes them out. 

Last time we're we're in the city on a weeknight, they even stayed open a little late so my husband and I did not have to miss a trip. In 19 years, Eric's has never disappointed.
author: Ang P.

description:
I had a wonderful meal at Eric's many years ago and decided tonight to try this place again with my partner and another friend.   What a disappointment.   We ordered three dishes and they used the same sauce for all three dishes.   The rice was hard and seemed like it was leftover from lunch.   The  fried noodle nest for the Ocean Seafood dish was cold and soft.  Knowing that the sauce was similar for all three dishes, the wait person did not suggest other dishes to balance the meal.
This is another disappointing Chinese restaurant in the Noe Valley/Castro area.
author: James J.

description:
I would bump this down to 0 if I could.
Eric's hit a new low; they contacted me directly, tried to explain that I was mistaken about how dismal the food was, that is was 'supposed to taste like that' that I must have kept the food sitting around (I didn't) to get the over cooked broccoli, and then asked me to come in for a "free" meal, and if I still didn't like it they would refund me the original. When I said I wasn't going to remove this review I got an "oh. OK." and a hang up.

And news flash, this just in from Eric's; Wor Won Ton soup is SUPPOSED to be spicy and sour. And have mushy broccoli and zucchini. That's how THEY make it. yum.
Awkward...
author: Sara D.

description: We ordered the Mongolian beef, tso's chicken and chow main. Chow main was a bit too salty in our opinion. The rest was excellent.
author: Matti B.

description: Eric's is my go-to choice for great Chinese cuisine. They do NOT add MSG to their dishes and they combine unique ingredients to create very tasty food. I usually go fo lunch on weekends but their weekday lunch combinations with soup, entree and rice are a terrific value. Even better... the Muni "J" Church stops right outside both inbound and outbound!
author: Dean J.

description:
This is the most unassuming Asian restaurant I've been to because 1. the name, 2. the look and feel on the outside, 3. minimal Asian-inspired decor inside, and 4. the location.

With that said, the food was good and fairly priced for a somewhat up-scale Chinese restaurant.

The style is Hunan and Mandarin, which means that the options range from moderate to spicy.

We ordered:
- Combination (chicken and pork) fried rice
- Portobello mushrooms and beef 
- Honey walnut shrimp

Honestly their portions are very good. It was just the two of us and we could have easily fed three.

I think that the honey walnut shrimp could have been better. It was very average at best. I'd forego that dish. Portobello mushrooms and beef was the best dish.

If you order a fried rice or chow mein dish, you won't need to pay extra for steamed rice. 

Overall, not bad for the area but I'd still go to Richmond or Chinatown for my Chinese food fix.
author: Amy H.

description:
I'm willing to give Eric's a 2nd chance.  Somehow, even though my yelp name does not match my real name, the staff at Eric's were able to track me down and call me on the phone to discuss my review.  I know they have my phone number; that's how they track orders, but not sure how they matched it to my review.  The manager apologized for the mix-up and offered to credit me on my next take-out order for the dish I didn't order.  I asked for a direct credit to my credit card but she said "our machine can't do that" (hmmmm).  I was brutally frank and said it was not just the bad service; the taste of the food was off and not as good as the other 40+ times I've eaten there.  She said it was a bad night (Chinese New Year) and to please give them another chance.  

At first it seemed really "big brother" that they tracked me down and called me, but give them credit for making the effort.  That said, I now have a credit for my next visit, I just have to tell them my phone number (hopefully it's in their system).  Normally, I'd blow it off and not go back, but the restaurant and I have a long relationship, so I'll give it a chance.
author: Iris F.

description:
#107/2016

I wanted to like this restaurant more; perhaps I didn't order their strongest dishes?

Both the sesame chicken and the Mapo tofu were incredibly salty, the latter inedible and for the first time in a long time, I sent a dish back to the kitchen.

The sesame chicken could've had more chicken and fewer vegetables. The chicken was thinly julienned and sautéed with more vegetables than chicken. All the same, it had a great flavor and the chicken was tender though the dish had a lot of MSG or salt. 

My Mapo Tofu was beautiful with gorgeous chunks of silken tofu and oyster mushrooms but a little light on pork. But, it didn't matter because it was truly inedible, just too salty.

(And I loooove salt, let that be said).

The kitchen nicely offered to remake it and I agreed but a moment later, I decided to forgo it. 

The wait staff offered me any appetizer on the house and I first demurred then settled on the hot n sour soup and it was delicious. A "small" bowl was enormous (order accordingly).

I'll definitely give this spot another chance: The decoration of the space is lovely and the beautiful, big windows give it a bright and airy feel.

The staff is accommodating and efficient and the menu is promising so I'll try again soon.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
One of my fav spots when I'm visiting! Away from the tourist, is this gem! 

Parking is in flat area for the most part! Less than 1 mile away from Dolores park. 

They are clean, very nice and their customer service is great! 

We like to start off with the combination plate for 2 (can feed 2-3) includes, egg rolls, crab Rangoon, dumplings and fried chicken wings. Hot and sour soup, and tea a must! For the entrees we share sweet and sour chicken, Erics chow mein and walnut prawns!! Amazing!! Most Chinese food feels heavy and drenched in oils and sauce, Eric's get it right!
author: Monica C.

description: Quaint joint in Noe Valley. I wasn't crazy about the beef and snow peas (wasn't bad though) but my husband's Mongolian beef dish was really good! You MUST get the avocado rolls! Delicious!
author: Sara H.

description: Sesame Beef with the asparagus and fried rice is my favorite. It's kind of funny because Alice's is right around the corner. This place is always busy with a lot of locals. Take it from a San Francisco native this is one of the top Chinese restaurants in the city. Customer service is amazing my brother and I ate here a few weeks ago and the hot and spicy soup was too spicy! Lol but the waiter just said 'I'll fix that for you' that was really nice of him. You got to get lucky with parking but it's totally worth it.
author: Sasha M.

description: Gotta be honest, I was skeptical going into this.  Who is Eric?  Is he worthy??  Looking back, I'm not sure if I'm worthy lolol.  GREAT neighborhood taste!  It's not like what you'll get from Chinatown, but it's not too "Boujee", either.  Given location, AMAZING prices, especially the lunch specials!!!  I'd recommend all three dishes we had, which was Szechuan Pork, Mango Beef, and Eric's Chicken.
author: Chi L.

description:
Can't believe that I crossed from one side of the city to the other to visit Eric's.  But loon that I am for Chinese food, I did.  And if the food wasn't memorable, it was OK.  And the price was right and service was a bit disjointed but OK.   OK?

Mu Shu Pork came piping hot to the table together with four much too thick pancakes.  But I ignored the pancakes and just ate the Mu Shu with a fork.  It was a nice mix of pork, cabbage, and egg although it was also very sweet.  The chef here has learned that America overall and I in particular have a sweet tooth.  The former head of the Food and Drug Administration, now a Professor in the city at UCSF, considers sugar to be refined poison.  It probably is but if you have to take poison it may be best to take the sweet kind. 

Walnut prawns made me think of the never ending attempts by Chinese chefs to make small or maybe medium sized shrimp appear to be immense prawns.   In this case, the shrimp were coated in much too much batter, which after frying were not entirely cooked through.  So the shrimp were OK but they were encased in a somewhat gummy coating.  The walnuts were nice and crisp but I've never fathomed why shrimp on this iconic dish need to be coated in mayonnaise.
author: David D.

description: Fresh & delicious! To get three different types of mushrooms in gorgeous rainbow colored veggie dish was delightful. A Noe Valley standby.
author: Alyssa B.

description: We had lunch here last week with an old friend who lives close by.  We were both a little nervous because of some of the reviews.  I'm gonna tell you now, that our lunch was great, great food, great service.  I had Twice Cooked Pork, a dish I love but often find disappointing.  Not so here.  My dish was savory, well prepared and I ate it all.  Yum yum.  My husband had Beef in Black Bean Sauce, another dish that can go wrong.  He also loved his lunch and cleaned his plate.  The recipes are not the standard, sauces are darker in color, tend more towards savory, portions just right.  Our waiter was friendly to everyone who came in.  We don't live nearby but will make the effort to go there again.
author: Carolyn K.

description: I love you, Eric's! From being one of the first Chinese restaurants to offer brown rice, to your always fresh and crisp vegetables, you are where I go when I want to eat clean. Although the fried tofu and seaweed is pretty amazing. Service is prompt and friendly, the ambience and decor are clean, sophisticated and comforting. Parking is kind of a problem. Eric's is always busy so go early. They are quick with to-go orders too.
author: L. M.

description:
This review is for an incident that occurred about 6 months ago. I'm hoping it hasn't happened again since then.

I ordered takeout from this restaurant frequently for about 2 years. It was my absolute favorite Chinese spot up until one day when my boyfriend and I decided to eat inside. I don't recall what I had ordered but as I had picked up a spoonful of rice, i saw something shiny on my plate. I pulled it out and saw that it was a piece of steel wool. I was so shocked that I didn't even know what to say. I had thought very highly of the restaurant up until then and didn't think they would be careless enough to leave something like that in a rice cooker. I used to work at chipotle and used to clean out the big rice cookers so I chose not to get upset and calmly called the waiter over and showed him what I had found. He looked at me weird then took it from me and said he would ask his crew about it. He came back about 20 minutes away and said my meal would be free. His tone made it seem like he felt more annoyed than empathic about my inconvenience, as if I had placed it there myself. Neither of us have returned and we suggest friends against going there.
author: Janette M.

description: If you are in the area come here!!!! The General Tsos was lit and the service was awesome. The waiter made suggestions and was very cool. Parking in the area is street parking, unfortunately. The spicey chicken was also an excellent dish.
author: Gabrielle M.

description: Never disappoints.  The food cannot be matched when it comes to healthy and flavorful Chinese.
author: James M.

description:
Eric's is one of those restaurants that I constantly crave and luckily, I leave near by and the prices are cheap enough that I can satisfy those cravings. I keep coming back for the food (obviously) as well as the big portions, friendly service and fast delivery.

Favorites of mine include the Hot and Sour soup (you have to try this), Mango Chicken and Buddha's Delight. My boyfriend, I swear, would eat their General Tso's Chicken every day if possible. They do charge for rice, but the price is pretty minimal and since it's already a relatively cheap meal, this isn't a huge issue.

Is the Chinese food authentic? Absolutely not. Is there a culinary creativity to these dishes? Not really. Is the execution fabulous? 100%. If you are in Noe, I HIGHLY recommend you come here. You cannot go wrong.
author: Carrie W.

description: This is my favorite Chinese place in SF. LOVE, LOVE, LOVE Eric's! The sesame beef is my favorite, but everything I've had over the past 6 years has been perfect. Not one single bad visit. That's quite an accomplishment. The main male server is so kind, as has been ever server we've encountered there.
author: Amber M.

description:
I visited with friends for dinner and found the food to be very mediocre.  The Walnut Prawns $11.95 looked wonderful in what might be a fried won ton bowl but they were soggy and just so overall unappealing we did not finish them nor take the home.
.
The Spicy Smoked Pork $10.95 might have had some liquid smoke on it but really didn't taste smoked. Although it was very thin and decent pork, it was just too salty in may be a teriyaki sauce.  
.
And, finally the $9.75 Mixed Mushrooms, Pea Pods & Water Chestnuts seemed a bit bland but was perfectly prepared.
.
It really pains me to leave only two stars, it is my sincere hope that what ever the cause for this unremarkable change is remedied quickly.
author: Caesar A.

description: Late review. Stopped here at a whim. The service was good. We were seated promptly, order taken promptly. The food was mediocre in my opinion - We ordered spicy egg plant, hot and sour soup, and chef's special lamb. The Spicy egg plant was the only thing which had some flavors (it was too salty though), the lamb was kind of bland (and there was hardly any lamb). Hot & Sour soup was Meh. I think there are better chinese restaurants in the neighborhood including Alices and Hunan restaurant.
author: Chet L.

description:
This is probably the best Chinese food I've ever had. My favorite dish was Eric's combination, 
won ton soup. I would definitely go back.
author: Ana P.

description:
The food is delicious here and it's vegan friendly. Loved the Eggplant and the Kung Pao.  

The dining room can be kind of loud and the service can be just a little clunky, but these minor flaws won't keep me from loving this place.
author: David T.

description: This is my favorite Chinese place in SF! Amazing hot and sour soup, awesome apps, yummy tea upon arrival, and the Hunan lamb and Mongolian beef are amazing! Good old fashioned Chinese food that doesn't skimp on the meat and delicious sauces. I love this place!
author: Nathalie S.

description: Eric's is a nice neighborhood Chinese standard, especially if you like lightly seasoned or not too heavy dishes. Still very satisfying, and very friendly staff. Avocado egg rolls are a strong move, hoist your hunger pants.
author: Christian L.

description: I was calling for a pickup. I saw the menu and prices previously so I knew what I wanted.  Upon getting to the cashier to pick up my order I was told of the total. I was shocked because the prices online DO NOT reflect the actual price and so buyer beware!  They should have told me over the phone of the price change at the very least.  When I told the cashier of the price difference I saw, she/he said that it has been that way for a long time, as if I should have known. I would have ordered differently if I knew. That is why I wouldn't give it a 5. Owner~Update your prices on your website bro.    P.s The food was good though.
author: Pamela A.

description:
I've been going to Eric's since around 1994( and boy has a lot changed in SF since than) 
Eric's is a no frills good time restaurant with really nice hardworking staff and really good americanized chinese  food. Nowadays a deli sandwich or burger or bad cocktail will cost you 15 bucks.
So my point is support these folks and your palate will be happy.
author: she o.

description:
I stopped by Eric's on my way to tour an apartment down the block on Church St. The location was very busy for a Wednesday afternoon so I decided to stop in. The lunch menu had a wide variety of selections at very reasonable prices, and includes a cup of soup, water, and a pot of hot tea for under $10.

The atmosphere was peaceful, and I was served a glass of water and hot tea the moment I sat down. 

I first was served the soup of the day, which was Hot & Sour that was excellent.  I ordered Kung Pao Chicken (one of my Chinese go-tos) and it was very good, albeit a little too much salt. And lunch was finished with a couple of orange wedges and a fortune cookie. 

Overall, loved the atmosphere, the service, and the portions of the food. Would recommend toning down the salt a little bit, though I admit that I have a sensitive pallet when it comes to salty foods.
author: Mike D.

description: Thank goodness Eric's was open when Toast disappointed us by closing a half hour early. Their friendly staff greeted us with hot tea and ice water with lemon. So attentive and courteous. And the food? Delicious!!!
author: Tim G.

description: Best egg rolls in a long while, the broth in the wonton soup is somthing that makes your tast buds vibrate with pleasure, and  the twice cooked pork with brown rice makes two delishes meals, (hearty amount).    Gunther d.
author: Gunther D.

description: Food poisoning. Went with my 4 y/o daughter for dinner. Ordered rainbow fish and the lamb. Got home my daughter started complaining of her tummy. Then she start throwing up the fish and rice. Terrible experience for her. Never coming back.
author: Roman O.

description: Egg rolls and avacado rolls are incredible. Eric's Spicy Chicken was not very spicy so ask for more heat if you like that.
author: James R.

description: I have been going to Eric's since '95. They manage consistency for all these years. Best General Tso I ever had, just ask for extra sauce. Veggies are always fresh and cooked perfectly. It's plain inside in decor but the true experience is in the plate, the food is great. Most dishes are really good a few are bland but some people like that.
author: Bruce B.

description: Go to Chinese restaurant in the neighborhood.  Always tastes super fresh and delicious, hits the spot every time.  Thank you for all the awesome food over the years!
author: Emma A.

description: Extremely racist  treated very unfairly..seated next to restroom and kitchen when there were open spaces in front. When it came time to pay they counted the money in FRONT of us as if we weren't going to pay and we paid 25% tip! We noticed they bagged everyone else's food for them and we had to bag ours ourselves...it's crazy because the item we ordered was not to our satisfication and we still took it to go instead of returning it. We were very embarrassed! Will not be returning and we will be reporting them!
author: Asia S.

description:
Good food, bad service. Which is strange, because the guy was polite enough to other tables. That said, good service is not what we come here for.

The walnut prawns are always good. Don't expect authentic Chinese food here. It's American Chinese food, and it's pretty good.
author: Steven W.

description: While visiting friends in the Bay area, we walked by this place a few times. This unassuming storefront be on a busy street looks like a mediocre American version of Chinese food. There's nothing wrong with that, but I like authentic food/cooking. It was one of those nights not knowing what we should eat. When our friends suggested Eric's for dinner. We did take out and to my surprise, it was really amazing. Never realized this place turned out authentic Chinese food. I'll be going back again when I'm up in the Bay area.
author: Cindy B.

description: We have eaten at this place several times. The food is average, often greasy but passable when you are  hungry and out for a late lunch. We were there this afternoon.  We were the only customers, both of us seniors.  The waitress brought the  food. We were about to start eating when hell broke loose in  the kitchen. We heard an angry man  shouting at a woman in full voice. She screamed and cried. I asked the waiter and waitress what was  happening, but they stayed away from us, as if afraid of answering. The chaos only stopped when i got up  and threatened to call the police. Only then did the waitress alerted the man in the kitchen to cease. "I told him to stop," she said. We will never again patronize this restaurant. It will always remind us that behind its facade of civility things may not too safe in the kitchen for the females working there.
author: George W.

description: I have been going to Eric's for two years on a very regular basis. I receive fabulous service from Ben and Esther. Although everyone, including Wil,  has been gracious and kind but these two make things perfect. Ben is charming and friendly and always gets my order just right. I say that because we do  make some changes from the typical offerings. He is always smiling and makes us feel like we are home. Esther remembers little things and always tries to make me happy. She is warm and thoughtful. So service is wonderful at Eric's. We eat a variety of things when with family members and fairly repetitive when one or two of us. I say this to show we experience many dishes. We are happy to have found Eric's and will continue going regularly. An additional note is about the bathroom. The bathroom is always clean. This is very important to me! I appreciate knowing I can walk in comfortably and use it without concern.
author: Pamela S.

description:
Honestly, Eric's has been a favorite for a long time, but I hadn't been spending much time in that neighborhood in the last few years. The other night, it was Chinese New Year weekend and I decided that I really did want some good Chinese food for dinner. 

It's a unique Chinese restaurant in that the walls are white, it's got a ton of orchids everywhere and there is zero tacky cliche ethnic decorating. I enjoy being there. 

We had beef and snow peas, pot stickers and honey walnut prawns with white rice. It was delicious, and we felt really good when we left. My only complaint was that they ran out of tea, so no tea...which is pretty funny at a Chinese restaurant.  I guess it was a very busy weekend with it being their holiday and all. The staff  was very nice and attentive although it was packed. There was almost a line out the door for their take out. Again, I think part of that was owed to the holiday. They also have a nice lunch special menu, but their prices are super reasonable to begin with.
author: Rachel L.

description: This place is perfect! The hot and sour soup is one of the best I ever had and the General Tso's is great! I only wish it came with a vegetable like broccoli.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Went here with some friends this past weekend.  I liked how clean the restaurant is.  There are not a lot of items on the table.  Just a napkin and utensils.  Items slowly start to build as your food comes in.  Enjoy how fresh everything is.  

One thing that I noticed, is a lot of families with kids.  Babies crying, kids walking around in the front near the door way.  A kids potty seat in the bathroom.  That takes away from the adult atmosphere, but the food makes up for it.
author: Michelle M.

description: Not great.  I will preface this review in saying that I am Chinese, and born and raised in San Francisco.  We ordered approximately 5 dishes including spicy eggplant chicken, broccoli cashew chicken, broccoli tofu, spicy smoked pork, veggie lo mein, and rock cod in white garlic sauce.  The majority of the dishes were too oily and too salty.  The same sauce was used for all the dishes except the rock cod in white garlic sauce; they isimply added peppers to make the "spicy" dishes spicy with their brown sauce, and for that reason all tasted the same.  They poured this sauce on top of the lo mein, too .... Traditional lo mein does not have sauce poured on top of it. The food was just about drowned in this sauce, and all the ingredients were brown because of how much sauce was used, including the broccoli.  The spicy smoked pork was dry and tough. I did enjoy the rock cod in white garlic sauce. The spicy eggplant was good, but again just too salty and oily.  I'd go back if I was in a fix for food, but I would definitely request less sodium and less oil.
author: Rosalie L.

description: Terrible Chinese food.  I had mango shrimp and kunpao chicken.  It appears they use the same sauce , disgusting brown with a ton of sugar and the tiniest bit of pepper in the kunpao. I don't understand how anyone could give this garbage a 4 or 5 star rating. I came here because of the positive yelp reviews and can only assume those people have never had even mediocre Chinese food, let alone good Chinese food . Complete waste of money, hundreds of better Chinese restaurants in SF. Don't waste your money, go anywhere else
author: Biggwally K.

description: This is my family's favorite place to eat. And, you cannot  visit us from out of town without us taking you there... Shanghai  Chicken rules!
author: Eric G.

description:
I've been here so many times and I love it everytime. The service is great, and the food is as well. 
My favorite appetizer is the cream cheese crab rangoon. If you like rangooons, do yourself a favor and just try them. They have so much cream cheese it's amazing. 

I love almost all of their menu items. We normally ask the waiter for recommendations and sometimes do our own thing. But every single dish we've ordered has been great.
author: Margaret K.

description: I really don't understand why this restaurant exists in a food mecca like SF. It's a throwback to the 1970s when Chinese food was first introduced to the American palate? Remember chop chuey? Well, at least chop chuey is not on the menu. Every dish is flavored with an overly sweet sauce. The dishes that are labeled spicy? Forget about it. It's sweet. Everything tastes the same because they use the same sauce. Not to diss the other patrons, but they seemed like the crowd that would appreciate Panda Express as authentic Chinese food. Actually, Panda Express does seem like gourmet, compared to Eric's. On an end note, how could anyone mess up fortune cookies? The ones they had were stale.
author: Calforever C.

description: One of my favorite Chinese food spots. The location is super peaceful. Really beautiful setting. Small and cute. The food is amazing. Full of flavor. Love the broccoli beef and avocado rolls. Great for a date night. Prices are great.
author: Nicole J.

description:
consistant.
clean.
yummy.
friendly.
great, great, lunch deals.
completely off the beaten path. many san franciscans know it, but not all. rarely is there much of a wait, but even when there is - they move things along quickly.

parking can be a hustle at times. and yes, I think dining "in" is better than taking your order "to go."
author: Nick S.

description:
Got their potstickers appetizer. There was hair on it. Sure, I was grossed out....but having worked in the restaurant industry....I get it, it happens.
I sent it back, requesting a new one. 
My friend already laughed, saying: you know they'll take the hair off and send the same one out again. 
(I wished he wasn't right) 
Got the " new" potstickers and after eating half way through, I saw another hair. So, sadly, my friend was right. 
Stopped eating right there, didn't even tell the waiter anymore, because clearly, either he or the kitchen staff ignored my request. 

The rest of the meal was fine (hence the extra star) but I won't be back.
author: Anett R.

description: Good food and much nicer atmosphere than most Chinese restaurants. Delicious gyoza and hot and sour soup.
author: Chris G.

description:
Eric's has the best Chinese food that I've ever tasted. We live a few blocks away, but I honesty didn't start going there regularly until the last 10 or so years. Despite being almost next door, I first heard of the place from a recommendation from someone at my high school in Marin. This was in 2007 or so. A teacher who realized I lived in Noe Valley mentioned that I have to try this place. The teacher lived in Marin, and said she went there every time she was in the area. Soon after, I decided to try Eric's. Long story short, I've ordered almost everything on the menu, I've done both takeout and eating in. The signature secret sauce that they use on almost every dish makes my mouth water even in my sleep just thinking about it. All of the food is incredible, there is no comparison. I've been to Chinatown in SF, and have also tried numerous other Chinese restaurants, but none come close to the excellence of Eric's. My favorite dishes are Eric's Chow Mein (a mix of beef, chicken, pork, noodles, veggies), Mu Shu Pork, Fried Rice, and Great Won Ton Soup. The sauce is the key. It's the key to all their dishes, I must repeat that. The best way to describe the sauce is "heaven on a spoon". Aside from the food, the place is clean and well lit, and priced cheap for SF Chinese food. The food portions are nicely large, and you get the same portions whether or not you take it to go or eat there, 

I've been to Eric's over 100 times, and the consistency is incredible. 10/10
author: Zach S.

description:
2 soups and some avocado rolls.  The food was tasty, though both of us thought it was bit greasy (keep in mind we're talking about soup here).  

I would've classified it as a craving-fulfiller if not for the food poisoning we both suffered in the middle of the night.  I'm known to react to some cheap oils like canola and my husband has a longstanding issue with MSG, but we rarely BOTH get sick from the same food, which makes me pretty confident that it was in fact food poisoning.  

I don't think we would've returned regardless, but after that I would warn people to prepare themselves!  Load up on Imodium and Gas-X and take your chances.
author: Kali M.

description: Great flavors, classic menu, attentive staff, and just the place to be when you need some Chinese food!
author: Kimberly C.

description:
Very slow/poor service.    I had to get up three times to ask for our bill, explaining that we had an appointment and needed to leave.   It took 15 minutes to get the bill.   The main dish took an hour to arrive.

The food was okay but I was sick within the hour.
author: Mark K.

description: Thank goodness Eric's was open when Toast disappointed us by closing a half hour early. Their friendly staff greeted us with hot tea and ice water with lemon. So attentive and courteous. And the food? Delicious!!!
author: Tim G.

description:
First, let me say that I'm not a food snob and I've gone to Eric's many many times since moving to Noe Valley 4 years ago. Tonight I was eating by myself and decided to order Eric's Kung Pao chicken to go with some brown rice. I just have to say it's probably the worst Chinese food I've ever had! The chicken was not boneless, in fact there were bits of bone and gristle in every third bite. And the pieces of chicken themselves - were they from the back - the feet - what was it? The worst most gruesome looking parts - horrible. I threw half of it down the disposal.
It's too bad. I'd gladly pay a dollar or two more for some decent chicken in the dish!
Really bad.
It will be a while before I go back and I won't be ordering Kung Pao chicken!
author: Charles B.

description: Four of us were looking for a pleasant dinner at Eric's. it definitely was not!  One of us was served his entree after waiting for 40 minutes. Thirty minutes later there was still not one entree served to the rest of us. After asking one of the waiters when the rest of us would be served - we just got a shrug. Twenty minutes after that and still not having been served, we cancelled our orders and left.  We got no apology and in fact were mocked as we left the restaurant. Will never go back to be treated so rudely again.
author: Sarah G.

description: I finally made it to Eric's and arrived before 3pm before the daily specials were over. I had the beef with snow peas.  I was immediately served water, hot tea and a delicious cup of hot and sour soup.  I had  a generous portion of rice, beef and snow peas.  The beef was tender and the snow peas were fresh and crunchy! Just a little bit oily to my taste but overall it was great.  Friendly staff and clean ambience.  Excellent location as the J Church (Muni Metro) stops right in the corner.  I will go back and try  other items from their regular menu.
author: Hum V.

description:
So bummed to write this but it needs to be shared.

My boyfriend and I loved Eric's for quick Chinese food in noe. We've been a few times now and have our favorite dishes one of them being the Eric's fried rice. 

We went tonight and ordered said fried rice. My boyfriend chewed a piece of egg shell. Gross but whatever we asked for another order of it. We didn't finish it so took it home. I go for a late night snack and a few bites in chew a piece of egg shell. Like REALLY?! 

Sad cuz we really liked this place...
author: Amber W.

description: Eric's is probably my fav Chinese food spot. Cannot go wrong with food here. So delicious. I just wish they delivered for those lazy days. I have nothing bad to say about the food I've had here.
author: Nawal W.

description:
I go to Eric's whenever I'm too lazy to cook dinner which is about once a week or so.  I love this place and have been going there for such a long time.  
Thanks to one of my best girlfriends for introducing me to this place way back  in our partying days.  I have many fond memories of this place.  This is where my husband and I spent many of our dinners back when I was in college.  This is the place where I told my friends I was expecting a little one.  This is where I took my mom to have dinner a little while after we found out she had breast cancer.  She's in full remission now, thank goodness. 

I find so much comfort in the food here and the fast, friendly service.  I think one of my fortune cookies here stated, "You will marry the person you are sitting across from" and that person happened to be my boyfriend who is now my husband.  How cool is that?  And how spot on right!?  My last fortune cookie here stated, "You will never have to worry about a steady income", which hopefully means that I am winning the lotto. Ha!  A girl can dream right? 

Anyway, my go to items are the honey walnut prawns and mango chicken.  I can't ever go wrong with these items.  My husband and little boy also love the sesame chicken.  I also like their fried rice.   This is one of my regular places and I absolutely love it.
author: Christine P.

description: Very good food, solid service, will definitely be back. Food was flavorful and well-cooked.
author: Samir W.

description: My favorite Chinese food in the city. Love the location, love the friendly service and love the food.
author: Angelica W.

description:
Erics is part two of my holy trinity of easy going Chinese lunch spots in San Francisco.

My three have some things in common.  They are all in converted old Victorian Houses, because what could be better than eating a great, inexpensive lunch in a Victorian house in San Francisco?  They all serve a light version of Chinese food, that is heavy on vegetables, and they have great lunch specials.  

Erics is no exception.  Located in a small, corner Victorian house in Noe Valley, Eric's serves up some very good dishes including a minced chicken with fried basil dish, a super tangy sweet and sour soup, and an fantastic house eggplant dish with chicken and prawns that gets me everytime.

My holy trinity consists of Erics, Alice's and Eliza's.  Some of my favorite dishes at Eric's unfortunately cannot be ordered on the lunch menu, but they are generous, and as a share, one or two dishes will go far with a party of two.
author: Rachel H.

description: Giving this place three stars because it tasted great, but not so much when I spent all night long puking it up. No one else in my party got sick, but then none of them had seafood like I did. Had to skip a couple days  of my trip to San Francisco (came for New years) because I was too weak to leave bed...I'd still go there again but never order seafood.
author: Allison R.

description:
Absolutely delicious. Came into Sam Fransisco from the Orange County area!! Our cousins took us to this Gem and we ate at this delicious place. 

We ordered (mushu) with prawns, it looks like a burrito! The waitress rolls it at the table, and serves you! I can't believe how delicious this was. The chow mein, Mongolian beef, and king poa chicken were also great. 

Will definitely come back!!!
author: Linda G.

description:
I've been going here for a few years. The food is great. They will honor your request if you would prefer less salt or spices. The service is good and they are very attentive.

Well worth it!
author: Alexander M.

description: Horrible, first time trying and again horrible! I know great Chinese food and this isn't one of them! First of all I came in there to order to go, every qiestion I ask him was followed by a NO. So rude, not good Customer service either. Wontons in the soup were soggy and grainy. Disgusting! Won't be surprised if they go outta business soon. NEVER AGAIN!!!! : ( : 0
author: Joanna S.

description: This place is a gem! Great food, reasonable prices and a cozy environment. My wife and I go here all the time. And pickup is super quick too. I highly recommend if you're craving Chinese food!
author: Jim C.

description: Well, where do I start?  Not only is the food superb, but the service is quick and friendly, prices are reasonable and noise level is low (we were there on a Monday 5:15).  The walnut prawns were tasty with a delicate batter, smidgen of sauce dribbled on them, crispy walnuts sprinkled generously about and served in a delightful baked (or fried?) pastry bowl.  The lamb was lightly blackened -- amazingly tender & tasty with a rich sauce and fresh vegetables mixed in.  All this with clean white tables, icy cold water and a full pot of tea--served with a smile.  Can't remember having better Chinese food in the Bay Area.  I wish we had room to order more.  Unfortunately, we'll have to come back!
author: Diane G.

description:
Vegetarians Beware! 
Eric's used to be a great place for the lunch special.
A sunny spot with window seats.
Has Eric's changed hands?

We found out today that almost everything on the menu uses chicken broth - EVEN the vegetarian dishes with fake meats.

The hostess informed us that everything has chicken broth and "vegetarians cannot eat here."
We were confused.

We asked the server and he said, "No, that's no true". We asked, "Are you sure?"
He assured us we were fine. 
The hostess said something to him in Chinese and then he came back from the kitchen and told us that the sauces "have just a little bit."

We paid for our avocado rolls and got up and left.
We feel betrayed because we were clearly lied to. 
No wonder so many of the recent Yelps mention greasy food (even the soup) and food poisoning.
Yuck.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
3.5 Stars--I WISH THEY WOULD SERVE HALF-ORDER OF POTSTICKERS LIKE BRANDY HO & Many other places do! I would come here more often if they did. Their potstickers are really good though. We're not vegetarians, but I nearly ordered the fake chicken cos it looked really good. Bf likes it. I went for the spicy eggplant, shrimp chicken thing. It was too sweet for me--cloyingly sweet. It's described as spicy but it's not. To me, spicy is tangy & well, spicy-- with peppers. They might want to add to the menu that the dominant flavor is plum sauce. Bf didn't care for it either. The waitress was nice & sent it back--I ordered Kung Pao chicken instead. It was really good. Not super spicy either, but good flavor & fresh zucchini, water chestnuts  & red bell peppers nicely cooked-- still crunchy! I still prefer Brandy Ho but the parking is easier on Church than in North Beach. Reliable neighborhood spot. 
The restaurant is still the same after all these years, very clean and bright, with nice flowers.
author: Scott F.

description: Love this place! I go there almost every week, the food and service are perfect. Good prices too. Great option in the neighborhood. My husband could eat their General Tso's Chicken everyday!
author: Lucy D.

description: Sooooo delicious!! I always Love coming back. :) the service is mostly very fast and friendly. And lastly the prices are well worth for the food. :)
author: Lala T.

description:
The family restaurant is my second favorite Chinese place in SF, right behind Mission Chinese. I'm not a huge fan of Chinese cuisine, but I really appreciate the simplicity and dependability of Eric's. Too many restaurants in the city spend an inordinate amount of time and money achieving a perfectly calculated atmosphere - because let's face it: the decor and overall vibe are hugely important toward the outcome of a restaurant. Eric's success is far less calculated. The noise level never exceeds moderate to low and the mustard yellow walls make it clear there was no interior designer involved. The extensive but well organized menu is one of my favorites.

The full review is on: https://eatingthroughsf.squarespace.com/reviews/erics
author: Lily K.

description: Super friendly service and generous portions. We were looking for some tasty satisfying Chinese, and we got it. Order the spicy eggplant and you won't regret it!
author: Megan B.

description:
Been coming here for about 9 years and was really bummed yesterday. We came for an early dinner before the Giants game and we didn't see any staff for at least 15 minutes while they helped 2 other people. We ordered pot stickers, house rice, general chicken, sweet and sour chicken and broccoli beef. Food was just ok, not spicy enough, and we asked for a side of sweet and sour they brought hot oil?
Gave it 3 stars for cleanliness and decent food. Nothing special anymore
author: Ann G.

description:
I was in SF today, not far from here, so I picked up take out...orange beef and drums of heaven. Just as yummy as I remember when I used to live closer.  It was after 1pm, but the place was packed, and parking took awhile, circling for a spot...surprising for a Tuesday afternoon, in a residential neighborhood. 
Glad to see that the menu was about the same, and favorites still flavorful, crisp, clean environment...this continues to be a good neighborhood joint...a nice surprise!
author: Lynn C.

description:
I too like the previous reviewer was really bummed by the really horrible food served at our favorite Chinese restaurant.  We have dined there for years and have many favorite dishes.  After the substandard meal we had
we were embarrassed as we had taken good friends for dinner.   Sweet and sour pork with tomatoes and pink sauce?  Walnut prawns in a stale tasting sauce and soggy shell.....the worst was the pot stickers that tasted like they were stuffed with dog food!......sorry ....but the bloom is off the rose....fire the chef!
author: John m.

description:
Believe the hype! This place is great, I feel lucky to live just a couple blocks away! From the lovely interior to the hot tea served as you're seated, this neighborhood gem is sure to become a regular stop for me. Don't mind the spelling errors, this menu delivers! The crab rangoons were delicious! Served with spicy mustard and sweet n sour sauce, I'd advise mixing to two together for a tasty dipping condiment. The pot stickers are a must try. They are large and with 6 to an order they're perfect for sharing. The pot stickers are steamed and then crisped up in the pan which creates a fantastic contrast in textures. It was obvious why these were on multiple tables across the restaurant. 

The list of entrees is as appetizing as it reads! We chose to start at the beginning with general tso chicken and were not disappointed. The nicely sauced nuggets were fried perfectly and with two appetizers, the portion was generous enough to serve two! We are looking forward to our next visit and sampling more if the menu at Eric's.
author: Melissa R.

description: Love love love. Everything on the menu is spectacular. Prices are great. Very clean, beautiful spot.
author: Nancy I.

description:
9/22/13  Dinner

3.5*  The BF decided he wanted Chinese food in Noe. So we came to Eric's. Immediately upon sitting down he commented on how I was the only Asian, or Chinese, diner. That tells you something about the restaurant, right? 

I do like Eric's, despite its somewhat unauthentic dishes. It's actually quite a city establishment---been there for as long as I can remember. When people mention Eric's, I would think of its rival, Alice, in the same neighborhood. 

Menus are in English only. That's tell-tale sign #2 for you. It serves seafood but no fish tank is in sight, sign #3. Chopsticks yes but rice bowl no. Like any Chinese restaurant, menu is huge, divided into beef, pork, poultry, and vegetables. The specials are listed with almost all 26 alphabets. It's clear and straight-forward. You just have to make up your mind.

Half the restaurant got potstickers, egg rolls, broccoli beef, sweet & sour somethin' and the very famous house special sesame chicken topped with black sesame seeds---or a varied combo of them. Coming here means I have to bend a little bit for the white-meat eating BF.

*Egg Rolls ($4.95): Available vegetarian only, with shredded celery, carrot, cabbage, and mushrooms. Two rolls cut in four pieces. A bit greasy and lacking flavor. 

*Walnut Prawns ($10.25): Specials item Q. The walnut prawns here are deep fried in a batter, instead off being dipped quickly in the oil. So it's not the walnut prawns I'm used to, but otherwise very tasty. Served in a "bird's nest" with candied walnuts. They give you plenty of prawns, too.

*Lemon Chicken ($8.95): Tender pieces of white meat chicken in a light batter with lemon glaze. Believe it or not, we have this dish in Hong Kong so it's not something invented to cater for Americans' palette. 

*Pork Fried Rice ($6.95): Rice is dry (supposedly dry because fried rice should be made with leftover rice) and not greasy. Plenty of egg and diced BBQ pork and tiny shreds of lettuce. It's better than I expected. No soy sauce added thank god!

Service was attentive enough for a Chinese restaurant. I'm most impressed that they seated us at the table by the window. They could have put us all the way in the back against the wall since people at the window just got out. They quickly cleaned up and set the table for us. 

Restaurant is airy and bright, free of cooking fume.
author: Matt Y.

description: Best Chinese food in SF south of Chinatown. Definitely my go to. Never disappoints. The service is great; the food is amazing. It's not trendy but I almost love that more. It's a quiet, never crazy busy place to get amazing and well priced Chinese food. If you can try the moo shu vegetables! Yummy!!
author: Kassandra Z.

description: This is a nice neighborhood place for Chinese food. The food is made with fresh ingredients and is tasty. The staff is attentive and pleasant. My favorite place for Chinese food in the neighborhood.
author: Nancy M.

description: I love Erics!  It is clean,  convenient, very reasonably priced and the waitstaff is very attentive.  I typically get the spicy eggplant with brown rice--my mouth is watering--and eat like 3 meals from it. I was there this past weekend and ate the last of my food today (3 meals).  The ambiance is right on,  laid back but upscale. #hiddengem
author: Lynda M.

description: I've gotten takeout from here a few times and it's always been pretty good. The staff isn't the friendliest but the food comes out quickly. They have a nice variety of reasonably priced lunch specials.
author: Diana G.

description:
I like Eric's fine. 

My husband complains because he thinks it's pretty Americanized and he doesn't like that he's usually the only Asian patron. But I'm fine with that.  I'm also fine with the food not being really greasy. 

Potstickers:  good, and actually pan fried which I like.
Hunan Fish: yum. 
Sizzling Rice Soup: broth was good yay 
Mu Shu Pork: good, except they use flour tortillas instead of the traditional pancakes. Oh well.
Rice: choice of brown or white 

It's pretty inside, clean, the service is good, and it's not too expensive. Portions are pretty big.. It's  a nice neighborhood restaurant.
author: El B.

description:
Happened upon this polite Neon spot on a double date...

The date-ees were questionable, but the tofu... oh the tofu..

I'm a meat eater. A carnivore woman moderne. Not once have I ordered tofu with my own two lips.  

"Shhmoney" That's the way my Date Opposite's man summed it up. Delicious beyond comparison and comprehension. I will never be the same.


T           O           F           U        !
author: Claire B.

description:
Have to say that over the years, when we think about Chinese, it's always & only Eric's

Might have to do w/ the fact this place is SO darn close to home or the fact no matter what time we call for take out, our order is always quoted 10 min & they mean it.....it's ALWAYS ready when we get there

And this is regardless, if the place is empty (which is hardly ever) or jampacked w/ people spilling out onto the sidewalk (which is almost always)

Sometimes, there's a bit more heat, or ginger or something slightly different in the dish's sauce - prob depends on who the chef is for that evening - but it's consistently delish

We've also had the good fortune to branch out from our standard dishes over the years & try new offerings such as Shanghai Tofu - which are little cubes of flavorful tofu along w/ some kind of crunchy leafy green......reminds me of a most beloved Thai dish we used to get from Neecha Thai ( which is now closed )

Note to the restaurant.....if you're considering other new dishes, how about offering some kind of pumpkin dish in the future!?  ;-)

But for providing consistency & remaining our go-to Chinese take out spot, have to say a happy 5th star is long overdue
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Eric's is one of my FAVORITE restaurants!!! If you go once... you will understand why! I haven't had a dish that I didn't like! I love their Hot and Sour soup! Very little egg in it and they make it vegetarian style! Not to many places do that... believe me I have looked! 

One of their very best dishes is... their appetizer Drums of Heaven!!! Chicken wings encrusted with garlic and slightly blackened. OMG!!! I don't think I can put in words how good these are! You will just have to try them!!! 

Oh and a few of my favorites... Eric's Spicy Eggplant! Chicken, shrimp, eggplant, jalapeños and a to die for sauce!!! If you want to go veggie than go with the Spicy Eggplant! It's in a yummy garlic and something sauce that it soooo good!!! 

I would also suggest the Shanghai Chicken! It's minced chicken over dried seaweed and pine nuts mixed in... with a yummy sauce!!! I know what you are thinking... seaweed!?!? Believe me... it's not what you are thinking at all!!! It crunchy without that seaweed taste! It's one of my favorite dishes and believe me when I say I am very picky!!! LoL!

Oh and my latest favorite dish is the Hunan Fish! It's sooooo good! I am not a big fish lover but this is sooooo yummy!!! It comes in pieces with a glaze over the top! Very good! 

Not a place you will want to share with your friends because it's busy enough! LoL!
author: Matt C.

description: came on a Thursday with friends. sounds like pretty standard Chinese fare but oh so good! potstickers, sesame beef, spicy garlic eggplant, walnut prawns were all good but man, the salt and pepper tofu was soooo yummy. salty, spicy, little crunchy squares of tofu with a soft, pillowy center. must try. we noticed a LOT of people waiting for to-go orders. if you call in for a take-out order, allow 30-45 minutes even if they tell you 10-15. otherwise, go!  :-)
author: chris k.

description: Best Chinese food in SF in my opinion. Very fresh and not too greasy. Great potstickers!!!
author: Alyce K.

description:
Well, if Eric's was good enough to be my very first Yelp review over four years ago, then it's certainly good enough to be my 1,475th. Scary, huh? Not Eric's. The fact that I've been to 1,475 places since my first visit there. Oy! I need to cook at home more often. If Julia is about eat, pray, and love, my spiritual journey must be eat, Yelp, and eat again. In the meantime, Eric's is like the Secretariat of Chinese restaurants, a thoroughbred that delivers nearly every time at the finish line... as long as Jamie W. and I stick with the items we always order. 

I still feel the $5.50 bowl of Wonton Soup is the best in the city because it doesn't have that oily broth you usually experience at other restaurants. The broth is clear and fresh-tasting, and the wontons are well packed with flavor. This time, we went for the $9.50 Hunan Lamb, which is leg of lamb sliced in bite-size pieces with red pepper, garlic and chopped spring onions on top (see photo). Tasty and not too spicy-hot. The other dish is unavoidable for us, the $10.25 Walnut Prawns (see photo), because who can deny mayo and honey slathering deep-fried jumbo prawns and candied walnuts?

I still think they need to drop the taco shell for the original crispy noodle basket. The service is still machine-like, and I really wish they would separate the take-out side of their business from the restaurant because I get tired of people staring at me while I gorge. Stop judging me. And parking seems to be getting more painful in this part of Noe Valley. We just don't have the patience to wait for the J-Muni since the city continues to cut back on service. But Eric's is still worth an occasional tap on your bumper... after all these years. 

FOOD - 4 stars...signature dishes like the Walnut Prawns deliver...and the best wonton soup in town 
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...nice converted Victorian but cordon off the take-out customers, will ya? 
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...machine-like waiters who don't have time for chitchat...or order adjustments 
TOTAL - 4 stars...nice to know some places won't ever change
author: Ed U.

description: I have always loved their food. It's not greasy, and its quite tasty. Their prices are very reasonable.

description:
Took a chance and tried their lunch special.  The price is very fair especially in the Noe area.
My first experience wasn't a good one:( need a lot of pepto-bismo afterward.  Not sure if I will go back.
author: Bill T.

description: Best Chinese I've had in a while. The quality of the ingredients are great, the portions big, nothing was greasy and the seasoning was amazing. The Mongolian beef and fried rice were my favorite. We ordered 4 plates(fried rice, Mongolian beef, chicken and sweet and sour pork) for 3 people so we could take it home. It was so good we ate it all.
author: Luci M.

description:
I ordered the 5 Taste Chicken but I swear I only tasted 2--sugar and grease.
Service is always effecient.
Their dishes could use more flavor.
author: Thomas D.

description:
I used to LOVE Eric's....I have been going here since 1991. Until this year, the food has been so great, clean and fresh. The recipes have changed slightly and are just not as great as before...especially the sesame chicken, which was out of this world. 

Really bummed out when I last went, and everything was different, and not good. Boo.
author: Lena H.

description: My favorite local restaraunt. Hunan fish and meatless chicken dish- out of this world. Food is not too heavy and always perfect.
author: Joanna W.

description:
Scene One:  My husband and I have gone to Erick's for many years, but now we will NEVER  MORE.  Our take out meal tonight for the two of us, at about $50.00, was marginally okay. But my love of Wor Wonton soup had turned to rip us off,  Though not on the menu, they have made wor wonton  for me in varying degrees of tastiness. until tonight's surprise which is so bad I am yelping it. I feel very used. Wor means 'every' it is a meal unto itself, a  virtual stew as soup. What I bought was nothing close. Save your money by not going here.Too bad, We've had good times here dining friends. I called Eric's letting them know how displeased I am and would never patron them again. They're answer was to hang up.

Scene Two:  I giave one  of my two orders of Wor Wonton soup to a friend saying how disappointed I am and for him to check it out for himself (and for me too). He tells me about two other friends who also experienced Eric's decline. 

Epilogue: Well the ambiance is still there but the food is somewhere else.

I'm augmenting my review to say Esther called me and demonstrated sincerely their desire to make good and to improve.. So we talked about each dish we ordered. in doing so, realized I should say our Crab Rangoon was the best we ever had because it was.
author: Frank M.

description:
I went to this restaurant with a large party and they accommodated us with no problem.

Their lunch specials are between $6-$7.  It comes with soup, one dish, and rice.  Extra points for them because they serve brown rice here.  I got the spicy eggplant and it was good, and I enjoyed it...but I enjoy it at any Chinese restaurant I go to.  My friend got the chicken curry and that was just okay.  Nothing special.  Another friend got the mango chicken and there was way more mango in there than chicken.  Someone ordered a combo of appetizers and that was pretty good. 

The service is good, the place and its bathrooms  are clean compared to other chinese restaurants I've been to.  You get oranges and fortune cookies after.  I think the lunch special is a good deal, the presentation is nice, and the food is good...but I can't differentiate the food from any other Chinese restaurant I've been to.
author: Angelica T.

description:
Vegetarian pro tip: general tso's fake chicken is omfg good. It will make u say "maybe I am not such an idiot for being vegetarian after all." If I were to start from scratch and name this dish I would call it Adult Tofu Candy.  Seriously it is good, try it.  For bonus points ask for the adult tofu candy, maybe it will catch on.
If you made it this far you're probably not a vegetarian. I will just ignore the fact that you are reading a "vegetarian pro tip" review for now and give you a meat pro tip: I used to go here before I became an herbivore and the adult meat candy (aka general tso's chicken) is also delicious.
author: Rock Rock Robot Rio G.

description:
SO I've been coming here for about 20 years ( omg I feel old) lol 
My mom has been bringing me here for awhile, it was our treat on payday.

First word that comes to mind when I think of Eric's is clean, everything is just so clean to me. It's quaint and charming. The food is really good. I've never had a bad experience here. I've also never really ordered anything different here lol 
Appetizer plate for 2.  that include super good crab rangoon, my fav light n crispy veggie egg rolls and a few other treats. The combo wonton soup is very good. Feels like it's freshly made each time it's served.
We get the sizzling beef and scallops, mushrooms, chestnuts and pea snaps veggie dish along with Eric's fried rice. Usually have a nice to go box from all of that.
Very friendly! Parking might be a little tough on a week night.
author: Angela Z.

description:
Been a customer of Eric's since 1997.  

Stopped in on a Sunday night to a half-full restaurant (yay! no wait, I thought), at about 7:30 pm with my teen son to order a large bowl of hot and sour soup. 

After ordering from male waiter, female worker with black hair and closely cropped bangs approaches our table with the menu pointing out quite adamantly the restaurant's minimum charge per person of $8. 

Really? To a longtime customer and with empty tables?  Huh?
I plan to share this story with each of my 250 + business students per semester (I teach college)  for many years to come -- a fabulous example of how to lose customers.

Bye bye Eric's.  It's been a good run, but on to Eliza's from here on out.
author: Susie S.

description: A small group of ex-coworkers went here for our monthly reunion dinner last night. I'd eaten at Eric's once a long time ago and remembered it was something special. Well, Eric's didn't attain special this time though it was fine in general, more or less. Service was polite and quick, a good thing. The Lemon Chicken and Hoisin Green beans were the highlight, esp. the beans. The pot stickers and egg rolls were way too average. And the Sesame Beef was, I think, overcooked, sort of dry and chewy. It's not suppose to be like that is it? Nonetheless, all in all we had a good time and the food was fine for our purposes I guess. We may or may not be back since our last reunion site closed. oh well.
author: Richard A.

description: This place has great food and the service is quick and friendly! I always come here when I am craving good chinese food.
author: Nicholas F.

description:
I LOVE this place. I can't wait to go back again and again. The food is amazing. The ambience is perfect for nice conversation.

But back to the food.

Won ton soup
I really wanted soup so I ordered a small and it was enough for 2. Good thing I had someone to share with. Often times soup broth can be too salty, but not at Eric's, they got it right and it tasted very fresh. 

What really stood out is the Shanghaii Chicken with chef's special sauce. We decided to order it because of the "chef's special sauce" thinking it must be good. It was so good I'll be back for more hopefully soon. If you usually get the same few things at Chinese restaurants like I do, I encourage you to try this one. It was amazing.

I also have to say that the fried rice was really good too. They put lots of eggs and didn't skimp on any of the meat. 

Extra bonus, we weren't quite done with the conversation after we paid our bill, and no one made us feel hurried to get out. 

I'm so glad to have found this spot. I highly recommend Eric's if you like Chinese food and don't care about fancy decor or swankiness.
author: Monica G.

description: Our take out meal tonight was gross, along with cranky treatment.   We are sad because we have going to Eric's for 10 years; but we don't want to risk feeling badly.
author: Darby A.

description:
I've been coming to Erics for a long time.  Mostly the food is good and the service is the same.  However, the last three times I got food to go, it wasn't very good at all.  Last night I ordered the Orange Chicken.  When I opened it, the food was burnt to a crisp.  I tried to ignore that because I was hungry but I couldn't.  So the trash ate it instead of me.  The time before I ordered the Mongolian Beef.  Chewy is all I can say.  

I give it 3 stars because they use to have better food.  I'm hoping it changes.  Otherwise, I think I'm defecting to Alice's.  Just saying.
author: Ryan B.

description:
I'm really pleased with this place. I'd recommend eating in, as the food is always better served hot and there is free tea :)

This isn't your fanciest Chinese restaurant, but for what it is it's amazing. I'd recommend:
-hot and sour soup
-sesame beef
-mu shu chicken

Definitely give this place a shot. I haven't found a better Chinese place in the area.
author: Rick F.

description: This might just be my new favorite Chinese restaurant on either coast. First of all the staff are wonderful. Friendly and most welcoming, as well spot on in service. The restaurant itself is well lit, spotless and most cozy - the right place either a romantic evening or dinner with friends. And the food, well that was just sublime. The General Tso might be the best out there. Both savory and sweet, with just the right amount of crispness and spice. As for the mu shu pork, it as close to perfection as one can ever get. I cannot wait until my next trip to SF to eat there again.
author: John Jeffrey P.

description: Very yummy Chinese food in Noe Valley. I ordered the hoisin string beans and the general's chicken along with the onion pancake. Every dish was delicious. And the portions were fairly large. The service was abrupt but efficient. The place only opened at 12:30 p.m. for lunch and was packed by 12:45 p.m. on a Sunday, so get there early!
author: John L.

description: The food was amazing and reasonably priced. Loved their sesame beef! We went on a pretty empty day so the food came out super fast. Will definitely go back again.
author: Kyle H.

description:
Eric's is one of my wife & I's favorite places to grab chinese food when we go out! They are very friendly, fast service, and very tasty. We love to order their veggie egg rolls and hot & sour soup. My wife's favorite dish is the Moo-shu chicken wraps (forgive me for most likely spelling that dish incorrectly). They bring over the wraps and make them for you! 

Great food, great service, a great little place. Highly recommended!
author: Betsy K.

description:
This used to be an excellent restaurant, but it has become a sad factory of mediocre and standard dishes. A recent lunch was so bland that it really shocked me. The service was slow despite being only about 1/3 full and the server was rude. Then to have such boring and bland food was so disappointing. 

I used to eat here quite frequently and always enjoyed it. In fact, my first date with my husband was here 17 years ago, so I have very warm feelings for this place. I guess it will now just be a memory.
author: Jonathan P.

description: This place is definitely the best!  Very fast, clean and delicious!  Can't go wrong for American style Chinese cuisine!
author: Dominic R.

description:
I've been going here for two years now and have yet to be disappointed with any facet of this establishment. 

I have never had to season anything I have ordered, as everything is perfectly seasoned. The drumsticks of heaven are definitely heavenly, and I could eat their hot and sour as an entre! Their lunch deals offer a perfect amount of food. The establishment itself is clean. The service here is phenomenal; I have yet to empty a glass, as they fill it as soon as they notice you've taken a dink. Courteous, friendly, efficient.
author: Ash S.

description: Quiet and very nice Chinese restaurant with good American Chinese food. Most items are serve with free grandma style home cook soup.
author: Doris S.

description:
We've been going to Eric's once a month for about 15 years!  It is an attractive restaurant with carved wooden panels, banks of orchids and big windows onto Church St.  Crisp white napkins and tablecloths.  The wait staff is friendly, prompt and professional.  The food is delicious, with good portions, fresh, crispy veggies and plump savory dumplings.   Great soups and dishes with mango.  Generous portion of mushu pork/chicken/etc with expert folding by waitstaff.  The prices are fair and affordable.  $25 for 2 with drinks, appetizer and entree.   And we usually take home left-overs.

Try it and you'll be happy, well-fed and with money left for dessert at Mitchell's ice cream a few blocks away !
author: KH B.

description:
Mo ho ho ho

(evil Japanese anime laugh)

After attending a friend's first SF foray into an art gallery opening, I decided to treat him to some tasty Chinese in my hood and we did this by simply crossing the street:  the seductive and alluring smells wafting out from a well-lit corner establishment herded us straight to the door.

Eric's is situated on a busy corner in Noe Valley.  Granted, my living here has never once tempted me indoors (I usually stick to Chinese on Clement or just simple dim sum I pick during window shopping excursions for cheesy stocking stuffers in Chinatown) but tonight was different.  I had just finished my friends art show, had an hour to kill during a viciously cold breezy evening, then it was off to the Cat Club for some dancing-to-the-80's night.

Small, cozy and warm, we sat by the window which afforded us views of other Noe suburbanites waddling away in their cashmere scarves and Merrell Shoes.  Since it was freezing, we ordered a small portion of their Hot and Sour soup followed closely with their Spicy Eggplant and the pork Mu Shu.

"Rice?"

But of course.  A side of your brown rice please.

I have to say, that every dish was amazing.  The Hot and Sour soup had the right balance and was very savory, with crunchy strips of bamboo and slightly salty pieces of pork.  I may have to request it extra hot for next time since it cooled quickly.  The Spicy Eggplant was sooooooo intense in flavors that I was ladling it right on top of my brown rice, which incidentally, was one of the best bowls of brown rice in my life.  It had a consistent texture and the right amount of "give" as I ate away.  The eggplant was not overdone, usually the consequence of this vegetable being simmered.  But in this case it absorbed the flavors of the sauce without sacrificing the texture of the eggplant.  The Mu Shu was perfect and after the crepes were utilized, I continued to pick away at the julienned slices of veggies and tasty bits of pork.

The beauty of most Noe Valley establishments is that you will inevitably run into someone from the surrounding blocks.  As we consumed our order, several groups of people escaped the cold to take a seat in this little restaurant, smiling and waving as we took turns with salutations.

The prices here are slightly more than I usually spend at Chinese restaurants, but it is probably warranted because it is Noe and add in the exorbitant and insane prices for rent here, I'm not surprised.  

Great food and a perfect little corner spot to keep an eye on Noe traffic, wheels and feet.  Parking is a pain, so if you live a few blocks away, a nice walk will whet the appetite for your meal here.
author: Miika M.

description: Oh, Eric's.  Maybe you're related to the other two restaurants with non-Asian names, and maybe you're not. Maybe the Health Department gets up in your business and says "WTF?!" sometimes.  But you still have THE ROLL.  It's not as big as it used to be, but it's still my avocado roll.   And when I get off the plane? I need THE ROLL.
author: AD J.

description:
This was the first visit to Eric's for all four women in our party, and we all liked it, although I would say it is not strictly Chinese which is OK with me.  If a chef wants to improve on or get creative with a cuisine, then go ahead if it tastes good.  Maybe "fusion" is the latest buzz word.  For instance, the appetizer sampler plate ($7.50) had Crab Meat Rangoon (cream cheese and crab in a won ton skin and fried) and that is not a typical Chinese recipe (maybe Burmese?).  Tasted good, though.

Another atypical thing for a Chinese restaurant...it was CLEAN!  

I wanted to try the large Sizzling Rice Soup ($8) so we could all try it, even though one of our party did not want soup.   Well that changed when she saw it!  It was full of vegetables, seafood, and of course the sizzling rice, so our friend changed her mind and was glad she did.

Our group also ordered Mu-Shu Pork ($8.50), Asparagus Beef ($8.75), Beef with Green Peppers (lunch special...can't remember price), and the Hoisin String Beans ($7.50).

It was a Friday at lunch time and not particularly busy, the service was good.  It was not noisy, which facilitated conversation.  Two hour street parking was easy to find.  

The cost for each of us was $15 with the tip, and we all went away with leftovers.
author: Kelcie T.

description:
