Eric's is modern, fast, tasty, & convenient when in the esteemed Noe Valley. (part of tha statementt is a joke... you get to decide what part).

I kinda like Eric's. Is it the most "authentic" ?, and properly "prepared" ? and "traditional Chinese food" ? ahhhh no. But, hey its in THIS 'hood. So, dumbed down dishes, fast service, English speaking employees rate the 5 star ratings, especially who use the moniker or greeting "dude!". 

Had a couple lunches with a variety of food at the table ( ok, I admit I can not help but snag a bite from any plate on the table) and think it is not bad. Its kinda good *(for what it is).  

Bad ? NO. A-OK yes !
author: Matsuo U.

description: Cute..cute little spot. Nice ambiance and fast service. Eat here or take out. Asparagus chicken with cashews!!
author: Debra A.

description:
My boyf and his family are Noe Valley natives.
When I came to visit them this weekend, they took me to their favorite and go to grub spot -- Eric's Restaurant.

I must say...I was impressed.

Mango Chicken (extra spicy)
Eric's Fried Rice
Drums of Heaven

The extra spicy mango chicken was HEAVENLY DELISHHH.
It wasn't exactly firey spicy like I enjoy, but it was tangy spicy and rich.
Howeverrrr, it was loaded with jalapeno slices...and when you got a bite of that with your chicken...it was fire. And then, the mango complimented the spice to tame it down and give you a zesty flavor. BOOM. ultimate party in my mouth.
-- Please do yourself the favor of ordering this dish.

Eric's Fried Rice is also really good.
It's loaded with all types of meat, but they warn you of that in advance.
It is hands down my boyf's favorite fried rice in the whole entire world. So, to say it was anything less than perfection would be blasphemy.

Drums of Heaven
Unique fried chicken.
They carry a punch but it is a unique flavor. Their dipping sauces are definitely awesome to try with the drum sticks. The more brown/orange dipping sauce is horse-radish-y, but beware, it's reaaaally potent and makes your eyes water (which I enjoy), but if you're not into that, just use sparingly. The other sauce is some sort of sweet and sour sauce. 
To be honest, I'm not sure if the sauces even compliment the taste of the drumsticks...but the drumsticks are awesome, the sauces are awesome, and together it's just a real party in your mouth.

CONCLUSION -- I'll definitely be back and I'll be taking my family and friends. Only come here if you like parties in your mouth.

ohh, and everything is reaaaally reasonably priced.
author: Riana C.

description:
I had a really strange time here.

I met some friends here that knew the restaurant for lunch and while I waited for them I perused the menu. They had several interesting choices on the lunch side so I decided to stick with that. It's not your typical Chinese place, kind of upscale, so a $6 lunch seemed like a great deal.

Everything started fine. We sat down and were given soup and hot tea. One of my friends asked for hot oil, they don't have the condiments on the tables. The soup was a very bland egg drop type thing with lots of tofu and carrots; I didn't like it. After about ten minutes, that is hours in soup time, my friend had to ask for the hot oil again. I tried a bit of oil in the soup but it really didn't improve it much. I tried to eat around the tofu as best I could but left most of it in the bowl.

When they took our order I asked what the waiter recommended and he suggested the Hunan fish. One of my friends ordered a chicken broccoli and cashew dish and the other ordered an eggplant and shrimp thing that wasn't on the lunch menu.

First they brought out the eggplant dish and then the chicken lunch. My friends were sharing so one took some rice off of the plate and the other one started to eat the chicken when the waiter came and took the plate away. He came back with a brand new one and put it down in front of my friend with the only explanation being "you order spicy". I was left sitting there with no food and no plate to put any of the already served food on. I told my friends to please start with out me.

My friend's chicken was way too salty; we all tried it and agreed. We called the waiter over and tried to explain but he didn't understand so the owner came over and I believe he thought we were complaining that there was too much sauce. We decided to switch to pot stickers instead. Still no Hunan fish!

Finally about 20 minutes after the first dish came out I got my lunch. It was very good but I thought a little soy sauce might make it even better so had to ask for it, they don't have the condiments on the tables.

Finally the pot stickers came out and they were the best I've ever had. We wanted to put vinegar on them so we had to ask for it because they don't have the condiments on the tables!

The food was good but the service was a catastrophe. My friends that go there a lot say it isn't usually like that so I'll give them another try and they could very well get another star out of me. 

One bit of advice though; ask for all of the condiments as soon as you sit down so you don't have to wait for them later.
author: Manny F.

description: not sure why most of the dishes have that dark heavy sauce. too bold. Would like to see some dishes with a lighter sauce. These dishes have that heavy sauce: general Tso's chicken, eric's chow mein, mongolian beef, broccoli & beef.
author: Patrick L.

description:
On a business trip, taken here by my colleague who used to live a few blocks away. I can see why this was her standby for fresh, healthy Chinese food. 

Portions were huge (huge!), ingredients snappy. Service, impeccable. Thank you, Stacey!
author: Kate G.

description:
DUDE!
Did I get lucky!  I was heading to a business appt around the corner at the hospital and I was starving.  I was saw this place on the corner and came in with my business partner for a quick lunch hoping for the best.

Food and service were awesome.  Cheap too, in SF no less.  Best Chinese food i have had in a long time.

We sat at the front window watching all some weirdo's walking by. Even got some of them walked in and started talking to us.

I am doing a bunch of business at the hospital so I will be coming here all the time.

lunch for 2 with tip, 21 dollars.  Awesome.  If you are around, come here.
author: Jason G.

description: Best Chinese in Noe Valley. Love the Sesame Beef.
author: Tatyana H.

description:
I've been to Eric's twice recently -  once for lunch and once for dinner and I think its great.  First, I love that its a Chinese restaurant that automatically gives you tea and ice water and keeps the water filled.  I really don't like it at so many Chinese restaurants were I have to be flagged down the servers to get water.  The service at Eric's is great.

The food is delicious and this is coming from a Chinese person who grew up with very authentic food. It's all about how its prepared and its done well - the potstickers are juicy and big, the Eric's fried rice is light, full of egg and scallions, and the mapo tofu has the flavor of the sichuan peppercorns.

Also the prices are great - I came here for lunch with a friend and the 2 of us stuffed ourselves for under $35 with great service.
author: Yin L.

description:
What happened to this place? It's unbelievable the food was so horrible today and not fresh at all!

The avocado rolls were stale and the sweet-and-sour soup tasted and smelled like armpit.The rice was overcooked and the beef and shrimp where very very distasteful!

Something has changed there maybe the chef or the owner I  don't know. What is for sure I will never go back there and really sad about that.
author: Lacio S.

description:
A few days ago, I was helping my daughter, Kris A. move to the city.  It was time to eat, so Kris suggested we eat take-out from Eric's.  Kris and her fiance, Aaron have eaten at Eric's when they lived on Cesar Chavez and Sanchez.  See Kris' review below way past my review.   Surprisingly, Kris' review is a complete 180 degrees from my review and I am her Mom!  

This time, Kris and I ordered won ton soup and four side dishes.  The won ton soup was piping hot that it melted the plastic lid from the styrofoam containers!  The cost of the take-out meal was $35.00.

I must admit I was rudely surprised by the won ton broth because the broth was unusually spicy and lacked the usual ingredients Cantoneese chefs use for won ton soup.  I guess I am hooked since early childhood on Cantoneese cuisine rather than Szechuan.  

I guess I am a wimp, a cry-baby when it comes time to eat spicy foods.  I just cannot seem to tolerate spicy foods which includes Thai, Indian, Mexican and Spanish cuisine.  Anything hot and spicy, I run away everytime!

The side dishes Kris ordered were alright-a little plain, too spicy, sparse with the ingredients-especially the meat, but here again, the side dishes did not satisfy my mild, Cantoneese palate. Nevertheless and despite my review of Eric's, the restaurant was jam-packed full of Eric's cuisine afficianados.  

Strangely, the interior decorum was Asian-Modernesque design, boasting a gargantuan mirror in the center of the restaurant while the front entrance is simply understated, plain, and you could never tell that this place serves Szechuan cuisine or any type of cuisine.  I tried taking a picture of the front entrance of Eric's with my Nokia 6260 video camera phone but, I chose not to post it because the picture was just too oddly plain.  The front door had a graphic picture of a coffee cup . . . this graphic picture struck me as quite odd.  I guess the coffee cup symbolism was surely a juxtapositioning of what type of business operates behind the exterior, but plain facade.  Parking was an issue for me-I had to park a block away, so Kris can order our take-out meal. 

I know I am not an Eric's fan due to not liking spicy foods in the first place and second, I was never a fan of Szechuan cuisine, but that's okay . . . Eric's is fully packed full of Szechuan afficianados, Eric's will not suffer from my review.

I guess I will return eating at the Far Eastern Restaurant on Grant Street.  Maybe afterwards, continue strolling down to my favorite place to snack when I do not feel like eating a formal dinner at the Far Eastern Restaurant . . . eating my dim sum from the Far Eastern Bakery on Grant and Commerical Street, shopping at all the stores on Grant Street and beyond the alleys.  

Ho-hum . . .maybe I'll eat an exotic, seafood Wor Won Ton Soup later for dinner at this restaurant on Washington and Stockton-the right side of the street from the corner. . . oh, I do not remember the name of the restaurant, but it is the traditional, old-style Cantoneese cuisine I grew to love.  I have eaten here so many times with my father since I was a child and before he past away in 2001.  I see all the old people I recognize since I was a child eat here at this restaurant and I know why . . . maybe they do not like spicy foods like me, too.
author: Shirley M. J.

description:
This is my go-to lunch spot when I'm craving Chinese food.  it's not greasy and at $6 for the lunch special it's a no-brainer.

Try the fresh tofu and veggies.
author: Laura P.

description:
I've been to Eric's on average once a week since they opened. That's the mid 1990's as I recall it. They're in my hood plus a club I'm in meets there Thursdays as a group.  I cant imagine eating anywhere else with such frequency. They are definitely "cuisine" - not chow, like Sam Wo's - and with an inventive-yet-steady Chinese-California format.

If you have dietary restrictions, ASK and be specific...they can do you well if you're heart-healthy or gluten free, for instance, but there's not going to be lots of choice there. Go to Millenium or Greens or Ananda Fuara if that's your deal. But, while you're not going to find it a 5star place for vegans, you can still get yourself a Vegetarian meal (if you're Reform but not if you're Orthodox). 

Atkins or other low-carb? No. 

On the other hand everything they serve is yummy and you won't feel awful -or hungry- two hours later. 

The dining room is small and loud and crowded and clean and lovely. They do a brisk business but theres not usually a wait - and if there is its never long. 

The service can be terse but they're quite friendly if you're minimally civil (they're awfully nice to my more difficult friends, though difficult friends tend to remain so). They recognize repeat customers and generally seem to love their service work. So tip them well as you can; theyre not going to get rich there and they are lively folks. Besides, it's the customers that make a good place stay good. 

This is a great neighborhood place - one if the reasons that SF is such a desirable place to live. 

I allot 15 for my solo entree after tip; 20 if I have a potsticker or "carb rangoon" appetizer...both of which never get old. Actually, an order if potstickers is more than enough meal for a solo eater - allot 10$ for that, incl tip.
author: Steve F.

description:
Eric's is my favorite Chinese place in the city.  I was introduced to it by my fiancé who has been coming here since he was a kid.  This is our goto take out spot for nights we don't want to cook or dine out, although I must say the interior is super cute here and the service is always stellar, if you were to dine here.  When you order you food it always ready in 10-15 minutes.   My goto dishes are:

Won-ton soup: always good.  You get two big containers in a large order.  Each container has about 6 wontons, two shrimp, some green beans and carrots.  

Sizzling rice soup: my finances favorite; however we only get this when we dine in

Potstickers: who doesn't love a good pot sticker

Orange beef:  my fiancés favorite entree.  It's really good to be honest and best when it is first served; however, we totally eat the leftovers.  

Chicken with cashews and broccoli:  I always add water chestnuts to this.  This is my favorite dish here

We're had a lot of things on the menu and its all good, but these are our favorites.
author: Lauren T.

description:
Very good Western-style Chinese food, among the best in Noe Valley.  Great take-out option for upper Noe Valley.  Very kid friendly (like most Noe Valley spots).

One negative is the staff can be a bit aggressive during busy times trying to turn tables quickly.
author: Steve J.

description: The food was alright here. Nothing special.  I was surprised I had to ask for soy sauce and spicy sauce. The Mongolian beef is one of my favorite dishes anywhere we go and this place was less than mediocre.  The meat was fatty and chewy. The general tsos chicken was pretty good in my opinion. The rice was way under cooked,  I had a few chunks of raw rice in my bowl.  Not impressed.
author: Nikki P.

description: I came here with a group of friends last sunday afternoon because it was within walking distance from where we all met up. There were 8 of us in the group and they didn't bat an eyelash and promptly adjusted the tables so we could fit. We all ordered and shared everything. By far the groups favorites were the sesame beef, spicy eggplant and the walnut prawns. We enjoyed the meal and there was no rush or hurry for us to leave and it was all very comfortable and relaxed! I highly recommend this place if you are in the area!
author: Trevor D.

description:
Hands down the best chinese food I've ever had. I can't even point to a specific dish that's great because it's all good. Though I guess I would say the moo shu vegetable - is that spelled right? - is insanely delicious. 

Anyway, this one particular time my girlfriend and I went there, ordered our food and began talking, before we knew our food was right there for us! Another time we went back and timed how long it took them to take our order and then for the food to be brought to us. It was 3 minutes! It was insane! The best part of this is that even though it's quick it's not lacking on quality. 

Don't even pretend there's a better place than Eric's. If you're in the area, go. Even if you're not in the area, take a drive over there.
author: Axel F.

description: Great vegan-friendly chinese food. Come here with a mixed crowd to please everyone, or pick up to go. We have only come a few times, but our favorite items are the Shanghai Tofu and the General Tso Meatless Chicken. The meatless chicken is juicy and has incredible flavor, and the Shanghai Tofu is delicious and comes with crunchy greens that really make the meal pop. Great ordered to-go, or eat-in for great service and remarkable ambiance.
author: Nick W.

description:
I have lived in Noe Valley since 2002 and Eric's has always been a popular fixture in the neighborhood.  Generally, i felt that while I never cared for Eric's, it served a purpose as a place for cheap Chinese Food that is aimed at an American palate.  Nothing wrong with that as Dragonwell in the Marina does the same thing, but much better.

However, we recently ordered takeout from Eric's and it was absolutely terrible.  The food was greasy,salty, stringy, and the ingredients tasted cheap. We ordered the food mostly for my nieces and nephews as they love Dragonwell, but Eric's was a poor substitute.  Our dishes are below:

* Beef with Broccolli - salty and greasy.  The broccoili was overcooked and stringy.

* Chicken and Aspagarus - the chicken looked like cat food and was almost unrecognizable as meat of any kind.  Again the sauce was a greasy mess of soy sauce, cornstarch, and juices.

* Garlic Shrimp - The worst dish.  The shrimp was mealy and a low grade of seafood reserved for the worst buffets.  Too much garlic and combined with mushrooms, which was an awful pairing. Again, they used the same disgusting sauce for the Beef, chicken, and Shrimp dishes.

* Potstickers - decent potstickers and by far the best dish.

I have eaten at Eric 3x-4x in my 10 years in Noe and over time the food has gotten worse and worse, while its popularity seems to increase.  I still feel sick from greasy salty sauce on every dish,even several hours after the meal.

Eric's is like a bad Reality TV show - It's terrible and getting worse over time, yet still popular for reasons beyond conventional logic and taste.
author: Zk K.

description:
Once upon a time Eric's had been our favorite Chinese restaurant in the city -- but ever since the rodent and sanitation scare of March 2008 (when it scored a lowly 56 on SFScores.com) we made ourselves scarce. There were too many restaurants almost as good with a 90-100 score sans the mouse poop.

But we couldn't stay away forever.  Eric's SFScore gradually increased  and the General's Chicken and the potato pancakes beckoned. 

While I can't vouch for the authenticity of the food, it sure is yummy. We started of course with Eric's pancakes, dressed with a peanuty garnish that tasted much better than it looked. Next came the Rainbow Fish, a colorful concoction of diced cod swimming in a sea of red, green and yellow sweet peppers and drenched in a flavorful garlic broth. And finally, instead of the General's Chicken, we opted for the slightly more healthy Sesame Chicken sitting on a bed of zuchini and carrots with the occasional celery stick. It did not disappoint. If anything was weak it was the brown rice, which clumped together a little to easily as if it had been in the cooker way too long.

All in all, I'm happy we gave it a try. I'd be happier still if they posted their SFScore in a more prominent location (like the window) and had more frequent inspections (the last one was mid 2009)... but I'll give them the benefit of the doubt. It sure beats our local haunt, King Wah in Daly City, which we grudgingly patronize despite the shark fin soup on the menu.
author: Elvis M.

description: Eric's is good. It's not Chinese fusion or PanAsian--just Chinese food. They do it well and they're really nice. Not sure what else you were looking to find out besides if the food is good. It is.
author: Robert S.

description:
Walked in on 1/5/13 about 7pm, just a party of two.  They were able to accommodate the hot and sour soup (small) without the pork.  We had the spicy scallops w/ broccoli, mu shu (again without the pork), and brown rice.

We had plenty to take home for leftovers (they gave us more pancakes and hoisin sauce) and the bill was only about $30.  No alcohol.  Service was quick and we both thought everything was very good.

We asked a local while we were over at the Dubliner and he recommended it.  If we are back in the area we would definitely go back.
author: Teri X.

description:
When I moved to the area, someone told me that Eric's was overrated. I am really glad that I did not listen to that person and checked it out for myself.

This place is very inviting, but I haven't actually ate there. I usually stop in, place an order to go and wander around the shop next door until my order is ready. The service is very fast and my food is always hot and fresh.

Last night I had the Prawns with Vegetable, which had quite a few large prawns. I hate it when places give you like 4-6 in one dish. It was the perfect amount of food for dinner. 

I also like their appetizer sampler and won ton soup - when it's cold outside. The food has been consistently good, so I keep coming back.
author: Rebekah T.

description: I miss you.  Your fried salt and pepper prawns make me happy.  I think about you often and promise that I will have you sooner than later.  If only you were just a bit closer. Consider opening a Marin location? I know, I know, you do well where you are, but if you ever want to... we'd be happy to have you.  Until next time - thanks.
author: Rayna A.

description: Average place. Been here a few times. People are always double parking on Church to pick up their food. Many people picking up so wait times are long (mine was over 20 min just sitting there waiting for the phone order I called in 45 min prior). Also disappointed by their health inspection scores. Not good. Probably won't be back.
author: Jo M.

description: This is my local standby right around the block and is a great place to grab dinner. They have really great lunch specials and the service is good. My standby dish is the beef and broccoli and it's good and fresh.
author: Bobby H.

description: My dad used to take me here when he lived off Dolores St about 10 years ago. I hate that it's in Noe Valley since I'm all the way in Potrero Hill but it's really worth it. What I love mostly about this place is their orange chicken. I took my friend and his uncle here a few months ago and they loved it.
author: Michael B.

description:
Been here twice, thus far it has not disappointed. The service has always been great, the plates are always nicely presented and they taste just as good. 

The plates are pretty big so definitely sharing is a must. I love the mongolian beef that they wrap into a burrito for you, and the Walnut Prawns. If your planning on going during lunch I'd say you'll be fine, we usually come in at about noon and it's pretty empty, however by the time we leave it starts picking up (1:00pm). 

My second favorite part of going to Erics is baby stroller counting, I'm trying to beat the ultimate high of 10 strollers and hour. If you can beat my record let me know hehehe.
author: Lannette G.

description: Eric's has good food for lunch or dinner.  I probably go here for lunch more than dinner, but I have had both many times.  Eric's ts a nice choice for the Chinese dishes, such as Cashew Prawns, that I have grown to love in my many years in San Francisco.  Service is usually prompt.  Thank you.
author: Christian L.

description: Good chow; mango prawns were excellent (very plump with fresh mango bits) and the pork s were good.
author: J. Mike S.

description: The steamed dumplings were phenomenal (very similar to soup dumplings you get in China). The Spiced Pork with Leeks was also a highlight. Definitely will be back!
author: Ira S.

description:
"Meh. I've experienced better." has never been so true.

I was house hunting in the city with Mark and we ended up hanging out with my old roommate Sunshine/Moonshine the clown. She recommended that we have dinner at Eric's because it is Michelin rated. Yes, it's clean and beautiful. However, those are not the requirements for good Asian food that my mama/family taught: "Follow the Asian people." There wasn't a single one dining there that night. 

We should have went somewhere else, but we were ravenous. Hunger is supposed to make food taste better, but I don't think it flavored our food much. In fact, we had Mango Prawns, Kung Pao Chicken, and Buddha's Delight and Sunshine complained that they all tasted the same, because they were cooked in the same brown sauce.
author: Elaine B.

description:
This is a great Chinese restaurant in the quiet Noe Valley neighborhood. Great food and really reasonable prices. There could be good wait during early dinner rush but they are generally efficient. 
Most servers are very polite and attentive, BUT there're some who should not be dealing with customers at all, like this one guy who- 
1) yells 'WHAT' from across the hall when you want something and signal to him, 
2) tells you 'rice is free,  no problem' when you ask for another serving as if it's a big deal to pay for freakin bowl of rice, 
3) tell us "we close shortly" while you're eating and then just stands there...."when you ask what would you like us to do? and jokingly say we'll eat faster"...then clears it up that he wants us to pay early....which we do. Brings the receipt and at 9:20pm (10 mins BEFORE closing) then gestures from across the room to sign it! At this point I had to tell him to not rush us or be rude and let us eat!! Thankfully other servers saw this and came to our rescue, they were apologetic and very attentive.
4) he then continues to sing loudly, stretching his body as if he's in his living room, trying to show with attitude that he doesn't care about his incompetence 

That one rude guy definitely needs better training or should not be dealing with customers in the dining room!
author: A K.

description: Eric's offers the best Chinese food! You can't go wrong with any of the items on the menu. If you're a first-timer, I would suggest to try the walnut prawns, any of the mu-shu dishes, their fried rice, and their shanghai or sesame chicken. I will drive an hour on a weeknight just to eat here because we always know we are going to get high-quality, made-to-order Chinese food. The staff is accommodating if you don't like your food spicy and very attentive even when it gets busy (which is almost all the time). Their take-out counter seems to be just as busy as the dine-in service with all of the locals who frequent there.
author: Allyson Y.

description: Your next door family feeling restaurant with excellent service. The wonton soup is delicious and so is Mongolian beef!
author: Sachin G.

description: This a good place to go to if you want really good Chinese food. The best part about this restaurant is that it is in a really nice neighborhood.
author: Isaac H.

description: Sorry, Eric's, I know you're a neighborhood institution, with a delightful owner and servers, and a fun people-watching location...but I found the food to be only ok-but-not-great. So please folks, don't make a special trip to this place, but if you're in the neighborhood, and they've got a table, you'll be fine.
author: Elizabeth R.

description: I love Eric's Chinese so, so much! I once ate there 3 times a week. For a few weeks. It was amazing every single time. By far the tastiest chow mein in San Francisco! They are always so sweet every time we come in. The decor is pleasant and the place is always very clean. I also love the hot and sour soup and fried rice. Dip some rice in the soup for the full effect! Definitely go here if you haven't already. You won't be disappointed unless you are pointedly looking for something to be disappointed in.
author: Morgan B.

description: Went to Eric's last night . Was reluctant after reading all the negative reviews, we ordered my favorite Eric's fried rice, sweet and sour pork, crab Rangoon, potstickers and beef chow mien ,everything was great. We had a nice waiter and did not feel rushed to get out of there. My husband and I are San Francisco natives that have moved away so it was nice to go back to one of our old restaurants and see that they are doing well and the menu has not changed since they first opened. We were customers 24 years ago when they were new to the neighborhood now they are a go to place if you want great Chinese food. We will try to go back more frequently. My absolute favorite dish there is the Eric's fried rice in my opinion nobody makes rice as good as this and I have to eat it every so often to fulfill my cravings.
author: Rosemarie M.

description:
They rise the price but the potion become smaller.
And I found roe tini meat on my beef dish...........
The walnut shrimp was not crispy, the walnut is not as good as before.
author: Annie D.

description:
Update on my review based on two recent visits

*Surly lunch service, bordering on yelling. No substitutions at all. No you may not have fried rice instead of the steamed rice. Ok, dude, I hear ya.

*General Tso's is now virtually blackened beyond recognition. Used to be a better, fresher dish. Now resembles gristle.

*Fried rice does need some moistness as it now tastes like warmed over Panda Express

*Mongolian Beef does not look anymore like before. Thin dry rice noodles are indistinguishable from morass blackened sauce.

*Pot stickers need seasoning in the filling. Also dreadful when cold as the grease coagulates.

*Gotta hand it to the hot and sour soup, still shines.

*This place doesnt take Am Ex. What's up with that?
author: Alfonso L.

description:
I went to Eric's just the other day and I can say that I was very disappointed. The restaurant has become a family restaurant with many young screaming children.  It's turning into a Chuck E. Chinese restaurant.

We ordered the lemon chicken that had a bright orange artificial color, it was exceptionally sweet and all the pieces of chicken were all the same size and shape, which led me to believe it was frozen and very appealing to small children.

 The soup was bland and the potstickers lacked Chinese spices. The quality of the food has suffered tremendously and seems to be catering to the palate of small children.
I will never go there again.

 A lot of restaurants in Noe Valley are suffering because of this.

 Why not have a children's menu instead?
author: J D.

description: Excellent and attentive service is always such a relief.  I will always come back to Eric's when I'm hungry and in the neighborhood.  I can trust that I'll receive quick and flawless service.  The food is not bad at all.  The fried rice is a little bland for my taste, but I really like all of the entrees I've tried and the soup was quite good too.
author: Amber R.

description:
Not much to say.
Worst and slowest service, make you wait standing while they have plenty of seating and wait staff and some of the most tasteless (and many times luke warm or cold even though overcooked) chinese food in the bay area.
Do yourself a favor and stay away from this yuppie and tourist trap.
author: Big H.

description:
Yes theY have cheap lunch and their soup and Genetal's chicken is good but
is it worth the stomach problems after ???
More than once me and my guests have gotten stomach
problems and lost all we ate - if you catch my drift - right after.
They do seem to cut corners and don't know what they put in the sauce
As always if it's too good to be true .... It's cheap for a reason
The staff specially the ladies are very sweet
Too bad
A good Chinese place in SF is R & G lounge on Kearny
Staff is typical clueless about service and human interaction Chinese
but if you're craving Chinese food then it's very good.
author: Dee B.

description:
I live in the area and have driven by Eric's neon sign, not realizing it was a chinese restaurant.

My roommates and I finally paid them a visit. One roomie has a tree nut allergy, so we had to avoid the Shanghai chicken (has nuts) and the walnut prawns - the waiter was nice about verifying that our other items didn't have nuts (and he made it through the meal safely).

We ordered...
- Hot and Sour Soup - Delicious. Both hot and sour. Really hit the spot on a cool night.
- Mu Shu Pork - The waiter wrapped these for us, which was kind of nice. But, they put way too much oyster sauce in there, which made the whole wrap overly salty. I had to drip a bunch of sauce out, which made it taste better. One roommate ended up unwrapping it and just eating the filling.
- Garlic Shrimp - Pretty good, it was in some kind of dark brown sauce that was quite salty. Lots of whole garlic cloves were included that were really tasty.
- Some Eggplant Stir Fry - Probably my least favorite dish, because it was the saltiest. It was also almost exactly the same as the garlic shrimp dish (same sauce), and also included shrimp, so we felt like we were eating pretty much the same thing again.
- String Bean w/ Fried Tofu - Liked this dish. Not overly salted, green beans were crispy.

Overall, no MSG, which is good. However, I got a stomachache later that night, which happens to me when I've eaten something too oily. Saltiness was also through the roof on most dishes.

Would consider going back the next time I crave hot and sour soup, but I'll try some different entrees next time and perhaps ask if they can reduce the amount of salt in the dishes.
author: Erin Y.

description: We are so lucky to live near Eric's! Our favorite Chinese food in the city, if not the universe... I always get the Moo Shu Shrimp, but also love the Basil Chicken, Fried Rice, Broccoli Cashew and Wonton Soup. The staff is very friendly and the food is very good quality.
author: Lindsay B.

description: I love it here! I live nearby and it is my favorite place to go when I want a large, warm meal! I could just get 3 orders of the potstickers and be super happy :)
author: Simona M.

description: The food is just Meh. Basil chicken is nice, but the lamb is really overcooked. Might go there if I am hungry and no place else is open.
author: Balu V.

description: The food is yummy so we keep coming back. They have a great selection on their lunch special
author: Nate W.

description:
Vegetarians rejoice! They now offer four meatless (mock) chicken dishes, located under the "Vegetable" section of the menu. From what I've been told by the staff, this was something they just put on the menu as of recent - it was a pleasant surprise to see.

So if you're over the plain tofu and vegetable thing, now there are more options.

I eagerly ordered the General Tsao Meatless Chicken and wasn't disappointed. Fresh, delicious broccoli surrounded a mound of mock chicken in a spicy sauce. The verdict? Mmmm mmmm good. Even my carnivore dining companion found it tasty. 

Big Lantern and Emmy's has a larger selection of mock meat dishes, but I don't think either restaurant can match the service and settings of Eric's (which hasn't changed much over the years - a good thing).
author: Sean G.

description: Food was terrible!! The three dishes we ordered seemed to have the same sauce . Used to be my favorite Chinese restaurant in Noe Valley. Will not come back at all.
author: Jenny B.

description:
Never have you let me down but that's partials to the fact that I've never sat my self down here. I gets the Chinese food to go and bring it to my lovely casa.
The chow mein is spot on and my favorite despite it's commonness. The price isn't bad and they get the food cooked quick for the pick (up).
Eric's don't ever change a thing!
author: Alexander R.

description:
Drums of Heaven (chicken wings) were a charred mess.

General Chicken tasted good but not presented well.
author: Inigo M.

description: I love it, I have to get carry out at least once a week, and eat-in  whenever I can.  Must have's are the Mongolian Beef, and the Chicken with basil leaf (spicy).  Highly recommend.
author: Kent W.

description: Such great food, atmosphere, and service! And on a Saturday night!! We ordered the Sesame Beef, spicy eggplant with chicken, wonton soup, combination chowmein, and finally, the  potstickers. Not in that order. Everything was fantastic!! Especially the sesame beef and eggplant. Yum! The potstickers are huge!! Great portion sizes. We have lots of leftovers and the bill was very reasonable.
author: Roya D.

description:
This is a local staple of mine. I like the big old windows and how it is located on Church st. It makes me feel like the city is not so big and scary. Every time I have been to Eric's the food is prepared well and the services is great. 

The menu is lean but never find myself really wanting more options. One of my favorites is the the sizzling soup. I must get take out from here once a month or so and have found it to be just as tasty. The place has an "almost too nice to be real" grouping of orchid plants/flowers. I have never had to wait for a table (this is a good thing) and the with this combination of things it stays on my monthly restaurants list!
author: Ryan B.

description:
people must like it as it gets full at lunch,about $7.50 plus tax,they do rush you to get in and out even when empty 
they grab stuff off the table while your still eating,the problem I have with it is most dishes are covered with soy sauce and I mean covered so you cant really taste anything just soy sauce and salt,its pretty clean ,they own alices around the corner which has the same menu
its an ok but I have had better food,but I would go back there
author: cc c.

description:
I came in wanting to LOVE Eric's because I have been such a fan of Eliza's for so many years. Sadly I was disappointed. Eric's has many of the same dishes (same family) and a great mid town location. The room is pretty spare,  but elegant at the same time- no large glass sculptures here. Service was efficient and friendly. The take out came very quickly. Maybe a little too quickly as it turns out...

Unfortunately I ordered the pork pot stickers and they were clearly re-heated. Worse than that, they might have been a old cause I felt ill 5 minutes after eating them & got a bit sick. Such a bummer! I also got the sesame seed chicken (not the deep friend kind) with diced carrots & yams. This version was very heavily sauced with almost no orange veggies, just an abundance of celery at the bottom. The chicken was fresh enough (no sickness after eating left overs the next day).

I wish I could say I would come here again, but probably won't.  Sad.
author: Suzanne D.

description: I came with my boyfriend and i was pleased by the fact that they sat us in the table right in front of the window. The vegetarian rolls weren't amazing and rather burned my tongue. The fried rice, chow mein, and general chicken were goooood. The service was quick and efficient. Will come back soon!
author: Jacky H.

description: Called to order a late night carry out before close. Food was ready when we arrived and the host was pretty nice. Mongolian beef looked burnt and unappetizing but the taste was the complete opposite and it was pretty good! Crab rangoons are usually what I try at every Chinese joint so I expected the typical origami style, light fluffy exterior with cream cheese and artificial crab meat. However to my surprise, the rangoon was surprising unique, almost like a chinese tamale, nice golden brown deep fried exterior with a smooth cream cheese and a good chunk of crab meat or artificial crab meat..couldn't tell but it was good! Also got Eric's chicken which was very good and full of flavor. Will be trying other things on the menu when in the San Francisco area.
author: Augustine P.

description: Returned here after many years and remembered it for amazing food. What a disappointment. Not sure if it changed owners or what. Our waiter was a complete dick and the food was awful. It all had a weird after taste like tainted pans or bad oil. Ick. No to go boxes, thanks.
author: David Z.

description: decent Chinese food for cheap but service wasn't great. I do love their lunch specials so I think I'll be returning if I want Chinese food before 3 pm.
author: Alyssa L.

description:
Good Chinese food at great prices.
I have not dined in but gotten take-out twice in the past week.
Their vegetable soup was good - veggies crisp, not soggy.
Beef with snap peas was delicious and garlicy, which I liked.
Also got chicken with broccoli and cashews. It was tasty and not greasy. (And again, garlicy!)
The food is done in 10 minutes or so, so no complaints on speediness. 
Recommend it for easy, quick and tasty Chinese food in the neighborhood.
author: Dora M.

description: Went to Eric's Restaurant for dinner. I went there with 2 of my friends and we were promptly seated. Got Eric's Chow Mein which is noodles with a mix of meat and veggies. The waiters are very helpful and friendly. Prices are pretty good and portions are good as well. Food was tasty and I was happy to learn that they didn't use MSG in any of their dishes. Overall, very happy with this restaurant.
author: Arvin A.

description:
GO!!!
YUM.

Had a late dinner here on 11/24/12. Second time here, and will be back any time I am in Noe Valley.

This time we ordered this:

Appetizer:  #6, the Combination Plate (totally enough for two people). Awesome egg rolls, crab meat rangoon (AMAZING),pot stickers (also AMAZING) and Drums of Heaven. The price is GREAT at $7.50.  Simply delicious.

Next course:  Hot and Sour Soup. Got the small---PLENTY for two. Perfect amount of heat and so tasty.  And the price:  $5.50. YES!!

And finally, as a main dish,  ERIC'S SPICY EGGPLANT.  Again, way more than enough for two people. I have never had eggplant cooked better than here. The sauce is incredible, the chicken, shrimp, and basil also VERY good. And some sort of pepper which could be hot to mild, but had perfect heat this time.  $9.75

SERVICE: very fast and efficient, and the staff are friendly.

Can be a little cramped and warm for seating, so best to wear a light shirt and not a sweater like I did. Noise level can be a little high on packed nights, but the food is SO  WORTH IT. GO GO GO GO GO!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Ed B.

description:
The lunch special is big pot of tea, soup of the day, your choice of entree with rice, orange slices, and a fortune cookie: All for $6! In Noe Valley!!
Good lawdy, that is cheaper than fast food, and nearly as fast.

I really like Eric's chow mein, which looks nothing like traditional chow mein.  There are so many vegetables in it, I thought that I got the wrong order when I opened my takeout boxes. But I really liked their spin on what is usually a dish of low nutritional value.

When I tip the server for togo food, she acts surprised, which makes me sad for her.  This leads me to believe that no one else tips her on the reg. Tip her, dammit!
author: Juliette F.

description: We ordered sweet and sour pork and lemon chicken and I liked both. They served us quickly and made sure to refill our drinks immediately :) they also packed out leftovers themselves and the check came out to be a good price (fyi, I am more/less a cheapskate). I'll definitely be back!
author: Christl A.

description: Eh.  Food is ok, but not great.  It's a nice neighborhood place that's easy to walk to.  Service is usually pretty good.
author: Allen A.

description: I went to Eric's based on the good reviews on yelp . I was sadly disappointed. the first visit I had wonton soup which was good but not great and the Mango Shrimp which was poor at best.The sauce was a dark brown and thick and very sweet with a bad taste to it. The second time I brought my wife for lunch and we had the wonton soup which was still good and Kungpau Shrimp which may be the worst I ever had. The vegetables were over cooked and soggy the sauce appeared to be the same sauce they used on the Mango Shrimp only with a tiny bit of spice added. Sweet and not hot makes a terrible Kungpau . I am still astonished at all the good reviews . Have these people never eaten good Chinese food. As I looked around I noticed only Caucasian customers many dousing their food with soy sauce and putting sugar in the tea. I will never return. So if you like overly cooked vegetables and nasty sweet sauces this is the place for you if not go almost any where else
author: Bill K.

description:
I went back for one last try the week after my first review and...

It doesn't get much worse than this. A 53% with possible food contamination??? Why would anyone go here, and especially bring their children. Wow this is really poor performance. 

http://www.cleanscores.com/170401/ERIC%27S+RESTAURANT


And to boot, after having a meal, while walking by the waiter, he didnt even say good bye or acknowledge us, he just ushered in the next couple into the table we left that wasn't even clean yet. Didn't smile, didn't say thank you, nothing. Pass on this place.
author: Adam X.

description: When we go out to o eat Chinese it's ALWAYS Eric's! I love the walnut prawns and Shanghai chicken. I've heard the avocado roll is great too. Their hot and sour soup is great too. I highly recommend it!
author: Michael S.

description:
Eric's is my favorite Chinese spot in Noe Valley. I've been here several times since moving to the neighborhood in February, and I have not had a single disappointing meal. My favorite items so far: 
Crab rangoon
Wonton soup
Mango beef
Fried Rice
The service is prompt and courteous, and the prices are quite reasonable given the generous portions of food.
author: Ashley T.

description:
There was a time when I really enjoyed Eric's updated take on standard Chinese fare.  Either my taste has changed, or they've fallen a fair ways.  There seems to be a focus on turning tables to the point where it feels like you're just quickly grabbing food at a Panda Express in a mall.  Worse still is that just like the Panda Express, every dish at Eric's seems to be a variation on a handful of different sauces.  We recently ordered "Eric's Tiger Prawns" and Broccoli with Jade Tofu and were surprised to discover near identical corn-starch thickened, light brown garlicky sauces.  Hey, no problem, but it would have been nice if the menu (or the waiter for that matter) had clued us in.  Both dishes were passable, but ultimately bland, bland, bland.  They had a little chile marker on the menu next to the shrimp dish, but I didn't taste any heat.

I think the key at Eric's is to accept that they excel at those very same dishes you might order at a Panda Express.  Yep, anything fried and anything in a super-sweet sauce is going to be good.  Check your health at the door, as well as any visions you might have had of eating anything terribly unique.
author: Laurence W.

description: went recently for lunch and enjoyed it very much. Mango beef was excellent. Atmosphere was nice and the place and restrooms were clean.
author: Asher B.

description: I love Eric's!!!  Not only do they have great Chinese food, but their prices look great on the bill as well!! I've been coming here for a couple of years now for lunch and I doubt I'll be stopping anytime soon...I work in the industrial part of the city and they have lots of other Chinese food restaurants but I can say with confidence that no other place around the area tops Eric's. Sweet & Sour Chicken and Garlic Chicken are at the front of the line!!
author: Cesar N.

description: We had two friends in town who wanted Chinese food, so we decided on Eric's.  Absolutely everything we were looking for - tasty Chinese food, attentive service, and spotlessly clean. Eric's never disappoints in my book.
author: Eric U.

description: Sad. Eric's has changed. And not for the better. I've lived in the hood for 25 yrs. Eric's has been some sort of institution. But last night's dinner was disappointing. While the Chef's Special (eggplant, shrimp, chicken) was good and has always been. everything else lacked flavor, or was greasy or both. Won't be straying from our go-to Henry's Hunan again. Sigh.
author: vicki s.

description: I'm known for hating Chinese food, and I went with friends who have been going there for years, and it was awesome. I enjoyed everything and left happy. Granted, the wait was a bit long, because the small amount of tables available.
author: Leilani W.

description:
Crab Rangoon, ok, a bit heavy on the cream cheese, not so much "crab"
Buddha Delight's, Tasty and had a bit of a kick.
Mu Shu Vegetable. This was actually good... except their pancakes reminded me of flour tortillas. The pancakes are supposed to be thin, similar to that served with Peking Duck.
With so many other options in San Francisco, you can find something better.
author: Geordie E.

description: My wife praised this place so I was looking forward to some good Chinese food.  Unfortunately I was disappointed!  The food was mediocre and pricey.  I'm not a hater, just disappointed.
author: JFK B.

description: Hunan fish, Walnut Prawns and everything else on the menu. The lunch specials can't be beat. Highly recommend this place to anyone looking for a small, low key, amazing Chinese food restaurant in SF. The prices are perfect and the food is always fresh and delicious. The service is fantastic and if you haven't been here, GO! I have probably been here around 30 times.
author: Jeremy F.

description:
I've been going to this Chinese restaurant long enough to finally review it.

This has been my go-to Chinese place for many years, for good reason. It has great quality food, it's really inexpensive, it's clean and it's fast. 

This is not a hole in the wall. It's the kind of place where you can take out-of-town guests and they'll think you have exposed them to a special piece of San Francisco.

Parking can be tough in this neighborhood, so allow extra time if you're meeting up with friends at a specific time.
author: Lynn F.

description: I have been extremely disappointed with every Chinese restaurant I've tried since moving to San Francisco. Finally, I have found a place with tasty food, great attentive service, and reasonable in price. I had the prawns with broccoli and cashew. Usually you get very little protein in this dish and have to ask for extra shrimp. However, they are very generous with the number of shrimp, and the sauce was about as delicious as it gets. I really enjoyed the appetizers as well. Definitely a spot I will try again.
author: Bradley V.

description:
I haven't had Chinese food in quite a while and was really looking forward to stopping by at Eric's. We walked in and grabbed a quick seat. 

We decided to order soup, rice, and a couple of dishes between the two of us, which was definitely just right. 

While everything was pretty good, nothing was stellar. Well, except for the soup. 

I'll have to be back to try a few more things out!
author: Art A.

description: It's all about the ingredients. Everything is so fresh, simple and seasoned just right. I recommend the walnut prawns and have the waiter bring over the chili sauce.
author: Joe N.

description: Killer service to go with their awesome food. Walnut prawns and avocado rolls are the must haves, go ahead and try anything else, it's all equally good. I love this place even tho it's 20 minutes away from home
author: Andrew J.

description:
good food!,  good service!, clean! what more can you ask for....
Usually this place is packed with people waiting outside to get in, we drove by and saw that it was half full!. we lucked out on some parking nearby(if there is a minus to Eric's restaurant, its the parking !) we ordered a veggie soup that hit the spot in this cold weather we are having.the hunan fish was flaky and spicy ,but i liked the basil eggplant the best...tender and creamy. As we were eating we noticed that the house was full of people...I guess it was are lucky day.
author: francisco a.

description:
We ate at Rick's this weekend.  The General Tso's chicken and Combination plate for appetizers (egg roll, crab meat Rangoon, pot stickers, drums of heaven) were really good, BUT we ordered also Eric's fried rice which was terrible (no taste at all) , Mango beef which was just so-so.  We also ordered String beans with curd and that had almost no flavor either...  with so many Chinese restaurants to choose from in SF and elsewhere that are fantastic, probably would never go to Eric's again.  But it was good to try something new, as that is always entertaining.

Eric's did make a couple of really good dishes as reviewers had said before, the General Tso's chicken and appetizers were great.  The service was excellent we thought, very attentive.  The place looks very clean and the restroom was very clean too which we appreciate.
author: Linda G.

description:
I've been coming to Eric's for over 15 years and I am finally done with them. They've changed owners (or at least the complete staff) at least 3 times in the last 5 years and their recipes have devolved from the somewhat-saucy but still good Californian Chinese to typical San Francisco fare. It used to be the highlight of my evening back in the 90s to come here before a night out on the town, but now it's just a joke to me. Wah.

They charge $2-3 too much for dishes that contain bad cuts of beef and too much zucchini, and this goes for the lunch specials too. Just today I got a lunch special that came with no rice. From a Chinese restaurant. They didn't even apologize.
author: Erm N.

description: Just got take out from this place.  The soup is mostly broth, not a happy camper esp. since today is the Lunar New Year (snake) and I was soo looking forward to the experience.  don't skimp on the solid components of soup Eric's...lame.
author: C L.

description: Pretty yummy chinese food and a great assortment on the menu.  They have been in business for a long time so you know it is good.  They staff is great.
author: Nicole B.

description:
Great place for lunch...  How can you beat under $7 for an entree + rice + soup?  Tasty, well presented, nicely cooked, clean.

Remarkable resemblance to Alice's, although I'd rate my meal here a little better.
author: Roni L.

description:
This place has the most amazing food.
We took a train and a bus to get to this place while
on vacation, more than once.  We will be going 
back on our next trip, and every trip after that.
author: Robyn A.

description: Mmm goooood!  Started coming here a long long time ago when our family was still living in noe valley (over 8 years ago)! Love their sesame chicken, walnut prawns and their eggplant!! My dad loves this place too :). Their lunch specials are superb!
author: Colette P.

description:
Came here for lunch.

Pros:  Rice had a nice consistency.
            The servers usually have a smile, even when ignoring you.
             Water glass is kept full. This can also be annoying.

Cons:  Kung Pao Chicken actually bland, which is quite a feat.
              Sweet n Sour Pork also tasteless.  Even cookies seemed stale.

               It is not a good feeling to watch people who have been seated after you get their order taken while you are still waiting.  Long wait for check also.

         Disappointed and won't be back.
author: Susan V.

description:
I love Erics. I've been coming here even before I lived in the city. 

My favorites:
*potstickers
*green beans
*tofu eggplan
*prawn dishes 

Local Noe restaurant and very kid friendly (high chairs)

Cheap lunch specials.
author: Katherine B.

description: I like to go here occasionally. Lunch specials are fairly priced, and that's when it's busiest. Portions are satisfactory, and staff is usually nice. Not amazing, but not horrible; more on the better side though.
author: John A.

description:
Two words for Eric's " cheap and good"!!

My friend and I wandered around the town to find an interesting restaurant to try and we tumble on Eric's and My friend recalled that every time that he drove by this restaurant, it always packed for both day time and in the evening. So we went in and tried this place.

   When i walked in, I surprise how this restaurant didn't look like Chines restaurant at all. The whole decoration is quite neat. But the biggest surprise for me was to see the price on the lunch menu so low. 

   "This is not real" I told myself when I saw the lunch menu. Considering all the decorations, the dress code for the waiters and the look of the food on other tables. I was really to pay at least $15.00 per plate.

  Well... we ordered. "Hunan Fish" and " Egg plants" for lunch special which also comes with a very testy soup. and Once we tried the food. It became clear to me.... why this place is so popular. The food is quite good. 

  O.K.... May be this is not the best Chines food that i ever had but considering the price, the service and the food itself. It's quite a great deal. 

 I ended up buying more lunch special - TO GO, to bring home with me and yes, I will come back to Eric's again and again. Even it's pretty far from my place.
author: Dom G.

description:
My comments are directly related to take-out.

One of the worst Chinese meals I've had.  How the mighty have fallen.  Eric's used to be the go-to place about ten years ago, and has just gotten worse and worse over time.  If you like industrial Chinese food filled with gooey sauces and shocking amounts of fryer grease, then you'll love this place.

For the rest of us, it's a factory for sheer crap.  Their once-great Emperor's Prawns are a sticky mess, indistinguishable from the sort of delivery food you think about when you think about dorm-delivery food.

I don't think I've ever had greasier egg rolls, so greasy that they dripped grease when I pulled them out of their greasy little travel sacks.  Is that supposed to make me crave more of them in the future?

Everything was utterly disgusting.
author: Andrew L.

description: Eric's is one of the best chinese in the city. offers brown rice and gluten free options. eric's spicy chicken, avocado rolls, gen tso's - all delicious.  tonite, its Eric's.
author: T B.

description:
Its a pretty good place. I have to say some of the dishes are like Chinese Mexican fusion. i.e. Avocado spring rolls (which are good by the way, but similar to guacamole in a fried egg roll wrapper) and tortillas with their mu shu dishes is totally odd.  The chow mein is different than anywhere else.  Its very saucy.
I am not a fan of the service. but the Shanghai chicken and sesame beef are tasty.
Yes, sometimes I am in the mood for it but it isn't all that authentic. 
I will continue to go, but not with any high expectations. Just sayin'
author: Suzanne L.

description: We go to Eric's often and have always found the food to be excellent.  We eat in and do takeout.  It is nice to eat at the restaurant and get the food as soon as it is cooked.  We have found all the ingredients to be fresh.  We have recommended Eric's to a number of friends and family.  Everyone has enjoyed their meals.
author: Susan G.

description: WHAT has happened to Eric's.  For dinner, we had prawn salad to start. The lettuce was soggy as though it had been made at lunch time.  It was AWFUL.  That was followed by broccolis in garlic sauce.  The broccoli seemed as though it was cooked the day before and then reheated in the garlic sauce.  Menu said it was spicy, but it did not have a whisper of spiciness.  New manager? New chef?  Whatever -- it is awful.  We live in the neighborhood and having been going there for many years.  Something has happened.
author: ditty D.

description: A laid-back/peaceful Chinese restaurant with OK food.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Had dinner at Eric's Restaurant this past Friday early evening. The server and waiter were very polite, friendly and attentive and the food tasted fresh.  The service is also pretty quick!

Our party of three (3) were seated right away. We were offered water and our glasses were always checked on throughout our time there. Right away we were also brought a small pot of tea, which was a nice touch!

I ordered the Mongolian Beef which was just a tad sweet and spicy.  It was not that spicy for me (however I have a high tolerance for spice) but the flavor was good. The sauce almost had a mild hint of a barbecue sauce taste in it.

I also tried Eric's Fried Rice which was a combo of chicken, pork and beef with fried egg and scallions.  The fried rice was fresh and delicious!

That was my first time at the restaurant. I would definitely recommend it to others to try and would return to try a different dish.

What stood out the most to me about this place was the genuinely friendly and polite employees along with the fresh taste of the food.
author: Miz M.

description: This used to be a favorite spot with my bestie back in the day. Last night was the first time we had been there in years (like 10ish?). The egg rolls were so good. Crunchy and perfect. Drum of heaven still heavenly. Hunan fish, not so much and the eggplant even less so. The service was excellent but waking up with food poisoning at 2am was probably my least favorite part of the Eric's experience....
author: Lita P.

description:
My girlfriend said she thought Eric's was related to the late Eliza's....
We had the Walnut Prawns and Asparagus Beef, and neither had that 
wonderful Chinese flavor that Eliza's had.....really tasteless and boring food.....Now I'm sitting here with the doggie-bag, and I'll add a little oyster sauce to the beef and  see if I can bring this prawn up to Eliza's standards........
author: Bill R.

description: I've been eating at Eric's for years and years and it never disappoints! I love Chinese food, always have, but in comparison to Eric's every other Chinese restaurant is a disappointment--and no, I'm not exaggerating. I love the ambiance--the orchids are beautiful. They use the freshest ingredients, which makes everything taste amazing. Their spicy eggplant is off the chain! Snow peas and mushrooms.... yes! The mango shrimp makes regular appearances in my dreams. It is incredibly reasonable, especially their lunch specials. Love the brown rice option. Dude, I want to be eating at Eric's right now.
author: A E.

description:
I happened upon this place this afternoon since a good friend of mine just moved into the neighborhood.

And boy, was I surprised! I mean I live pretty close to Eliza's (ummm..is there a relation? And what is with Andy's? What is it with the first names?? How.... unauthentic they sound hahahaha) and it's ok. Not the best and the service can be kind of crazy there. But, I found Eric's to be quite a peach!

I ordered the Chicken Kew and it was loaded with veggies cooked to perfection. Not too soft, and just crisp enough to snap when I bit into it.

I shared with said friend an appetizer sampler and found everthing in it to be fantastic too! The "drums of heaven" (chicken drumsticks covered and fried in a spicy sauce of some sort) super yummy and their eggrolls had tofu AND mushrooms!! I mean hello? I got used to the banal cabbage and a few shreds of carrot variety.

So all in all, for a great dinder of 2 entrees, a large appetizer plate, enough brown rice to feed a family and good tea and service, I give Eric's  4 stars for their  overall performance. An extra star for not making me feel ill after I stuffed my face. Are your ingredients fresher? Do you not use scary chemicals in your food??For the first time, I left feeling pretty darn fabulous after my Chinese meal.
author: Kathy K.

description: I had a birthday there with 14 people and the service was probably the worst of any I've had. My 80 year old father was practically insulted by waiter who then made myself, my son, Dad and Mom be the last ones served AFTER the rest of table had finished their food. I'll NEVER EVER come to or recommend Eric's again. And I've lived in SF for 23 years and eaten here many times. Not again.
author: Dave M.

description:
Dear god...the greasiest egg rolls I have ever had. I was asked to touch the bottom of the bag it came it and I had to wash my hands under hot water with soap when my hand surfaced. I'm not sure how this place made vegetables so unhealthy but I'm a fan. 

I ordered the clams and they were good except for the fact that I found pockets of sand or grit in them which made one of them crunchy. Ick. The sesame chicken was so good and I kept going back to the kitchen for more. Actually it was a whole day of gluttony and it was amazing.
author: Ashley I.

description:
FINALLY. Chinese in SF (outside of Chinatown) that I actually like. 

I moved here from the East Coast, and for whatever reason, your typical Chinese food here is different, and not in a good way. To me, at least. 

I'm sure trendy a-holes will lampoon me for liking "Americanized" Chinese food. Maybe that's true, but for once, I really liked the food. Everything my boyfriend and I ordered was great, and the service was good, too.

Give Eric's a try!
author: Cee D.

description: Excellent food in a clean, simple space. We went as a group of 4 and ordered several appetizers and 5 entrees to share. The portions were great and we ended up with leftovers to take home. The prices were very reasonable....3 appetizers and 5 entrees came in under $80.  The pot stickers and prawns with walnuts stood out as excellent dishes.  The service was extremely friendly and the only downside was the pace at which the food came out....much too fast and before long plates were piling up and there was no room left on the table.
author: Jason M.

description: I thought it was really really yummy - we had sizzling beef and scallops, chow mein, and wonton soup. Portions were generous. Sauces were so good - thick, brown, salty/sweet. I was looking at others' orders and drooling, which is always a sign of my kind of restaurant. Total bill was $28. Fun atmosphere - packed - big neon sign outside. Felt neighborhoody. The sauces were flavorful and the meats were good. My parents (Chinese food enthusiasts) were thoroughly satisfied. They love Red Jade until the day we switched to Eric's. Also UBERnice waitress.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Great lunch spot in Noe -- light and airie atmosphere with beautiful orchids everywhere to make it cheery.

The lunch special is a great deal - came with a tasty corn egg soup.  We also ordered the deep fried avocado rolls - yum.  Our dishes were also tasty - not too greasy or salty which sometimes can be the case with Chinese food.  Also, lilke the fact they serve brown rice.

Definitely a great lunch spot.
author: Gina C.

description:
I don't want to knock this place but for obvious reasons, this place offers "safe" chinese food for, perhaps, the lighter demographic of the Noe area. While nothing was off putting, flavors of this Chinese restaurant were one dimensional... which itself is very hard to say for Chinese food. 80% of the menu was a battered and fried something in a soy "gravy". I know I won't be coming back but for some reason, I know this restaurant will persevere because there's no way in hell a Chinatown/Sunset restaurant would get the same ratings as this one has in the same 'hood.

The staff was very friendly though and really, it's a good spot for a fairly relaxed Sunday dinner out (minus not so great food).
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description: Our first visit to Eric's: Wow. Wonderful take on Chinese. Just traditional enough, but way fresher and cleaner than any Chinese mishmash I ever had to decipher! Everything we ordered was top shelf. It's just great to discover new places in an old "hometown." Lovely room. Nice location. Friendly and welcoming staff. Just a real suprising treat for all of us for a first visit, not knowing what to expect..
author: Chip J.

description:
wow... eric's has stepped it up a notch!!

our recent visit was so much better than years ago.

sizzling rice soup- simply, yet nourishing

orange chicken- not sweet at all. crunchy & crave worthy in texture

hunan fish- not bad. slightly thick and glossy, yet perfectly cooked

erics eggplant- wonderfully rich and not overly oily (like others)

combination rice- decent

a basic prawns with broc & carrots for all the kids- huge hit!

tall water glasses served to children- not quite the right idea. kids loved drinking water out of low tea cups. 

children plastic plates served at meal, added the unexpected to all the kids. they loved a little familiarity in a restaurant. mega kudos to understanding how to please a child, and make dining easy for stressed parents!

would go back :)
author: SF U.

description:
After moving away from Noe Valley with my girlfriend, we got a hankering for some Eric's one night. We picked up our food, came home, and then opened it up to find that instead of our lemon chicken, we got some sort of fried bean thing. This isn't a problem I thought, I'll just call them up.

The girl was very nice on the phone, and said to come on down and we will give you your lemon chicken. So we got in the car and swung back into Noe Valley to get our tasty erics. But what happens next is a bit of a shock to me.

When we got there, I talked to the girl, she went into the back to talk to the main chef/owner (obvious person in charge). The girl comes back to me and says, "Did you bring the bean dish with you?"

"Uhhh, no," I said. I was pretty confused at this point. "Why would I want to bring back the food, it could be contaminated at this point." 

I looked back at the head chef/owner and we made eye contact, he then put his hands up basically making it clear that "I don't get free chicken." I then put my hands up in the air mimicking him asking aloud in the restaurant why I should be bringing back "contaminated" food.

Then it dawns on me.... there are 2 POSSIBLE ASSUMPTIONS FOR THIS SITUATION:

1) I am a liar and/or thief trying to get some free lemon chicken out of the deal (I can assure you the 15 min ride, and double parking on church isn't worth trying to rip them off of a 8 dollar dish)

2) They were planning on putting the bean dish back into "the pot" assuming I didn't touch it.

Both of these are pretty gross and or insulting. Having worked in the food industry as a waiter when I was younger, we NEVER EVER EVER took back food. If someone came back saying the order was wrong, you just give them another order. There are to many complications with contamination to even bother. And customer's shouldn't need to present "proof." And if they do, then you throw it away. Given the shiesty-ness of this situation, I can only wonder if it was every going to get thrown away. Long story short, I left bitterly. 

Well it's been a good run Eric's. Faithfull customer for years, but I am done with you. I've been hearing some sketchy stories lately, and my personal one just really takes the cake. Alice's is 4 blocks away, and is virtually the same food....
author: Tim O.

description:
favorite dishes: kung pao chicken or kung pao prawns, Eric's chow mein, spicy eggplant and Eric's tiger prawns. Small place which gets crazy busy during peak hours, but truly some of the best Chinese in San Fran. Great lunch specials ranging from $5.50-$7.00 and always great to take home and enjoy with friends or family. Parking is tough so get there early if at all possible.
Enjoy!
author: Hector G.

description: Consistently great food.  Super fast to-go orders and friendly service.    This is not your father's Chinese food!   YES, it's not healthy, but anyone who things American-Chineese food is supposed to be healthy has another clogged artery coming to them!
author: Michael M.

description:
"Eat your fruits and vegetables to strengthen your health."

Okay, who gave my mom a job at the fortune cookie factory?

Just realized that most Chinese restaurants I go to nowadays don't give fortune cookies.

I used to go to Eric's all the time for years. Then, around 2007 or so the food went downhill and I stopped going. Lately, I noticed the reviews have improved on Yelp, so I decided to give it a try. As one other reviewer put it, they have their game back.

For best results, do try to stick with the chef's specials or the vegetarian versions thereof, which are quite tasty. The standard American Chinese dishes are just so-so. If you order sweet-and-sour anything you deserve what you get.

But you will get fresh, al-dente veggies, plenty of vegetarian choices, a brown rice option, and quick service.

Service, ah, that can still be random. One night a friend and I went in and we were totally ignored except to be told to get out of the way, so we left. But other nights I've been greeted like the long-lost regular that I am.

Don't expect Hong Kong style, but, again with the chef's specials, don't expect tourist food either. It's more like California Chinese.

Can be really loud when full, so if you hate that like I do try to eat there off-peak.
author: Charles B.

description:
Hungover? Bad day at work? "Woozy" from an afternoon in Dolores Park? Jewish male?....
If you answered yes to any of these questions then you are in dire need to good old fashioned American Chinese food. No better place for the craving then Eric's. So good. So cost effective. So coma inducing. Perfect.If they only delivered!
author: Josh B.

description:
I really liked Eric's, because it's named after me! Just kidding.

When comparing to other restaurants in the area like Henry's Hunan, I enjoyed Eric's more. The portions are ample and you'll have enough to take home.

They mentioned spicy, but I would not recommend Medium, it's not spicy at all in my opinion.
author: Eric A.

description:
if i was a white 35+ year old person with a wife and kid, and maybe one token chinese friend i'd rate this place 4 stars.

but i'm neither of those things, and i wanted more from this chinese place in almost all aspects.
author: Ameer N.

description:
I just ate here. It was fine for a late Sunday lunch.  I had the Combo Platter to start;  the chicken was burnt, spring roll was made of 90% cabbage, and the shrimp chips were stale.  The mains:  Rainbow Fish and Beef & Scalops were OK.  This is definitly American style Chinese food.
Service was excellent, except they failed to bring the change.
author: Spencer F.

description:
Maybe I like Eric's because it's across the street from my apartment. But so is Amberjack Sushi, and I have only eaten there once because it was so terrible. 

Things I like:
1. $6-7 lunch specials. I'm not home for lunch most days but when I am, I'm pretty excited.
2. Fried rice "less oil, low salt please". 
3. Hunan fish "extra crispy please". Some days it is spicier than others (I am not a spicy person).
4. Take-out orders are usually ready within 10 minutes.
5. Did I mention the location?
6. SOUP!!!
7. Prices are really good for this 'hood.

Things I'm not as crazy about:
1. Service is hit and miss. Last time I dined in, they took so long to collect the bill that I ended up having to make the bf pay for it, cause I had waited 15 minutes and needed to GET TO WORK. Time before that, the service was very attentive. Hmm.
2. As previously mentioned on yelp, some of the sauces are all the same. Which kind of sucks. But if you pick out and order the gems,  the food is pretty good.

I don't care that it's not "authentic", that's the kind of chinese food I was raised on (having a mother that is allergic to most spices, corn, tomatoes, beans and a million other things...I am used to bland food). I don't want to eat this every day, but when I am feeling particularly lazy I'd much rather eat here than the aforementioned neighbor.
author: Katies F.

description:
My favorite lunch place and I LIVE A BLOCK WAY whoo hoo
The lunch special 11-3 monday through saturday is a deal not to be missed. soup, entree, tea, water with lemon slice in it (love that touch) orange slices and fortune cookie. DIRT CHEAP. 
My favorite dish is Hunan Fish. I have tried many other things and all of them have been excellent. 
I have brought friends here that keep coming back.
A definite!!
author: Eugenia P.

description: 2 stars only because the service has been decent for me and restaurant appears to serve a neighborhood need. Cook knows what he's doing, which is cooking for non-Chinese people with dead tastebuds. Food uniformly salty as seawater and sugary as Apple Jacks, due to the heavy use of corn syrup. Eric's is 1 star for me, but they've survived this long in the neighborhood, so somebody likes them. And that college teacher who gave a 1 star rating because the waiter pointed out that there's an $8 minimum per table? That was seriously unfair because you are penalizing them for enforcing a published policy. You should have gotten take-out. It's not as if they changed the rules on ya. Restaurant's got to make money, and can't have ppl like you acculturated to taking up valuable table space for one hot and sour soup for your  kid. It's not worth the waiter or restaurant's clean up and table set up cost for a $6 charge. Restaurant owners consider "good riddance" to customers like you (and critics like me).
author: Ichor B.

description: Busy place, pleasant interior but the food was just overly drenched in gooey sauce. Eggplant was greasy; I have definitely had better. Maybe the meat dishes are good but I don't eat that stuff. Did not feel like it was the healthiest meal I've ever had and I am still tasting garlic 24hrs later....
author: Mar D.

description:
!:-)

You like chinese food thats not swimming in grease? How about fresh, tasty, and vibrant looking vegetables with just the right amount of "al dente?"

If you said yes to the above, you'll love Eric's.. Yeah.. I know, its not even a Chinese name. Go figure. My favorite chinese restaurant is called ERICS! lol.  

Erics is a little place tucked away on beautiful Church Street in Noe Valley. I like it because its unassuming but nice enough to have small group parties and impromptu lunches (It's like shopping at a little neighborhood boutique rather than a department store)

http://erics.ypguides.net/

A mixture of Hunan and Mandarin Chinese Cuisine, the food here is "clean"-- never overly cooked, never overly sauced, never greasy. I love eating chinese food where I'm not OVERWHELMED and ASSAULTED by the sauces, spices or oils. At Eric's I'm pleasantly surprised by the taste of the meats, or the vegetables, "accented" by the spices and sauces. That's how cooking should be!

I'm always suspicious of places that overly sauce. What are they hiding? And why can't I taste anything else BUT the sauce? YIKES!

My favorite dishes at Eric's is the Sesame Chicken, the Walnut Prawns, the Garlic Eggplant, the Hunan Fish and House Fried Rice. Each are presented tastefully on white plates. And if your vegetarian, do not dismay, they have alot of dishes for you as well.

I can't find anything wrong with this place, and wished more places EDITED when cooking. It's not a fancy place, although you'll find people dressed business casual, to just casual. But it's also not a dive. Tables are draped in white cloth with votive candles, for that bistro feel... The large picturesque windows give you a view of one of my favorite neighborhoods in San Francisco. And if you've ever entered this place from a wintery rainy evening; it sets a beautiful mood as your enjoying your hot & sour soup, while looking out at the wet and rainy streets.

Eric's is just a great place to have a nice "fresh and clean" tasting meal. I'd recommend Erics' to everyone. Because there aren't many tables, you won't be at a loss for table service either.
