I was pretty depressed afterward, the heavy weight of both dishes in my stomach, and imagine no rice either!

That might have just been our last order...
author: Mariangela S.

description:
Best (American-ized) Chinese food I've had in San Francisco.  Mango Shrimp and General's Chicken are fantastic.  Come early or expect to wait.  

Overall, great food and fast service (though not particularily friendly).
author: Shawn S.

description: Best Chinese food that I've had in San Francisco, by far. The General Tso's was incredible, and the closest to how it's made in New York which is what my taste in Chinese food is based on. The sauce was just spicy enough, the chicken just crispy enough. The beef with broccoli was also really good. It's a simple dish, but I'm surprised at how it's not that great at some places. The beef was cooked well and the broccoli was steamed the proper amount. Not cooked enough or overcooked broccoli is so bad and can ruin an otherwise good beef with broccoli dish. Eric's had it all right, thankfully. I'll definitely be eating here again. If you've been searching for a good Chinese spot but could just never find one quite right (or even edible, which sadly is what most SF Chinese food is, not edible), your search is over!
author: Chris C.

description:
My favorite Chinese restaurant in the city!

Yes, it is "California-ized", but that doesn't mean it isn't delicious. It is the best place to go on a sunny Sunday afternoon on my way home to San Jose. I always order twice as much as I can eat so that I'll have leftovers.

My favorite dish: Shanghai Tofu. It is even better than the chicken version. They fry tiny pieces of tofu, and then toss it with pine nuts, some crispy green stuff that no one can figure out what it is, and a delicous sauce.
author: Lauren H.

description:
I like Eric's.  It's good food, served quick and pretty reasonably priced.  I love the quaint neighborhood and am a big fan of supporting neighborhood restaurants.

Please try the Avocado Rolls & the Eric's Cakes.  They are appetizers and are simply to die for!!!  Ooooh they are so yummy that I'm getting a craving for them now.  The hunan fish (fried cod) & the mushu w/pork are my favorites.  I usually request them spicy.

There is just something so homey about this restaurant.  I think that is one of the reasons I keep coming back.  That....and the Avocado rolls.  Yum!
author: lea m.

description:
I really like this place! I forgot what I ordered because I cam here over a month ago and I just am yelping about it tonight when I cleaned out my wallet and saw the receipt from here, but I know I thoroughly enjoyed every bite :) It's a Contemporary Asian dining aka whitewashed, haha, but it was divine! :) In fact, i was just in SF all day and wished I ended my evening here at Eric's. I'd definitely come back :)

PS, the restaurtant is clean! :D
author: Jojo N.

description: Sure, San Francisco has plenty of good Chinese restaurants.  But San Francisco also has plenty of lousy ones, too.  This is a good one.  I've been eating here since 2002, and Eric's food is reliably fresh and delicious.  The waiters are fast & efficient, and the ambiance is pleasant.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Dinner a couple of nights ago.  Excellent.

We went a bit on the late side, in the middle of the week.  Service was quick and efficient.  Got seated right away, up front by the window.  Tea came right out with out having to ask.

Hot and sour soup was exactly as I like it.  Spouse had wonton soup and it was also excellent.  She had noodles and I had mongol beef.  

(I lived in the south bay 17 years ago and ever since, I've been trying to find a place with hot and sour soup, and mongolian beef like I used to get in a little place in Mt. View on Castro Street - which is my gold standard for Chinese food).  

Bottom line - You want solid Chinese - this is your place.  Portions were large and tasty.  Service was prompt and friendly.  Prices were very reasonable.  I would certainly go back again.  Give it a try if you are in the area.
author: Andrea v.

description: There is nothing like the Mongolian Beef here, consistent and good. Always fast, friendly service, and very clean. Sizzling rice soup is great and the chow mien stands out.
author: Dee D.

description:
my favorite americanized, cheap chinese. amazing vegetarian options. i'm a huge fan of the meatless general tsao's chicken. sooo good. i'm glad they don't deliver...i'd go nuts!

my boyfriend likes the mango chicken and the sizzling rice soup.
author: arielle r.

description:
Eric's is middle of the road.  Their lunch specials are usually the only reason to go, cheap and filling.

In response to the "margot b." review... they did get a scary score of 59 but all issues were abated.  I have to admit that bad score makes it hard to want to eat there when there's so many other places for good food in SF.
author: Shawn H.

description: I had a great experience eating here. Went for the lunch special (ends at 3pm) which was the soup of the day, a pot of tea, and an entree, all for about $7! I chose the Kung Pao chicken, it was absolutely delicious! Great portions and very flavorful. The soup of the day was also delicious, it was a sort of vegetable medley. Very prompt and friendly service. Definitely recommend going here the next time you're craving Chinese food in Noe Valley.
author: Jena W.

description:
I went to Eric's with my roommate, who said that the restaurant had come to him very highly recommended as the best Chinese food in the city. My roommate, Chinese himself, was excited to try it, but upon walking into the restaurant immediately became skeptical that we were about to eat some very American Chinese food. I could see what he meant, but being that I am not generally a huge fan of Chinese food [American-ified or not], I was unfazed.

As it turned out, we both thoroughly enjoyed the meal, and my roommate admitted that neither the clams with black bean sauce nor the spicy eggplant was really inauthentic at all. We also had the sizzling rice soup, which was very good. Also a plus was that the food was considerably less greasy than most Chinese food I've had before. We both decided that we intend to go back.
author: Jon W.

description: i literally have cravings for the shanghai chicken every other week or so and salivate until i go grab it to go (i live in the neighborhood)! it makes me very happy :) i would also recommend the walnut prawns (so good!) and the hunan fish which is just the right amount of crispy to be scrumptious.
author: jordanne o.

description:
I'm a bit flummoxed that this place received poor marks from anyone.  I used to come here back in the day and today was the first time eating here since my triumphant return to SF.  Still the same killer Chinese food and attentive service.

This lunch we got some nicely crisped up pot stickers to start , a fresh tasting wonton soup, the always sinfully delicious General's chicken, and a huge chicken lo mein.  I'm not claiming the food is authentic but I am saying that Eric's consistently has some of the best Americanized Chinese I've eaten.  Unlike the real deal cuisine that I've had in Chinatown and other local immigrant haunts you're never in doubt of what type of meat you're eating.  I will say that identifying what part of the animal is much more challenging.  Still, the veggies are always crisp and fresh - a welcome change from the sauced out mush usually associated with less reputable joints.  

I agree with other patrons that when the dining room is full the wait staff is quite brisk.  It's a small place and they're trying to turn over their tables.  All I can say is sack up and take control of your own destiny.  If you're not finished with something don't let them take it.  If you want to hold your table and chat after your meal nobody will force you to go.
author: Adam A.

description:
I live right next to Eric's and I have to say, I love them. They're quick, cheap, and super tasty. It's not a restaurant to travel across town for, but if you're in the neighborhood and looking for fast and easy options, it's  a great bet. I've had both takeout and eat-in from them. Both types of experiences are great.

Recommended dishes: Hot and Sour Soup; Hunan Fish; Spicy Smoked Pork; and Eric's Spicy Eggplant.
author: Mag F.

description: Has something happened to Erics?  New chef?  New owner?  We live nearby and always order the same thing for takeout...Eric's Chow Mein and the Spicy Eggplant with basil.  We love those dishes but last night both dishes were almost inedible!  The Chow Mein was tasteless, the beef in it was tough and chewy, and there were hardly any noodles. The eggplant was awful,  tasteless and almost undercooked and instead of the fine slices of veggies there were HUGE pieces of hot peppers in the dish and a tasteless sauce.  We were so disappointed.  We're going elsewhere next time.  We may try Eric's again,  they've been great in the past, and maybe this was just a bad, bad night, but once burned....we need time to recover!
author: Sandra S.

description: this use to be one of my go to places, but things have gone down hill.  my parents like this place and ask me to order from it whenever they visit, which happened last night.  ordered the garlic scallops and shrimp with garlic sauce.  each entree literally had like 6-7 small pieces of seafood, then a mountain of vegetables.  We were shocked at how skimp they were on the pieces of seafood.  It makes me never want to order from here again which is saddening, just because the taste is normally so much better and portions much better.
author: Henry H.

description: First time trying this restaurant and ordered to go. Mongolian beef was spicy and good but needed onions.  Pot stickers were very good as the chicken broccoli. Atmosphere very nice.
author: M R.

description: Had the chicken and beef main dishes and the sauces were exactly the same. They were also pretty generic tasting. I am not rushing back.
author: Samantha S.

description:
"Make it all-white chicken...brown rice...no onions."
The head server at Eric's hates me. Oh wait, I think he hates everyone...

Despite him, Eric's serves up a very satisfying lunch value. Soup, tea, entree, and even pretty orange slices for dessert. I also like the sesame chicken, broccoli & cashew, sizzlin' rice soup. I tried the walnut prawns but I thought the sauce was kinda gross--like a mayo-sugar frosting?? I'm here for lunch 1-2x a week. Best part is the lunch deal is also available Saturdays. It does get a bit crowded, so do as the old folks do....go early!
author: Dora A.

description:
I have to admit that my first impression of Eric's wasn't very positive.

I had been warned by a chinese friend who lived in the area that it was "white people's chinese food." And, in a way, he's right. I could tell because everytime I walked by it, it was full of ..well.. white people. Not that white people's chinese food is bad, but sometimes you prefer something more authentic.

So month after month I tried chinese delivery in my area (Noe Valley), often being disappointed time and time again. 

One day, I decided to try it during lunch due to sheer laziness. Hmm!! What do you know? It's pretty good.

I just ordered take out the other day and I have to say that it beats the other deliveries I've had, hands down!

This might also be attributed to Eric's above-average restaurant. I've never been to the others but based on their food I imagine them to be hole in the walls.

I'm glad I finally gave in despite my first impressions. It's not the best chinese food and it may cater to certain audience, but it's decent if you're in the neighborhood and even better if you live in the area and want to get take out.
author: Pete C.

description:
I went here for lunch and it is a DEAL! Entrees are $6 to $7!!! Crazy! That's for a heaping mound of rice (brown or white) and a whole lotta Chinese food. I had the cashew brocolli chicken. I don't understand how there was so much food for $6! It tasted swell too.

Best crab rangoons I've eeeeeva had! Word to your mother.
author: Lisa F.

description:
I just went here for my first time, it was great. I chose the Sweet and Sour chicken (I always do), and my date chose Eric's Fried Rice. It was great! I think I'm going to switch my normal choice restaurant for chinese comfort food. The inside is really clean, and it feels like it should be more expensive than it is. It's cheap as most similar places are, and the portions are pretty good. 

One negative comment I would have is on the service. It's good, but I felt claustrophobic the whole time. I think it might partly be due to the time we came. But damn, give me some space! The second I put the fork down they came for my plate, and standing behind the waitress taking our empty plates was a waiter with the check. 

In summary though, it's good and I would definitely come again. Open pretty late too, which is good for me!
author: Aaron M.

description: Food was in edible. I took a couple of bites and couldn't eat it and they made me pay for it anyway. Will never go back.
author: Norm J.

description:
I really wanted to like this place but....The food was slathered in soy sauce and the lemon chicken was cold and stale.  I thought I had just ordered the wrong dish, but by looking at the food on other tables, it all looked the same.  Soaked in soy sauce or dark colored gravy.  

On a positive note: the staff are friendly and the restaurant is clean.  There's always a decent crowd any night of the week.  

Oh well..maybe I'll give it another try
author: Lisa E.

description:
This being my first time dining here, my opinion may not be as fair as it could be.  However, first impressions can be a bitch.  

We dined with a vegetarian friend visiting, so we ordered mostly vegetarian: one vegetarian appetizer,  two vegetarian entrees, with one non-vegetarian appetizer and one non-vegetarian entree.  More than enough food for three of us, and with enough left overs for two to eat lunch the following day.

The Vegetarian Egg Rolls looked crisp and delicious, although I did not indulge.  The Crab Rangoon, arrived a bit chewy and luke warm, as if they took a little trip through the microwave and then sat for a few minutes.  At the very least they should arrive crisp if not piping hot and crisp, they arrived neither which was quite disappointing.  We also had the Spicy Eggplant, which was "egg"ceptional, some of the best spicy eggplant I've had... AWESOME!  The spicy fried tofu with fried greens and pine nuts, was also quite good.  We ordered the Scallops with Szechwan Sauce and Broccoli as the non-vegetarian option.  This was at best average, drowned in sauce, and lacking scallops.  It is better described as Szechwan Sauce with Broccoli and some Scallops. 

I wanted to love Eric's, but it just didn't measure up to my expectations.  I will give it another shot, as my dining companions have dined here in the past and enjoyed those experiences.  Here's to hoping this was a weird off night fluke.
author: Kelly K.

description:
I find it really odd that a lot of people say they had terrible service. My boyfriend and I treat this place as our staple chinese restaurant ( the hot and sour soup, egg rolls, white rice, and normally a spicy meat dish). Its inexpensive and delicious. I will say that I have had dishes before that really weren't anything special. BUT- if you get the right thing, its perfect. Ask the waiter what they would recommend, and normally they give you great advice.

Also, the staff can get rushy when the place is crowded, otherwise they are attentive and friendly.
author: Krysti S.

description:
Food is OK. SOMETIMES the service is good but I have finally had it with the waitstaff. 
My husband and one of the waiters have gotten into debates because this one waiter won't give him a large bowl of soup if there are not enough people. Either he says "too much soup" or "not enough room on the table".
We've seen the waiters get in a full blown yelling match with one another.
One woman recently said "oh shit!" when she brought the wrong dish to our table.
I have found all of that strange, a little comical, but on mother's day we went in for lunch. It was empty. There was one table with people sitting, and a four seat table right next to it. The other four seaters were open. The "soup" guy says "you sit there!", where one chair is literally touching the back of the chair of one of the people at the other table. We had to say "excuse me" to squeeze in. We sat for a minute, pondered, reflected, then we left.
author: Mel B.

description:
Eric's is one of the best Chinese restaurants I have ever had the pleasure of attending.  The food is absolutely delicious, with extremely friendly and efficient service -- as long as you come in during a time where the tiny establishment is not packed with insanity-inducing hungry wolves, who cause the employees to have nervous breakdowns, frantically give you the wrong order, forget you exist up until said wrong order, and create last-timers out of first-timers.

However, I am giving them 4 stars because I have only had this experience once, and that was not my first time, nor is it an apt description of my most recent visit this afternoon.  Instead, I am now happily well-fed during a period of time where people were lining 24th St to experience the New Toast in order to accurately compare it to the Old Toast, or performing their usual Sunday routine of writing their names under the Waitwaitwait List in front of Chloe's.

Yay, Eric's!
author: Beth C.

description:
Best chinese food in the city.  Tell me what is better at this price?

I have eaten Eric's food at least 40 times in the last four years.

my favorite dishes include.

Crab Rangoon!  Generals chicken!
Hunan Lamb?

bombastic.

prompt, good service.  great for takeout.

Do you know the Alice story?  I would like to check that restaurant out finally.
author: J H.

description:
Swift, friendly service
Lots of good veggie options.
I heart veg. mu shu.
author: Alana D.

description: Yummy! There are plenty of veggie options here and the waitstaff is really nice. I feel this place is a little greasier than Henry's Hunan (which is nearby) but it's also possibly more flavorful. It's a tradeoff then, depending what I'm in the mood for. Eric's has this crazy good tofu dish with seaweed and this brown sauce that they mix up. Anyway, I'll be back for that!
author: Kristin S.

description:
so we wanted to eat out last night, someplace local - walking distance. my friend suggested Eric's (chinese?) food. interesting that a place named "Eric's" serves chinese food.

needless to say, i was not disappointed with this little restaurant in noe valley. now, i am by far no expert in chinese food, however, i would say it is not "authentic" chinese food.  their food is definitely more suited for an americanized palate, but with that said, it is tasty. spicy dishes are not real spicy. nice location, bright corner restaurant, good atmosphere unlike most dark, drab chinese restaurants i've frequented in the past.

service was fairly fast for a saturday night, however larger groups may require a longer wait for seating, as the dining area is on the smaller side for the amount of crowd this place draws. 

sesame chicken was alright/ fair- lacking a bit in flavor. had black sesame seeds, which i had never experienced before. nice alternative to the norm. kung pao shrimp was VERY tasty, (i must find out what was in that sauce!), and the veggies were served crisp- not soggy. nice. 

all in all,  i can see why this place is so popular.  good food, reasonably priced, decent service, nice atmosphere, and location.

oh, and btw, it's within walking distance of one of SF's best ice cream places....Mitchell's!!! A definite must for dessert after you've eaten here!
author: Lisa Z.

description: We generally like Eric's, so I'm sorry to post a disappointing experience yesterday.  The menu uses a "hot pepper" icon to show which dishes are spicy -- same as most restaurants.  Well, we ordered mango chicken, which we liked on a previous visit, and it supposed to be NOT spicy.  Well, it was moderately spicy, but the weird thing was that on the dish were several big pieces of what looked like jalapeno peppers.  We asked the waiter and he said yes, they were jalapeno peppers, but that the dish was not spicy!  How can a dish be not spicy with jalapeno peppers sitting on it??  Do not get this dish if you are sensitive to hot peppers.  Another dish, sizzling beef with scallops, was fun to watch & listen to at first, (it really does sizzle!) but tasted WAY too salty.  We'll avoid it next time.
author: Barbara B.

description:
Had some take out from here after a long dog walk. Great food, the
vegetable egg rolls are really fresh, and the staff there is very friendly.
author: Pete C.

description:
I live within blocks of dozens of Chinese restaurants, but I drive across town to get food from Eric's.

A friend of mine told me once that her physician wrote her prescriptions for Eric's wonton soup when she's come in sick.  Currently uninsured, I do what I can to stay as healthy as possible or nip a cold in the bud.  Eric's seems to do the job.

If you're a wor wonton soup fan, try it here.  It's packed with fresh vegetables (even asparagus, which I love), enoki mushrooms, delicious dumplings, beef and shrimp and served in a rich, vitamin-packed (tastes like it, at least) broth.  I ordered a "large" wor wonton soup and thought they made a mistake and gave me two larges instead of just one.  Apparently, at Eric's, their large portion is gargantuan ... they fill TWO of the TALL styrofoam soup containers with each large order (that's TWICE as big as other places!!).  I ate soup every day for a week ... and it was great each time!

I recommend the sesame chicken.  Unlike other places that weigh down random chicken pieces in batter, deep fries and drowns them in an unidentifiable sugary sweet "oriental sauce", Eric's uses chicken breast cut into strips, does NOT deep fry or batter them, and combines them with julienned carrots, zucchini and celery in a deliciously savory unidentifiable "oriental sauce".   What makes this dish even better is the crushed black sesame seeds they top it off with.  The flavor is much more complex, earthy and warm than the sometimes bitter or bland taste of white sesame.

As at most Chinese restaurants, Eric's offers lunch specials at bargain prices.  Less crowded during the day, that's a great time to eat in.  Otherwise, I recommend calling ahead and ordering takeout.
author: Jenny K.

description: Ive always liked Eric's but my recent experience disappointed me.  We waited a few minutes to order while the waiter had a loud conversation on his phone.  When the food came there was a  black hair in our steamed rice.  Again we waited for the waiter to reappear and brought it to his attention.  He returned w/a new bowl of rice.  As we were serving it there was a black hair in the bowl.  He didnt give us a new bowl.  Again waited for him and brought it to his attention and asked for new rice and a new bowl this time.  No real sorry or adjustment to the bill.  This experience bummed me out and changed my opinion of Eric's.
author: Lindsey T.

description: Not what it used to be. I got the fried rice and it was more like steamed rice with beef. My chicken broccoli hardly had chicken.
author: Irma P.

description: Good food, grumpy service not very helpful at all
author: Bryan E.

description:
i must be addicted to food because i actually just woke myself up wanting to write a review for eric's. part of me is still sleeping right now, so if you have ever wanted to see a zombie review something, now is your big moment. i am not kidding, i haven't even had coffee.

eric's is inviting, well lit with a lot of windows and always packed, which usually seems like a good sign.

the first time i dined at ye olde eric's was with a friend, who ordered the walnut prawns, which sounded like heaven. when they arrived they looked like someone had done some nasty things to them. why were the prawns white? because they were in a mayonnaise sauce. wait, what? why would you possibly drench delicious prawns in the cum of satan? i admit that i have a personal hatred with mayo but honestly, it blew my very mind to see the prawns devalued so deliberately. more for my butch dining partner, drowning her sorrows in a little white walnut shame hole.

the bootch ordered the sesame beef, which was crispy and spicy. perfectly unhealthy with nary a vegetable, just the way i am looking to be mollified after the whole mayo thing.

the next time i hit up eric's was mere days later while trying to figure where to go for christmas eve. again eric's was packed, still inviting, but much much more packed. at some point in the clearing of the appetizer (the combination for two plate which was very good) our waiter got a little rough with me and whacked me with a spoon in a hurry to take my plate away. i was still holding my drumette bone from the "drums of heaven".  i think i actually yelped and drew my hand back in surprise and the dude waiter apologized for hurting me. it's cool. i carry no scar. 

i decided to order the sesame chicken this time, thinking it would be just a poultry version of it's brother the sesame beef and what i got was a big bag of question marks. the dish came like a funeral. it looked like a lump grey with a liberal sprinkling of what i mistook for crushed beetles across the middle (but soon learned was black sesame). two bites in i made everyone try it, you know, because torturing your friends is the only way to feel better in these situations. i have tried to think of ways to describe it but the only word that comes to mind is why? please put a white block of medical tape over this on your menu eric's and i might be back to try the mango (mayo-less) prawns a chef acquaintance i know said was cool.

private to the parents of the kids who were clearly washing their butts in the sink and washing their hands in the toilet for about an hour. F.U. DUDE. i had to pee. bad.
author: Alysia A.

description: So close to home and so constantly good.  Eric's has yet to truly let me down in quality and taste.  The ingredients always taste and look fresh.   The prices are on the steeper side for Chinese food but you are getting quality so to me it is worth it.  If the quality starts to slip then I will start going down the road to Henry's.
author: Aus B.

description:
Great meal here this evening. I'm really stuffed as I usually find myself after a Chinese dinner. Here's the menu in simple 1-5 star rating. It's late and I'm getting lazy.

Sesame Beef - 5
Sesame Chicken - 2 (you'd think it would be similar to the sesame beef, but far from it. it was kind of sour...)
Mushu Vegetable - 3, just average.
Fried Chicken Wings - 3, but a few pieces might have been undercooked. we had to send them back to make sure.
Pot Stickers - 4. Yes, get them.
Sauted Green Beans - 4, tasty and good for you.
I'm not on a health kick, but my wife got the brown rice and it was awesome. 

Overall, a great place, with great food and service. A couple of dishes lost a star for me, and for a San Francisco restaurant, I was hoping for a better atmosphere/ decor. It's pretty plain, but it doesn't affect the good food, just the overall experience. I'll definitely come back.
author: Raymond G.

description:
i just don't get it.  gotta say, i've never been able to understand
why anyone thinks eric's is any different or better than any other
s.f. chinese restaurant.

i'd only eaten there once before years ago, when the most memorable
thing they served was the orange juice...because it was not only rancid,
it was so far off it was fizzy.  i got a huffy waiter
who brought the container out from the kitchen to point out that the
expiration date hadn't passed.  but wait...why would i care what the
container says - if it's rancid it's rancid!  he took it away...and
then tried to charge me for it.

and here's my latest experience.  i got the beef and scallops.  it's a
hot-plate dish, which was dumped unceremoniously at the table, without
any comment or serving utensil.  a late request for a side of white
rice went completely ignored until re-requested half the dish later.
about half of the beef was really tough, including a few completely,
utterly, inedible pieces.  as it started to cool it turned to hard
core brown cornstarch sludge - nothing subtle about this one.

the hot and sour soup was similarly constarchified, the veggie fried
rice boring, and the eggrolls bland.

so remind me again - what's so great about eric's?
author: will c.

description: Went to Eric's again this weekend. Just as good. Actually, I went with 2 people who had never been there before - despite having lived in SF for some time. They said that the food at Eric's wa some of the best upper end chinese food in the city. Another nice meal at Eric's.
author: Matthew M.

description: One normally doesn't associate the name with Chinese, but it worked. We had a larger group with a 5 year old and they were more than accommodating to our picky childs request, loudness and communal sharing of dishes. Really good, and we
author: Adriana K.

description: Good food grumpy service
author: b e.

description:
Californian-ized? Perhaps. Does it really matter? No.

Anyway, I lived two doors down from the place for a couple years and couldn't get enough. The Crab Meat Rangoons will blow your mind. Same with that prawn and walnut dish they serve with mayonnaise. I think it's called Walnut Prawns. Eric's has a very reasonably priced lunch special too. My Mom, a tight-wad if there ever was one, thinks the lunch deal at Eric's is the greatest thing ever. "And you get soup too," she keeps telling me. Yeah Mom, I know. Be prepared to wait for a table. By the way, the MUNI J train stops right in front of the place.
author: Brad L.

description:
I used to love Eric's back when I lived in SF.  But I went last week and was disappointed by everything but the hot and sour (or was it Egg drop?) soup.  We went for lunch and split pot stickers.  They were so-so.  Not as much ginger as I remember.
I got the king pao chicken, it was bland.  My friend got the curry chicken, she also thought it was bland.
I still like the atmosphere although was sad to see that the great flower shop next door had closed.
author: Lisa M.

description:
yeah, it's 'westernized' Chinese food, but it's hot and fresh and last time I was there, I got served in less than 10 minutes.  No kiddin'.

For vegetarians, I recommend the seriously delicious Shanghai tofu (it comes with some green crispy vegetable on top--seaweed?) and the Eggplant in Garlic sauce).  I was in serious happy-land afterwards. Not even a crappy uphill walk back to my car could ruin my mood.
author: Smruti S.

description:
Excellent and quick chinese food. Love the sesame beef, general tsao's chicken, STRING BEANS with fried tofu (the best ever!). Actually, everything on the menu looks good. Nice, clean atmosphere, quick and good service. Great for a date, groups (big food portions), and take-out- you'll most likely always have leftovers to bring to work the next day. 
PS: they dont have desserts here.
author: Miss Lili F.

description:
The first experience was tasty, but the company was not so great.  My date continued to let me ask questions, but asked me none.  Then proceeded to diss my car's suspension, talk about rich friends, and basically try to out-class me.  It was actually a fun experience and now I have the story.  But I digress!

The second time, my partner and I felt rather sick by the end.  It was really greasy and overcooked and just yucky all around.  Plus they REALLY rush you here and have zero service skills.  Zero.

What is entertainging about this place is the LOOOONG takeout line.  It's really unreal.  But it makes the whole place crowded and rushed and not special.

They also don't have chow fun, which is a major no-no.  I love chow fun.

I will never, ever return most likely.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Well... this is probably the worst Chinese restaurant in the city.

People rave about this place. And, why? It probably has to do with the fact that Noe Valley is this bizarre microcosm that no one dares to leave. A lot of it has to do with the concept of supporting the neighborhood. While that's fine in theory, it definitely has its drawbacks. Hence, the popularity of Eric's.

There is no flavor to the food. The service is horrendous and everyone is rude. "Yes, but all Chinese restaurant servers are rude," you say? Hmmmm.... I beg to differ. While that is frequently the case it more often happens in Chinatown than anywhere else. If I'm going to be treated in a rude manor I might as well enjoy the food.

Please leave Noe Valley every once in a while. It will be worth the trip.
author: Mark G.

description:
Thanks to reading the San Francisco magazine, I learned about Eric's.  In a readers' poll from about two years ago, it was ranked as one of the best Chinese restaurants in the city.  So, I gave the restaurant a try and have never regretted.  The dishes have been prepared more towards the American palate.  

My favorite dishes there are the Rainbow Fish, Mongolian Beef, General Tsao's Chicken, Green Beans and Tofu, Potstickers, and Crab Rangoon.  I tried their Fried Rice once and didn't like it at all...didn't have much of a flavor.  My co-workers and I go there for lunch every other month or so as they have daily lunch specials that are pretty cheap.
author: Michelle N.

description:
I used to rave about Eric's but then again, that was when I was a poor grad student living in the East Bay. After delighting in 3 years of exciting Chinese food in NYC, I am sorely disappointed in Eric's I kinda remembered that it wasn't exactly Chinese, but still, I remembered it fondly enough to drag my mom and bf there last week.

What a bummer. The service was great, quick and attentive, but the food, the FOOD... I don't know what happened. Maybe it's me, maybe it's Eric's, but I can't give it more than 2 stars. We ordered pot stickers, mushu pork, sesame beef, spicy basil chicken, which was sadly not at all spicy.  :( The portions were unsually huge, if you like that sorta thing.

I recommend Szechuan Trenz instead if you want yummy real Chinese fare. Eric's is the Chinese equivalent of Tex-Mex, which isn't necessarily bad, it's just not Chinese.
author: G Z.

description:
Ate here this past Friday around 9 and the place had seating.  Wasn't empty but it was packed either.

The avocado rolls are very good. Very similar to an egg roll but the inside was, of course, avocado.  It came with a sweet dipping sauce that was also very good.

Had our usual portabello mushroom with beef, off of the special items section.  Good dish.

Also tried the General Tso's chicken for the first time.  The chicken pieces were on the smaller side but flavors were still good.

Not too pricey but it's also not chinatown prices.  Most items, I would say, are in the $8-$9 range.
author: Will I A m.

description:
Lunched at Eric's today with some friends, and it was overall a really nice experience.  We had stingbeans with bean curd, veggie mu shu (sp?) and veggie chow mein.  Everything tasted fresh and looked great.  Yum!  The service was quick and they were very accommodating when we realized on our way out the door that we forgot to order takeout for one of the gal's fiance who was back at the house.  

I would definitely go back if I find myself in the area.  Go Erics!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
When I want Chinese food, I think of Eric's (or Alice's or Eliza's...how are they related anyway?)  Now I grew up in the Midwest and therefore NOTHING is a true ethnic food, especially Chinese food.  So I can't say how true to form the food really is but I do think they add crack or something addictive to it because I'm walking out of of the place stuffed thinking about my next order.  Everything I have gotten there has been great.  The avocado rolls ... oh my gawd. 

So why not 5 stars?  The service... rude.  It's usually packed and you have a wait when you go there.  The waitstaff are short, never look at you and throw the food on your table.  The next time you see them is when they want you to pay.  Oh, and don't ask them a question about the food.  You'll never get a satisfying answer.

With all that said...I still go back for the food.
author: Mike C.

description:
We go to Eric's all the time because it's close to our house.  We like it because it has fresh ingredients and they don't drown it in sauce.  You can specify how spicy you want it, and they are pretty good about getting it right, although you should tell them or you'll get mild as the default.  

The parking can be a pain, but if you go a couple of blocks away you'll find something.
author: Tonie C.

description:
I must admit....I am not super crazy for the ONE-sauce concept. 

EVERYTHING tasted the same!  The BF and I ordered separate entrees and both the prawns and the chicken dishes were smothered in this strange brown salty sauce.  Very Funky - not in a good way.
author: Veritas V.

description:
The guy I've been dating said Eric's was one of his favorite Chinese places to go to. I'd never heard of it, so we went to check it out last week.

The place is cute. 

The food...just above decent I'd say. It's a standard faire kinda joint. Nothing spectacular about their menu. Nothing interesting in terms of special dishes.

We ordered the potstickers, the spicy eggplant and the Shanghai Chicken, with brown rice on the side. I'd probably pass on the chicken dish the next time I go. It was servced over a bed of pan fried collard greens and I just didn't resonate with the texture of said collards. But the potstickers were pan-fried perfectly. And the eggplant in the eggplant dish was pretty good. 

Overall, not as good as San Tung, or even House of Chen.
author: Matthew M.

description:
How can you not love Eric's Lunch Special? (avaliable Mon-Sat)

Highly recommend the Spicy Eggplant or the Hunan Fish.

If your in for dinner the Shanghi Tofu is out of this world.  And the Avocado Rolls (deep fried) I could eat 10 of them and still want more!! Mmmmm- I am hungary just thinking about it!

And you get all the hot tea you can drink along with orange slices @ the end of you meal.

This place is good, fast and cheap.  Highly recommend that you go here, eat, and repeat.

(My only downfall with them is that whether I ask for SPICY or EXTRA SPICY- it always tastes the same)
author: Dangerous T.

description: Meh - totally mediocre. Heavy, a little too greasy. Go to Alice's... only a few blocks away, much cleaner and healthier.
author: Nicholas H.

description: Incredible Chinese food.  The service was phenomenal as well.  The food came quickly and the service staff was very attentive.  Prices are fair as well.  It's a solid Chinese food restaurant.....no frills, probably not a good first or anniversary spot....but it's great food and service.
author: Rob A.

description:
Hey, I like Eric's. 

But is it a good Chinese restaurant? None of my Chinese friends think so. 

The food is totally westernized. Everything is a bit sweet and it all tastes alike. It's a good alike, but still... 

And have you noticed that the most successful Asian places are the most westernized? 

Cases in point:

- Slanted Door - western name, western waiters, super popular. 
- Eric's and Elizas - western name, asian waiters, popular but not as much as the above. 
- Y. Ben house - bet you never heard of it....
author: Jacob L.

description:
Pretty Good chinese food. But its more like Jazzy Hunan food of sorts. It's not authentic Chinese though.  You can get brown rice in place of white. Clean and bright, it's a good date place. The Hunan Fish and Sweet and Sour pork are my favorites. Both have crunchy breading while in their sauces.

Pros: Very tasty good foods. Lunch Specials are excellent, i've tried every item at least once.
Cons: Sometimes the sauces / gravys is too thick and overwhelming.


i wish they had General Tsao's Chicken as a Lunch Special, but they tell me that it takes too long to make quick and tasty.
author: ToAsTy T.

description:
"Relaxed" is the word I would use to describe Eric's. You can tell right off the bat that this place has a sort of laid back atmosphere, which is in contrast to the hustle and bustle of the typical Chinese restaurant. For a person like me who likes to take things easy I could already tell I was going to like my experience here. 

I had a party of six and the waiter (an Andy Lau lookalike) promptly set us up with two tables despite the relatively small size of the restaurant. We ordered the Mongolian beef, sesame beef, eggplant dish, mango prawns, and sweet and sour pork. I can safely say that Eric's delivers great food across the board. I was pleasantly surprised with their eggplant because, well, eggplant isn't usually much a standout dish. The mango prawn, however, didn't really taste like prawn nor did it have enough of a mango flavoring I was expecting. Also, though the dishes tasted very good by all means, they aren't anything special or too different. 

Overall, great experience. Would not mind coming back here if I am in the area.
author: Steven S.

description:
VEGGIE MUST-HAVES

Healthy: 
Spicy Smoked Tofu(with leeks and chili peppers)

Not As Healthy but Good:
Shanghai Tofu(sweet and savory but not overly sauced)
author: michelle s.

description:
I had a really great experience here.

I ordered the braised string beans and the family style tofu, both were great dishes.
author: G J J.

description:
I see that somebody has already posted the health score of 56/100 from last week's SF Examiner. Too bad, this restaurant has a couple of dishes that are quite good, such as their Eric's cakes and Walnut Prawns (which is more common in other Chinese restaurants). The ambiance is also nice and quite calming. Hopefully they can work on improving their score.
Previous score was 67/100.
author: Chad B.

description:
The presentation and feel of this restaurant is pretty good for what you pay for.  The dishes are affordable, presented well and fairly good for a mid-level Chinese restaurant.  The fresh orchids decorating the walls are a beautiful addition.  A good change from third-tier, generic landscape paintings that so often bedazzle greasy walls in run-down Chinese restaurants. 

Both my hubby and mother thought the lamb dish was a bit too salty, and were unable to finish it.  The Walnut Prawn's and Ocean Garden dishes were decent, and well presented in a crisp noodle basket.

However, the service was not executed well.  They get the job done with minimal effort.  We felt a bit rushed.  But, you can't really expect much service from Chinese restaurants.  I was just hoping, just maybe, that Eric's would be a tiny step above it all.
author: Hellyn M.

description:
I love Eric's MuShu Pork! Sometimes I crave it, need it, have to have it...that good!

I am not typically a Mushu fan, but there is something about Eric's version that I love. The sauce is tasty, the Mushu flavorful and the pancakes are a little thicker than others and always fresh.

I also recommend the Walnut Prawns and potstickers!
author: Dee C.

description:
I've been a major fan of Eric's for the past 14 years,  food is great..... avocado egg rolls are to die for!!!!!!!  Ambiance is hip and cool with a minimalist aesthetic....not typical  for a Chinese place.  It gets pretty crowded, so we like to go early.

A reason it doesn't get 5 stars...........my friend and I went there once with her infant son (we used to be roomies in the hood and were SO excited to have us some Eric's) and the staff was visibly irritated that we brought a baby with us, it kind of bummed us out.
author: Lauren S.

description: This restaurant is like a spinoff of the Eliza Restaurant that used to be on 18th Street in Potrero Hill.  They cook (seems like) Hunan-style Chinese food geared a bit towards non-Chinese.  Still it's not bad, better than most of others of its type.  It has nice decor.  In the past, I mostly ordered ma po tofu which was good with the two types of mushrooms they add (I love mushrooms).
author: H K.

description: Fast service and fabulous food. I tried two dishes and first time since being in the southern regions of China have I had "Chinese" food that tasted even remotely like what I had there. This food is reasonably priced and satisfying. The service was average to decent, the location was nice. There is a cold breeze from the door so ask for a table to your right when you walk in!
author: Noel H.

description: I have been coming here for years. Really good Chinese food for a reasonable price. Can have long waits on weekend nights and they do not do reservations. Come early or be willing to wait. It is worth it. An extremely small space jam packed with tables. Very load. Those waiting for take put often stand next to your table while you eat, kinda awkward. Service and quick and efficient although not very polite. Language barrier between you and staff. Often they know as much English as I know Chinese........none. Great menu with lots of options. My favorites include the crab rangoons, mushu pork, sesame beef, walnut prawns, and Shanghai Chicken. The soups ate delicious as well.
author: Tobius M.

description: I'll admit. I've never sat down to eat here. But the take-out is amazing and totally five star worthy.
author: Jena D.

description: I love this place :) Best Chinese food Ive had in San Fran :)
author: Kevin S.

description:
5 stars because I really can't recommend a better chinese restaurant. They might be out there but I haven't found them yet. Eric's is fresh, tasty, and quick. I have never been disappointed. Of course who can go wrong with walnut prawns. The prawns are great but that edible looking basket they come in... not so great. Of course I know that you aren't supose to eat it, nevertheless, everytime I see a little bit of that mayonase sauce lingering and there are no prawns or walnuts to be found... I go for it. 
*Check out their sister restaurant Eliza's on Potrero Hill
author: Erin W.

description:
I would've given this place 5 stars, but I was sorely disappointed with the wonton soup I had on Sunday.  I don't know about you, but something about Sunday just screams out "Chinese Food!" to me.  I'm sometimes worse for wear after Saturday night out at the bars, kinda tired, definitely don't feel like cooking anything, and lo and behold, there's Eric's.  

Now I live in the Inner Sunset, so I often go to San Tung on Sundays.  But I do often enjoy some quality couchtime/TV watching on a Sunday afternoon, and seeing how I don't have cable, I often go hang out with some friends whom live in Noe Valley.  Six pm rolls around, I start to get hungry, and for the aforementioned reasons, we go to Eric's.

Not the cheapest chinese in town, but nothing in Noe Valley is the cheapest anything in town, so I don't sweat it.  Sesame beef is good, as is the oddly-dubbed, "Fly-Taste Chicken" which thankfully doesn't taste anything like flies. At least I think so, if that's what flies taste like, then sign me up!

Anyhoo.  Don't get the wonton soup though, $5.25 for a small was basically a few wontons in some chicken stock with a few veggies, bland and flavorless.  Get just about everything else though.
author: Jake S.

description:
If Only They Delivered!  3.5 stars.

The food and prices are great; the dining "experience" is not -- my solution: take out!  Dinner for two around $30 (with leftovers).  Go back?  Yes, but just to pick up my order.

Place.  Corner of 27th St and Church: parking is a nightmare.  (If you are just picking up, either double park and hope the J Church doesn't come, or snag the spot in front of the hydrant and hope the metermaid doesn't come.)  A white box with big windows, and with as many table crowded in as possible.  If dining in, try to get a table up front.

Food.  Excellent ingredients; generous portions; tasty sauces.  For starters, "Eric's Cakes" are yummy, somewhat oily scallion pancakes; the potstickers are standard; and the crab meat rangoon is just tasteless unless you count the sweet sauce.  My favorite dishes include the Mongolian Beef, General Tso's Chicken, Eric's Spicy Eggplant, String Beans with Bean Curd, and definitely the Clams with Black Bean Sauce.  BTW, nothing is really that spicy.

Service.  Abrupt; gets the job done.  Always a line for dinner.  For take out, call ahead and it's ready in about 15 minutes.
author: Yan L.

description: This is the best Chinese restaurant in the city! Their ingredients are very high quality. Huge portions, reasonable prices, friendly attentive service. Everything I've tried has been absolutely delicious and fresh.
author: Alli D.

description: I have to say this is one of the best chinese food restaurants I've ever been to.  Usually a lot of chinese restaurants taste greasy and heavy but this place does not fall into that category.  The food was not heavy and tasted really fresh!!  The service is a step up from your typical chinese restaurant but don't expect Nordstrom service.  This is one of my new favorites and I've already recommended it to a bunch of friends and posted about it on Facebook.  Definitely check it out!
author: DuWatte J.

description:
Inexpensive and HUGE portions.  That being said, the food is decent, although not mind blowing. I do like the mango chicken. 
Their dishes do seem to just vary on the kind of vegetables included with your chosen meat.  However, if you just want some middle of the road Chinese food in Noe Valley, then this is fine.
author: Christie F.

description: They make mu shu pancakes perfectly and I always like the food. Sort of reminds me of 1980s chinese food but with a slight California twist. Their hot and sour soup is really good. I wish they delivered but they do takeout super fast. Best Chinese in Noe/Bernal area.
author: Ben L.

description: Love the hot & sour soup and the sesame beef. The shanghai chicken is also pretty great. Prompt, polite service, delicious food, affordable prices make this restaurant a neighborhood staple.
author: Mus P.

description:
Outstanding food marred by overzealous service. This definitely would have been a five star review but for the service. Mouth-watering hot and sour soup and delicious entrees (best Shanghai Chicken I've ever had).  

Unfortunately the service was off-putting. Not that they weren't fast and efficient -- they were -- but we had to fend off numerous attempts to clear our table. I understand that restaurants want to turn their tables over but we really didn't linger for very long and the constant interruptions began to feel like harrassment.
author: Alan R.

description:
Had heard about Eric's and finally tried this place. It was quite good. If you go to an Indian restaurant, and you see a lot of Indians eating there, chances are the food will be good. If you go to a Japanese restaurant and you see Japanese people eating there, chances are the food will be good. Not so true with Chinese restaurants. I guess I like more Americanized Chinese food (recognizable meat etc.,). Good food and reasonable prices.  Go there.

P.S. I don't agree with a previous reviewer who compared this place unfavorably to Eliza's. The food isn't as good as Eric's and last time I ate there I spent  half the time swatting gnat like bugs from my table.
author: Boss H.

description:
As I was eating my leftovers, I decided to write a review of Eric's slipping standards since I first ate there a few years ago. But when I saw the info. about the health rating, it confirmed that I'd never go back. 

I have liked the food in the past, but it's not been as good the couple times I went. A 56 is shockingly low, and makes me wonder at what point SF actually closes a place. 

By the way, leftovers were left unfinished.
author: mary y.

description:
I originally found this place on "Check, Please! Bay Area" show. The reviewer got it right on the nose!

I normally don't like veggies, but am able to eat every morsel on my plate. They don't use MSG. The wine list makes us easy for us non-savvy wine drinkers & describe each wine to match the meal. The bathroom is pristine. Locals are really nice. Sitting by the window watching the J-Line and people walk their dogs brings a nice vibe to Noe Valley. And all the servers speak English well and don't rush you like most Chinese restaurants.

Eric's Restaurant replaced my former favorite Chinese restaurant. I absolutely love this place!!!
author: L S.

description: amazing restaurant in a great area of San Francisco.  Not too busy and the streets are just big enough for strolling and enjoying good company on a San Francisco night.  Eric's staff warmly welcomed myself and a friend although they were very close to closing for the night.  The service was amazing -- I watched in wonder as our waitress prepared our mushu pork at our table with practiced perfection -- and it tasted amazing to boot.  I would definitely return here again.
author: Lauren P.

description: One star added for raising their health inspection score to an 86. Way to go, Eric! Unfortunately I don't know if the food/service is any better because I don't go here any more...
author: Jason Y.

description: I've been here a few times things started off good the food was fresh and service was fast. The service however isn't as fast or friendly as it needs to be. The food is still very good hot and fresh. Get the walnut prawns!  The pot stickers are good as well. I'm only giving them three stars because I have very high customer service standards and they just are not meeting them.
author: Ashley K.

description:
I wish I could give 2.5 stars, but I can't....   :(

Dishes ordered: 

Eric's Eggplant - very yummy and lived up to the hype created by friends

Sesame Beef - OK.  It tasted like something you could get at Panda Express

Kung Pao Chicken - not very spicy and actually kind of bland (boooo!)

Garlic Shrimp - loaded with sliced celery sticks.  The flavor was a bit too tangy.  Just a strange combo all around

The bill - $14 each for 4 people. Not bad, and the reason why I leaned towards 3 stars and not 2.

Ambiance - Nice.  Very different than most Chinese food places in that it's not your typical hole in the wall.  You can actually take a 1st date to this one.

Service - Poor.  The guy who claimed to be Eric was very pleasant , but the others were rude and not very service oriented.

If I lived i this neighborhood I might visit again, but I think I'll stick to the average Chinese Food restaurant in my own hood.

Sorry Eric's, you let me and my friends down when we were craving good Chinese food.  And nothing is worse than disappointment when you're HUNGRY  :(
author: DJ N.

description: Locals love it and so do I! They're quick, friendly, the food is simple, delicious and affordable. If you don't want to leave Noe Valley for good Chinese food Eric's and Alice's are the only places to go.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Our favorite Chinese restaurant in SF. The staff has always been exceptionally nice, and the food is delicious. My personal favorites are mango chicken, shanghai chicken and green beans with tofu. Very reasonably priced. And no MSG!  You will not be disappointed.
author: Carolyn C.

description: A shade fresher than Alice's around the corner. On nights where there is a school function parking is difficult at Alice's. Erics usually has a wait, but the didn't on a Friday I was there. Everything is good.
author: Greg H.

description: I must have gone through the looking glass because the Eric;s i had take-away from was a disaster!  Everything had this dark goopy sauce on it which made it completely inedible. I don't think i will return in the near future,
author: Audrey T.

description: We continue to order take-away from Eric's every couple of months. It's consistently fresh, delicious and quick.
author: Bonnie B.

description:
not a bad restaurant.. they were slammed on xmas day. my family and some friends went there for dinner. service was good, noisy a little cramped. food was ok. don't know many if any chinese restaurant serves avacado spring rolls though. 
   at the end of the dinner we split the bill 2 ways down the middle. my friend paid cash and i paid with a credit card, he worked the tips into the whole amount and told the server to split it, then i signed the reciept and the server had the audacity to ask me for a tip, which was already worked into the bill. i thought that tipping was based on service and not a must give.
author: Dawg F.

description: "White people chinese food" it may be, but it's great nonetheless.  But then I'm not one to be stuck up about "authentic" when "delicious" presents itself instead.  When all's said & done, it's the taste that matters, ja?
author: Godot -.

description: $6 for a huge portion of delicious chinese food, rice, soup, oranges, and fortune cookie?  Yes please!  The food is really good and you just can't beat their lunch special.  I was there the other day and had the beef and broccoli, yum!
author: Karen B.

description:
Much much better than your average chinese restaurant, but execution is not always on.

Overall I would suggest it, especially if it's in your hood.
author: john s.

description: Don't get the sweet and sour pork - which should be good.stick w the chic salad or sesame beef.
author: Nancy M.

description: I love how this place offers vegetarian options! its hard to find good vegetarian chinese food.  Its not amazing at eric's but its good and cheap and it makes a great lunch and dinner. its a good realistic meal and the food is definitely reliable
author: Hannah S.

description: Sure, if you do not mind all your dishes using the same brown sauce.  I cook Chinese food a lot.. and trust me on that. It is the same sauce.. and they claim that they don't use MSG.. sure.. bec' they don't need to ADD additional MSG, it is all in the brown sauce.
author: Ervinna L.

description: Other than the hideous parking and the crowds, Eric's is a great place for Chinese, if you're not into the "Clement Street" type of Chinese food.  I love their sesame chicken.  It's made with squash and carrots, which tastes heavenly.  I always come here for lunch, because their specials are very reasonable.  The atmosphere is very clean, very artsy and very pretty...
author: Kristina R.

description: Dependable Americanized versions of classic Hunan and Mandarin dishes in a usually crowded and very noisy dining room. Among my favorite dishes are the walnut prawns, sesame chicken, twice-cooked pork, and Mongolian beef. The sizzling rice soup is a great starter. Vegetarians will find the eggplant in a spicy garlic sauce to be an excellent option.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Decent.  Not the most authentic Cantonese food you will get and not the most healthful (my chicken dish was doused with sauce), but a passable alternative in the chinese food desert that is Noe/Mission.  The ambiance was much better than I expected - relaxed, not dive-y.
author: Melinda C.

description: Eric's has remained the epitome of Chinese food perfection in my eyes since I moved to San Francisco some dozen+ years ago. It's rather small, which can pretty much guarantee a wait, but that also equates to cozy and intimate. I don't get over there as often as I'd like, but he's never far from my mind's eye when I crave General's chicken.
author: Gregor G.

description: Went here after multiple recommendations and they didn't disappoint! The spicy eggplant was fantastic and the service was great. I don't think our water glasses ever got to half empty. I was also surprised by how affordable it was! A meal for two with enough to take home was under 30 bucks! We will definitely go back soon.
author: Justin M.

description:
you cant beat this place for a $7 deliscious food sit down lunch special.......

quick, friendly, tasty(not to saucy like others in the neighborhood), and i love the the plants in the window....

all the regular dishes here served quick n tasty....
author: alex m.

description: I can't believe I have neglected to review Eric's.  It's a place I like to go when I just want a good meal.  I really like the hot and sour soup as well as the crab rangoon.  As for entrees, you can't go wrong with the sesame beef and the string beans as a side.  After all this talk of food, I want to go there right now.  Also, I think they have sensors in the water glasses, because any time the level hits below a certain point, there is someone to fill your glass almost immediately.  Gotta love that.
author: Lu E.

description:
I dunno, I was really happy with Eric's the first time I went (about two years ago) but when I went last night, I was not terribly impressed. I've no doubt that it's popular--packed to capacity at 9:30 PM on a Sunday night! That's swell. But for me, food, service, and ambiance were all wrong. To start, despite a reservation we waited for 15 minutes to sit down. I don't usually complain about this, since I understand that it's hard to measure how frequently a table turns, and you can't exactly ask customers to leave. But they weren't exactly polite or apologetic about it, and that kind of disappointed me. So there's my first ::sigh:: Then we sat down and after a while they took our order in a not-at-all friendly kind of a way. That's ::sigh:: number two. When the sizzling rice soup came, I was delighted by how it looked. The rice was sizzling in just the right way, the snow peas and carrots looked vibrant...but it tasted...not cooked. It just tasted like someone rushed through a soup to heat it up to burning hot, without really making any of the vegetables tender. Another ::sigh:: As the kicker, each dish we ordered (eggplant with spicy sauce, Ocean Garden, General Tso's chicken, mango prawns) had something wrong. Too much sauce, not enough taste, rubbery shrimp, chicken too cooked...I dunno, it was just all very disappointing. 

I am sad, sad. I used to think that Eric's was a good restaurant, but now I need to have another really great experience there for me to change the way I feel about it. Oh well, I suppose I should just go on a less busy night and see how it goes...
author: Josephine J.

description: Perfect restaurant if you want something casual, relatively inexpensive and quick.  Especially if you want something quick.  Left work on a Friday at 5pm, took a Bikram class till 7, rolled with the muni from 7ish to 8:30, walked up the hill to my home in Noe and at 9:15pm started my search for an open super low-key, casual restaurant with street parking.  Castro was crowded.  Mission was packed...   I easily found parking near Eric's on Church Street and came to my dinner destination.  After putting my order in, the food came out within 10 minutes.   My favorites dishes (at this restaurant & at Eliza's and Alice's) are the Sizzling Rice Soup (the large size is a perfect meal for one person), the spicy Eggplant and Buddha's delight.   The dinner was perfect for a tired, starving Bikram gal.  10:30pm and I'm at home yelping about it.  Goodnight.
author: michele g.

description: A great little chinese joint in the heart of Noe.  The dishes are a little different, served lighter and less greasy than your typical chinese-american restaurant, yet still modestly priced.  The Shanghai Chicken was quite tasty.  I do recall that the tables are jammed in rather densely and it can be a hassle to try to move around.
author: Rick H.

description: My friend lives in Noe Valley, and we eat the lunch special at Eric's a lot.  They've got a pretty decent deal for lunch, and it's a big portion of food.  The sesame chicken is really yummy, as is the Basil Chicken.  Chow Mein isn't great, but it'll do in a pinch.  Love the decor.  Nice, mellow place to eat.
author: Honey L.

description:
Sometimes I grudgingly buy in to hype, other times it completely turns me off, and occasionally I will drink the juice by the gallon.  At Eric's I am turned off by how easily I drink the juice.  On a list of restaurant choices it almost automatically gets a bye to the final round to battle some worthy challenger.  The Sesame Beef is meth to me.  I have been to Eric's several times, including visits with friends who are vegetarian or don't like spicy food, the bastards, and have never had a bad meal.  For sure the food is consistently a nice step above average.  Yet every time it wins I end up leaving feeling like I just cycled away from manic as somehow the overall experience never meets the expectations.

My most recent visit covers the full range.  Let's start with the service which was either smarmy friendly, in that unwinked nod to the fact that this is *Eric's*, or rough and rushed.  But also entirely competent.  Our Crab Rangoon came out crazy fast yet while tasty the wontons had that 'fresh out of the microwave chewy albeit recently fried' thing going.  They were a bit greasy but nothing like the veggie eggrolls.  And for both apps they brought only one small saucer each of hot mustard and sweet and sour sauce.   I understand conserving space on the table and we can always ask for more but that just doesn't cut it.  Use bigger bowls if need be.  We also ordered Garlic Eggplant, Family Style Tofu, and Scallops and Broccoli with Szechuan Sauce.  The eggplant was excellent both in flavor and quality with large pieces of eggplant.  I love eggplant!  The tofu was very tasty and cooked perfectly with a lightly crisped exterior and warm and juicy interior.  But while the sauce for the scallops was good there was just way too much of it.  Imagine broccoli fully loaded with and dripping sauce.  The scallops themselves were of at best average quality and in general the dish had more of a broccoli with scallops feel to it than vice versa.

yelp needs half stars because this really is a 3.5 star place.
author: Jay W.

description: I prefer Wild Pepper's food.  Great space, but the pork in the sweet and sour pork was disgusting.  Tasted not fresh.  I don't know why I even get that dish ever, anywhere - I have no idea what that fluorescent red goo is made of.  It went right through me, if you know what I mean.  I had a better meal there before, so I will not eliminate Eric's from my options.   I left grumpy, hence this review.
author: Christian H.

description: Somehow, 3/4 of the dishes taste the same.  But I admit that the mango chicken is pretty good and that fact alone keeps me ordering takeout from here.   I just don't understand why people wait so long to be seated here -- don't they all live in the neighborhood anyway?
author: Nat K.

description: It's always yummy and the food shiny, saucy, yet clean.  If that makes it americanized (i would say it probably does), then it's ok by me.  Everything's always yummy.  I tried the sizzling rice soup last time and it was simple and great (simple in not overflavored, but not simple in all the things in it - shrimp, scallops, waterchestnuts, rice of course, chicken that i picked out only because im vegequarian or whatever you want to call it...).  I've enjoyed all of the many dishes i've tried, but the sizzling rice crispies on the soup is really fun to listen to and then crunch on.  Parking is not fun, but  it's doable (and the muni train-line goes right by it, too.)
author: Today Y.

description: I, too, have been chastised by chinese friends for referring to Eric's as chinese food.  OK, so it's not real Chinese food.  But, the deliciousness is very real.  Could we call it Chinese American food and get over it?  I'm mexican and I enjoy delicious southwestern and tex mex food every bit as much as I enjoy authentic mexican food.  So I'll let people enjoy burritos (not real mexican) If they let me have my Eric's in peace.  I've been going to Eric's since I first moved to San Francisco 11 years ago.  I don't live in the city anymore (eventually caved in and moved to the East Bay to get a bigger place), but my husband and I have this ritual of stopping at Eric's on the way  back from SFO after we've been out of town, and it always makes us feel so happy to live here, and to be back home. I love love love love their sesame beef.  And their hot and sour soup.  And that pine nut and chicken dish they have.  Yes, they do kind of rush you through your meal, but it's part of the experience.  Just ignore them, it's not like they;re going to grab you and throw you out if you take too long.
author: cecilia g.

description: Not the most authentic Chinese food, which should be obvious from the fact that there's no Chinese name, and no Chinese on the menu. How very non-threatening. A nice and airy Indochine colonial decor that you won't get to enjoy because the waiters will do their best to get you in and out. Been there twice and the food is ok. I liked the mango chicken. You are much, much better off at Ton Kiang!
author: Hao L.

description:
i like Eric's for all of the great memories that I have had their---I have been going there for a decade.  

I like the Eric's Tiger Prawns, Sesame Chicken,  Hoisin String Beans.  --is it a gourmet eatery--no?  it is doesn't pretend it is-- is it authentic Chinese (Mandarin or Szechuan)?  

I would prefer they reduce the amount of oil they use and  would really like a higher grade meat and reduced fat in the portions served.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: My dad and I recently had lunch with my 91-year old great aunt. My aunt has lived in Noe Valley for 60+ years and has definite opinions about neighborhood restaurants. So it's a testament to Eric's being a fine, established neighborhood Chinese place that she choose it for our takeout lunch. We got three dishes that came with rice, hot and sour soup and oranges, while my aunt got the spring rolls with avocado that she likes. Inexpensive, reasonably good food and plenty of it. Eric's remains high in our estimation, but my aunt did note that there didn't use to be this much lettuce-stuff in the spring rolls. She can't eat cabbage, so quit it with the extra lettuce stuff, ok?
author: Megan K.

description: I'm a big fan of Eric's, and not because it's just down the hill. The food does vary in yumminess somewhat from time to time, but overall, it's great. They're super fast for take and friendly and efficient if you eat in.
author: Chris R.

description: I liked it, but himself being Asian said it was white peoples Chinese food. If i was by myself i would go there, but he wont go there. He & I said that there was nothing wrong with the food, it was "white" peoples Chinese food. that doesn't make it bad, it just puts it into a different folder.
author: ORLA L.

description: Fun little place to go to if you know your date well enough to not care whether or not you can hear one another.  It's loud but you can get in fairly quickly and for a place that's kind of isolated, the food is quite good.  My boyfriend definitely loves it more than I do but that's what's so entertaining because he knows all the good dishes to try.  Reasonably priced bordering on inexpensive so worth a whirl in my opinion.
author: Jill D.

description: My friend loves this Chinese place and often comes for their lunch special.  We went for dinner tonight.  I had the pork pot stickiers which were good though I suppose they did scorch them a little bit.  Also had the Sesame Beef (mild) with brown rice which was tasty.  Enjoyed a glass of their house Pinot Gregio and the service and decor were fine.  I can see why my friend enjoys this place.
author: Jim B.

description: I used to love Eric's and go there all the time.  I just went back after a couple of years, and found that it's gone totally downhill.  The food was terrible;  the sauces seemed to be slight variants of one another and tasted like soy sauce with sugar.  I was disappointed and probably won't go back.
author: Matt B.

description: appetizers and soups are delish, the entrees leave a stain in your stomach. If you do go here, try their special rolls.
author: L R.

description: When I eat Chinese food I like to squat, it's easier to shovel food in you're mouth.  This place is good but Jesus Christ people it's not the best Chinese food.  I take a star off because I'm sick and tired of people telling me that they rather eat 5-spice chicken than roasted duck and choy sum.
author: Justin C.

description: Not authentic from what I hear, but definitely tasty.  I could go with a group of 10 people ordering different things and still not get a taste of all the things I want from the menu.  I usually get the General Tso's chicken - how anybody could not love what is essentially fried chicken in syrup is beyond me.  Good for eat-in or quick takeout.  Don't take the often surly waitstaff personally.  Or, at least, I've chosen not to.
author: David G.

description: The restaurant was relatively clean, airy and neat. The service was okay. The food was flavorless. Not offensive, just horribly bland.
author: Matt W.

description:
Concur on the Shanghai Chicken sea weed never tasted soooooo good.  This place is always worth a stop when in the area.

Cheers!
author: Ryan B.

description: I've never actually sat down and eaten here.  I always do carry-out as I live just around the block.  It only takes 15 minutes.  The people are always very nice.  The food is always wonderful.  What more could you ask for?  Oh yeah...delivery!
author: Chris M.

description: I'm the first to admit the service can be slow and the waiters angry, but hot damn! they have some good food. The Sesame Beef, the Five Taste Chicken, the honey prawns (I think...), all fantastic. Good enough to outweigh the fact that there's always a wait, the dining room has waaay too many tables in it to be comfortable, and the afore mentioned angry service. This is definitely one of my top two picks for Chinese in SF (If you're ever in North Beach check out Chef Gia's!).
author: Jeff S.

description: You know how it seems that every single Chinese place has exactly the same things on the menu, same ingredients, same preparation?  Eric's is not that place, and we love them for it.  Always friendly, always fast.  Eat there or take out.
author: John L.

description: I think it has gone downhill recently. The last two times I went here I was not nearly as happy with the food as I usually am. Bummer.
author: Adrienne G.

description: ERics chinese good is so damn good!! the garlic fryed coconut is amazing OMG!  the waiter sucked and it was valentines day so that annoyed me!! but the erics chow mein and sweet n sour pork was so damn good.. and they even made me orange chicken which isnt on the menu!! its really inexpensive and huge plates of food
author: Shauna P.

description: This is definitely my favorite Chinese place in town.  Eric's does something that is hard to do - it elevates Chinese food into something interesting and different.  They have all the classic Chinese dishes, but somehow they seem fresher and tastier than your average Chinese food.  My favorites General Tso's Chicken and the spicy Eggplant  Gotta luv Erics!!!
author: Peter S.

description: We go to Eric's on a regular basis.  It is a good neighborhood restaurant that is above average in taste, and reasonably priced. They have some unique dishes.  My favorite are the Avocado rolls. I've had better Chinese food, but Eric's is convenient and good.
author: R B.

description: so so so yummy.  Love the pot stickers.  If they had a delivery service, they'd get 5 stars.
author: Stephan W.

description: Yes this is Americanized Chinese food but it is damn good. The mu shu pork and walnut prawns are my favorites. Not super expensive considering the neighborhood and the nice waiter service.
author: Mairead J.

description: I'll stick with Eliza's in Potrero Hill.  IQ's fried rice was good but I'd like to see some carrots and peas in there for my money.  My sesame beef was good too, nice and crispy, but a bit one-dimensional in flavor.  The potstickers were not even close to as good as those at Eliza's.  Toss in the borderline rude waitstaff and I'm not sure what all the fuss is about.
author: Kevin S.

description: I'd seen the lines outside the door of this place so many times, I had to give it a try to see what all the fuss was about.  The food was pretty good, but not the best Chinese I've had.  It was super bustly in there and extremely noisy -- not a place to take a date or socialize with a friend if you want to do a lot of conversing.  I don't plan on going again.  If I lived in the neighborhood, I'd probably just do take-out.
author: Bodacious T.

description:
The food was really good.  How we got the food, and the timing of that, was what turned me off about this place (in addition to the lighting which is a bit bright and sterile).
The waiter was on us for a drink and app order before our butts had even hit our chairs.  Then he kept coming back asking us if we were ready? ready? ready? yet.  It was intense.  Like something was wrong and they needed us out a.s.a.p.  We finally had to tell the wait staff to please chill out and let us eat as we were feeling very rushed.
(They informed us that the kitchen was closing in a little while, which is totally acceptable, but they should have said that up front.)
We had to go over our bill because there were a couple things that didn't match what we ordered, or confused us, but in the end, we owed them more than what was on the bill.  (Not a big deal, but it would have been nice not to have to question stuff.)  Maybe they were rushed when they were doing the math as well.
Not a totally negative or bad experience, but the timing of the service just seemed odd and awkward.  Maybe the waiter was having a bad night or something or had a hot date.
author: Brent F.

description: Chinese food is great but this restaurant puts the Chinese Food to the moon and beyond.. My faves are the portobello chicken and their eggplant .. Good price!
author: Faustino R.

description: Eric's is a solid performer.  My son is straight up addicted to the orange beef so I'm here often for the pickup.  Nothing here will rock your casbah but most everything is decent and well prepared.  Service has always been decent.
author: Benja F.

description: Very yummy and inexpensive. The only reason I gave it only 4 stars is the lack of atmosphere. Luckily, my dining companion and I got a table by the window, so that made it a bit nicer. The service was decent, but the best part was the food. We started off with the appetizer sampler, which comes with crab rangoons (which are heavenly), spring rolls, wings, etc....very generous portion for 2 people and delicious. I ordered the Mango Chicken for my entree and it was also very tasty. We plan to go back again very soon!
author: Jenny R.

description: Yup - it's not authentic Chinese.  I do like Chinatown too - but this is a block from home and is frankly better than any of the delivery places in this 'hood.  My fiance and I went here for the first time last night and had the pot stickers (standard, but very good), sizzling rice soup (hadn't had it before and was very happy - needed some soy sauce to make it a little more flavorful, but loved that the veggies were so fresh and crisp!) and Mu-shu chicken (also very good, but I was VERY disappointed that it came with grocery store tortillas instead of the thin crepe-like pancakes).  Overall, we'll be back because we ate dinner for $20, it wasn't greasy, and it's close to home.
author: Kelly M.

description:
