I have been going to Eric's for almost 10 years.  Even-though (or perhaps because) their menu hasn't changed in that amount of time they are consistantly good.  Some of their standard chinese fare (the stuff you can find in most other restaurants) are not bad but not stellar.  What they do best is their special dishes such as the Shanghai Chicken (with Pine Nuts and Toasted Seaweed), the Seseme Beef and the Eric's Spicy Chicken.  Their Hosin String Beans are a family standby as is the Spicy Broccoli.  Their food takes out very well, which is why my wife and I usually get take out, but their dining environment is also perfectly acceptable.  It's comfortable if not particularly big, service is always polite and prompt and not too terribly noisy.  If you are going to eat there, be prepared for difficult parking and on the weekends and on holidays the line for a table can be brutal.  All in all, it's consistantly one of the best Chinese Resturants I have been to in San Francisco.

As a side note, I consider myself a connoisseur of Pot Stickers.  Eric's are good but not stellar.  Don't let this deter you.  They are not greasy or over-fried and the contents are mighty tasty.
author: Torbin B.

description:
yummy.

basil&chicken = yum
black bean prawn = yum
green beans = holy fcuk that's delicious!
brown rice = tastes healthy (not in a good way)

got it to go.  was super fast. staff was pleasant.
author: Melissa Y.

description: I had to at least subtract two stars for the health score. So sad. I love this place, but 56/100 is really, really low. I've seen places that didn't look that clean with much higher scores than that. Scary!
author: Vanessa P.

description: Eric's reminds me of Eliza's at first glance.  It's a decent restaurant in terms of the food.  The service is a bit bizarre--our waiter was plenty polite, but the server just threw down the food as quickly as possible, spilling some of our soup and creating a bit of a mess.  The sauce in the eggplant/beef dish is a bit thick and overwhelming, but at least the eggplant was soft enough.  We also ordered the sesame beef dish...which seemed to have a similar sauce as the eggplant/beef dish...it was fine, but I wished that the sauces varied more!  I'd return to this Noe joint.
author: Lily C.

description: Eric's was a great experience...well almost. Don't get me wrong, I had the duck and it was awesome...the service was impeccable because they cue in at the appropriate time and don't over do it. The only gripe I had with them isn't really their fault but it's kind of cramped if you come with a party of 5 or more. The will make room for you but it just feels tight. If you are ever in this part of town then check it out....the food is worth it.
author: James J.

description:
Best pot stickers in town! Every time I go there with my friends, we each get  an order, so we don't have to share. 

The tofu with seaweed, the orange beef, the sizzling rice soup. It's all so good. In fact, I always get extra orders to go, so I can share them with my friends at work the next day.

It can get quite loud in there, and sometimes it might be a little bit of a wait, so make a reservation to cut down on the time that stands between you and your pot stickers.
author: Lucie T.

description:
Good chinese food in a part of the city that really doesn't seem to have many good choices for chinese. It's not the most authentic, but it's not over-westernized either (i.e. not oversweetened). Most of the dishes that I've had there have been really good, not too greasy and the vegetables perfectly cooked (loved the greenbeans). The portions are large - you certainly won't need more than one main per person (probably less if you're with a few people), but it's inexpensive enough that there's no reason to hold back. 

I agree with another reviewer, however, on the pancakes for the Moo Shu (which is otherwise excellent) - much more like tortillas than thin rice paper - and the only sour note on an otherwise very solid menu.
author: Peter S.

description: As indicated in other reviews I absolutely DO NOT care if food is authentic.  If it is, fine.  But to dock a place because it isn't seems a bit absurd to me.  As for Eric's, it shares my name therefore +1.  I lived around the corner for quite a while and ate there at least once a week.  The Mango Shrimp is fantastic as is the Beef with Broccoli.  I don't however recommend the Sesame Shrimp - not so good.  Overall, this is one of my favorite Chinese restaurants in the city.
author: Eric C.

description: Inexpensive California-style Chinese food with the freshest ingredients and prompt service.  A class above Eliza's.  Not a place to spend three hours over a bottle of wine or two, but ideal for takeout or a weeknight dinner.  The Shanghai Chicken and Eric's Spicy Eggplant are my favorites.
author: David O.

description:
Oh, Eric, I'm so disappointed. I've heard such wonderful things about your Chinese food in the past couple of months. Finally decided to try it for myself. Now, I did appreciate that my sesame chicken, pork and green beans and wonton soup was ready in 5 minutes -- kudos to you on that. And I'd overlook that I asked for two helpings of rice and one soup, not two soups and one rice. No biggie. It's Saturday night, and I'm sure you're busy. But the fact that you managed to burn the chicken, and that even the soup had a burnt taste to it -- that takes talent. The one star is for the fact that the green beans were crispy (probably because they were burned, too). But I'm sad to say that a couple of months of buildup led to an utter disappointment.

Never, never again.
author: andrea a.

description: With all the real authentic chinese restaurants in this city, why go here? This restaurant has your middle of the road  'american taste bud'  renditions of chinese foods. Food was okay, nothing special. The place was crowded which I quess is a good sign, but the way they  designed the place  made it uncomfortable to be seated towards the back. Everyone who was "taking out "was standing around the area where we  were seated.
author: Henry H.

description:
Great place to take the visitors from Des Moine.  It's ethnic enough to make the noe valley would-be hipster feel "edgy" and multi-culti, but also let's you feel just as safe as when you last dined at the olive garden.    


Their 5-taste chicken & a big bowl of rice is all I need.
author: rb l.

description: I had been to Eric's before, but had completely forgotten about it because it doesn't deliver and isn't in my neighborhood.  Thank goodness I stumbled upon it again! Eric's is exactly what I've been looking for, and failing to find, in a Chinese restaurant. Service was fast and friendly. We ordered the vegetarian egg rolls, sesame beef and rainbow fish. All were excellent. The egg rolls were crispy, not greasy and the veggies inside were really fresh and still somewhat crunchy. The sesame beef is my favorite - full of flavor, yet no sugary, goopy sauce. The rainbow fish was the perfect balance to the beef, less spicy, lots of good, fresh veggies, fresh chunks of cod. Delicious! The factor that makes the biggest difference between Eric's and lesser Chinese food restaurants is fresh, high-quality ingredients. Way to go guys! Now I just wish you would deliver!
author: Lauren B.

description: It's a tough choice but I have to give the slight edge to Eric's over Alice's, just more flavorful food, although you really can't go wrong at either, and Alice's is always less crowded.
author: Peter H.

description: Has got to be the best/cheapest Chinese food I have ever eaten. Service sucks but the food comes out fast and delicious. Personal favs: mango shrimp, broccoli beef and five taste chicken. The only thing I wish is that this place was closer to where I live now.
author: Jenny C.

description: Back in the dot-com days, we couldn't even hope to get a seat at this restaurant on any night. So we didn't even try, especially when Alice's is just close by. Lately, it has been easier to get tables. I really like it when we get the table by the window - you get to watch the train go by. The food is always good, but the service can seem brusque at times. To be honest, the downer for this restaurant are the customers. All these self-satisfied Noe Valley yuppies who seem to think that everyone else enjoys their misbehaved children.Everytime I need to be reminded of why I moved away from Noe to begin with, I just need to come here. 3 stars.
author: Rey L.

description:
Eric's has been popular since it open years ago. I love the 2antiqued chairs and the 1 antique table in the back seating area and the antiqued screen , always with orchid in the front. The place is clean but can get loud because it's always packed. 

The food is made for non-chinese for sure. Not that they are bad tasting, they are just Americanized. If you like "Koi Palace", I don't think you will like this place. Otherwise, a good place to hang out with your friends and have some Americanized Chinese food.
author: Nick S.

description:
okay, so what was everyone else ordering?  their dishes served with tortillas looked fun, and some veggies inside a bowl made of noodles...?

the mango chicken was drenched in a boring brown sauce and the meat was paper thin.  mongolian beef came with no veggies and tasted burned.  toss in a couple screaming babies and i'm a lot less likely to enjoy the meal.  

two stars for the yummy crab rangoons and the quick service.  did i order the wrong things or should i just go somewhere else?
author: Kris P.

description: So rumor has it that the owners of Eric's, Alice's, (just a few blocks away,) and Eliza's, (in Potrero Hill,) are all from the same family, but apparently multiple feuds have led to splintering off; first from Eliza's to Eric's; and then from Eric's to Alice's. The three places certainly have their similarities - decor, menu items, etc - and everyone I know who's been to all three has a preference. My personal choice is Eric's. It's a reliable option when I'm in the mood for some mu shu. Will it blow you away? I don't know about that - in a city like San Francisco, there's a lot to compete with, but it's tasty stuff, for sure!
author: Emily T.

description: I went here for the first time on a date last night. My date recommended the food highly, i mean he must love it to take a first date there..  mu shoo chicken was delish! fried rice was probably the best in my life! I would love to go back and try more on the menu, i feel like everything will be delish! Also, nice atmosphere, very clean, nice for a Chinese place. I really enjoyed the whole experience, and it was VERY FAST for the food to come out!! i mean less than five minutes for the moo shoo.. wow! totally worth a trip to noe valley in my opinion~
author: Danielle L.

description: Great Chinese. Tasty food without the over use of oil. Not greasy like many chinese restaurants. they have a dish with chicken, seaweed, and pine nuts that is quite unique, and their eggplant dishes are very tasty.
author: Fadi M.

description: I didn't believe the hype but since I used to live a few blocks away, we ordered take-out (no delivery at Eric's).  I would become a bulimic if I could at Eric's everyday.
author: J J.

description: I love Chinese food.  Let me clarify.  I love REAL Chinese food.  The kind you get on Clement Street or in Chinatown for super cheap and where, chances are the staff's going to be a little dismissive of you because you can't speak Chinese.  But when my boyfriend (who enjoys the likes of P.F. Chang's) took me here for takeout (the only way to go because of the usually large eat-in crowd) I was impressed.  The portions are a bit on the smaller side and the prices are a bit much but most dishes are pretty tasty.  The Mongolian beef is definitely worth trying.
author: Jasmine L.

description: Possibly the greasiest chinese food in town. Guys, eat real chinese food in SF. there are places for that.
author: Bobby T.

description: Killer five taste chicken!!!  Yes, I like the food but I take one star away because it gets way too crowded here.  It's those damn yuppies again, F*$!
author: Micaela M.

description: You know I will give this place 2 stars because I think the mango prawns are actually quite tasty.  However, I would give them an F- for their service.  It is a small place so if people are waiting to be seating expect to be treated as if eating dinner should be a race.  The servers are literally watching you like a hawk!! They took my plate away before I was even done eating.  I guess you should never put your fork down if you want to finish your whole meal.  IF ANYTHING, I would suggest only getting take out from here, because they are just RUDE!
author: Mariela L.

description: i'm a huge fan of the shanghai tofu.  easily 2 meals worth and so tasty!  this is one of our standby places, and i lived in noe almost a year without ever going there.  now i know!
author: Kat R.

description: I live around the corner from this place, and the only time I go here is for lunch. I must say, this place has the BEST potstickers I've had up to date. They are perfectly fried, not soggy or too greasy. Their lunch specials are pretty decent, but other wise I wouldn't wait in the long line in the cold, for dinner. I wouldn't say don't go here, but I would only suggest lunch..
author: Annie H.

description: I don't know why I keep going to Eric's.  I'll agree that the location, with its tall windows on a leafy section of Church Street, makes for a charming dining spot.  But I'm consistently disappointed with the food.  Every dish is doused with the same hideous, high-sodium brown sauce.  Good for them, however, for being so popular despite serving such low-quality food.  I'm sure I'll go back, if only because I'm following the crowd once again.
author: Mervyn H.

description: ive tried so many different chineese resturant but can find my favorite yet i mean xio loong so far is my favorite untill i found this one, still not as good but they hve the bes veggie egg rolls and walnut shrimp, the only problem with them is that they always wanna get rid of you as fast as possible and they r really cheap especially on soy sauce u have to pay extra for to go orders to get a lil more
author: Nate K.

description: Delicious! Inexpensive but doesn't feel like it. Good for friends, family, or dates.
author: Billy A.

description: Eric's is solid and I was bordering on being addicted to it for a while. The spicy smoked pork is amazing. It has leeks in it which is a nice change and the pork is absolutely packed with smoky goodness. The other dishes are good too but not as memorable. The lunch specials are a great value. I recommend checking this place out especially if you live nearby.
author: Aaron V.

description: Eric's Spicy Basil chicken and sesame beef - best two dishes.
author: Kavita S.

description:
what is so great about this place?????? all their dishes looks and taste the same! what is up with that? all you can taste is oyster sauce, soy sauce & msg. the look/presentation is boring and "brown"!!!
it's not even chinese food their serving.
author: Nelle A.

description: I'm not a big fan of Chinese food but this wasn't bad. Not life changing either.  All the things we ordered had the same basic flavor notes with variations coming only from the main ingredients (chicken vs beef).  The presentation was excellent though.  My girlfriend (who works with kids) that the bathroom had a little kid attachment for the toilet for little kids and they had little kid platters so its kid friendly.
author: rob. l.

description: Plain and simple, it's the best Chinese in San Francisco.
author: Philip M.

description: After our trip to St Helena, we filled up later that evening here. Parking can be a real drag out here but we evently got one. Since we were still pretty full, the four of us had Eric spicy eggplant, walnut prawns and the Shanghai chicken (my favorite). All dishes were good.
author: Ed L.

description: Some of the best chinese food I have had.  I find that a lot of chinese food is really greasy, doesn't taste fresh.  Eric's definitely changes that, not greasy, and the ingredients taste fresh. My first choice for chinese if I'm near Noe Valley.  Great and freindly atmosphere as well if your not looking for take out.
author: Greg D.

description: If you love Panda Express, and have money burning a hole in your pocket, you will LOVE this place.
author: kristen b.

description: I recommend the sweet and sour chicken, but their sesame beef was more like beef jerkey. Very fast service as well with a more california cuisine atmosphere, which I too enjoyed as well.
author: Sarah W.

description: Very Westernized Chinese food.  I mean the food isn't horrible, but if you want real Chinese food try elsewhere.
author: Tinou B.

description: Eric's is the best. Their fried rice is very appetizing. The sauteed string beans are pretty good too although it's sort of salty. My favorite is the walnut prawns.
author: Bianca B.

description: Oh man, Eric's is amazing.  My first impression was in 1997 prior to moving here.  I was visiting my brother and he said it was OK to smoke out on the curb of the street.  That's when I fell in love with SF.  Once I moved here I came back and re-enacted it.  It holds a little piece of my heart as the first restaurant I ate at in SF.  The food is still off the charts good and cheap.  Lunches are muy affordable.  Beef and broccoli is one of my favs!
author: Chard M.

description: Good to great food, good service. The key component here is consistency, which Eric's pulls off nicely. They handle crowds well, but the atmosphere is noisy and excessively lit.  Take out is sufficiently prompt. For SF Chinese cuisine, it is in the 3-star category.
author: Eric H.

description:
i love eric's.  is it bad that i know their number by heart?  i used to live down the street and eat here all the time; now i'm across town and it's evolved to a mostly take-out relationship.  i always get some combination of these three things: the spicy chicken with fresh basil, the sesame beef, and the mango prawns.  all delish.  

the atmosphere is more noe neighborhood spot than gold lantern chinese, which i think is refreshing.  the service is always good, so long as good means quick.  it's not a place to linger, discussing life's mysteries over your fortune cookies.  they'll shoo you out.  speaking of fortune cookies, theirs often have two fortunes in them.  i'm not sure how i feel about that.  one for each of my personalities?
author: brian g.

description: I am going to have to agree with piccolina i. The sauce on the food was the same. That said, the food was decent, but nothing to write home about ... wait, ain't that what i am doin'? I had dinner with a couple of friends at Eric's last night. We had Eric's Fried Rice, Emperor's Prawns and  Shanghai Tofu a couple beers and a glass of wine. Out of the three the prawn dish was the best. For Chinese food in this city Eric's ranked as average. If you want good Chinese for the same price, try Big Lantern on 16th. It will definitely deliver a better value. Or, if you are in the Richmond and want dim sum, try Bay Fong Tong. You will not be disappointed; especially with the price!
author: Jaime R.

description: It's yummy good.  The Hoisin String Beans are really tasty -- one of my favorites!  Same goes for the Sesame Chicken...very very tasty!  All in all, if you are looking to go out for chinese and don't want to gamble, you will not leave Eric's disappointed!  Too bad they don't deliver!  But maybe that's what makes the place sweet.  You have to go out to get it!
author: Dwayne A.

description:
good food service kinda ehh although my water glass was never empty!
it was what i would consider healthy chinese food but with the same amount of that grease that you would expect I personally still like lizas more in P.Hill
author: Nicholas E.

description: Not excellent chinese food, but very yummy. I'd recommend it in a minute.
author: Emily A.

description: It's important to disclose that I'm not a fan of Chinese food, but will say that given that fact, this place isn't so bad (and that's saying something!).   It's a super popular place in Noe, so if you like Chinese, I bet you'll enjoy it!!  Btw, my boy thinks it's freaking fantastic.
author: Jenn K.

description:
i found this restaurant through a pbs show. and so i went to try it out the food. it is honestly REAL chinese food. not no of those wanna-bes like panda or china express type. reading about how unsanitary it is... kinda made me drop a star for them... but REALLY, the food is so good and the service is the typical asian but a little better. 

everytime i try to come here and eat at night... its super packed. and i come to the city pretty often, and i've never seen a restaurant there get packed that people are waiting outside (like an entire crowd of people you would see waiting outside trying to get into the bar/club or something like that.)

i'll say this, i'll eat there until the day i get food poisioning.
author: Jenny H.

description: Okay okay okay. So even though it had a health score of like fucking 59 last year, I would still willingly poison myself with this deliciousness. Eric's is pretty much the only Chinese food place I will go to in the city without hesitation (well, them and Alice's, but isn't Alice's like Eric's doppelganger little sister or some shit?). The lemon chicken cannot be denied here. And your will power is nothing against the 5 taste chicken or the broccoli beef. And lets not go there with the hot and sour soup because girlfriend will sit here and talk about how tits it is for houuuurrrs. Seriously, I am a bitch when it comes to my chinese food but Eric's knows how to do it right and girl is not trying to fight it no mo! I always give in when someone says "How bout Eric's" How bout I'm already seated and waiting for you to make up your damn mind on what you want!
author: Lou C.

description: Came here for dinner over the weekend and the dishes were...disappointing.  We ordered drums of heaven - turned out to be over-done deep fried, almost blacken drums.  I am guess those drums got kicked out of heaven.  Also tried 2 of Eric's special dishes (Ocean garden and Eric's special eggplant), they tasted the same, extremely  salty and oily.  We ate less than 1/3 of each dish and didn't bother to pack to go.  I wouldn't give that food to my dog.  Price is cheap though.
author: Ed Q.

description: if you're looking for some flavor explosion go to Eric's. everything ordered was bursting with delicious. i can at least attest for the sesame beef, cashew chicken and mango prawns. this place is definitely more expensive than you average chinese restaurant but considering it's in Noe Valley it's to be expected.
author: Regina C.

description: Similar to Alice's, but I think Eric's food somehow isn't quite as tasty. My food was only lukewarm once, and since then I've stayed away.
author: Alden C.

description:
Clean, bright Chinese restaurant near enough to Glen Park to walk to. The wonton soup is tasty with gingery, peppery broth and fresh cilantro in the dumplings. The Avocado (spring) Rolls are sinfully rich and an appetizer I've never seen anywhere else. Don't be afraid to order scallops, which arrived to our table hot,  but still tender inside, the way they should be. 
Aside from the crazed lines for takeout orders on popular days of the week, Eric's is a consistently good place to eat at again and again. Really good value for lunch.
author: Jackie C.

description: I had spicy basil chicken, it was so good!  I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good Chinese place on Church st in the city.
author: Rob P.

description: I LOOOVE Eric's... Love it.  For well priced DEEElicious chinese, I say this is the place.  I usually carry on and on and write a ten page review.  I won't this time, cause Eric's is yummy - plain and simple.  Been going there for years and years and never had a bad experience, so I am sorry for the other folks who have, but maybe its the sheer volume of customers they take in every day?  I dunno.  GOOD!  GOOD!  GOOD!
author: Sara W.

description: This is the best value in SF for mid-week lunch.  Great service, great food, great atmosphere, and great price!  Best sweet and sour I've had anywhere (it's not too sweet like so many others).  Try the crab rangoon.
author: Mark O.

description:
B+ for the food
F- for the attitude
The food is pretty good. However, they really live up to the stereotype regarding service at Chinese Restaurants.  God, they have such 'tude. So rude!   There is another Chinese restaurant one block up and over on Church.  Same menu, nice staff.
author: Alulubeth O.

description: I had so much fun here. The staff is really great. We were served by a spoon mu shu folding specialist. Who kept bring us seriously tasty dishes. The mango prawns were really good. I found the fried rich a bit bland but not bad.
author: Angela K.

description:
Uber quick service! Yummy food!
As soon as we sat down we were served with ice water and hot tea. We got our order about 5-7mins after ordering it. The food tasted clean and fresh and the portions were generous. The 5-taste chicken wasn't all white meat, but when is it ever? Get the sesame beef (but save some for me)! It was delicious! I'll be going there again!
author: M J.

description: This place is great for lunch or dinner.  Very reasonable prices and above average chinese food.  Its in a convenient location and is easy to get to.  I have tried a number of the beef and chicken dishes and have not been dissappointed.
author: Alex E.

description: It seems they changed ownership about 6 months ago.  The last owners seem have to have taken a good deal of the taste with them.
author: Jeff P.

description:
Sesame Beef is Awesome.  The restaurant is Small and crowded, but hey that says something.  An empty restaurant tells you something about the food.  Especially in a residential area.  "Stay Away!"
This is always a "Come join us" restaurant.  Last night a friend was released form the Critical Care Unit of a hospital in The City and the first place he wanted to go to to get some real food was Eric's.
author: John C.

description: I should have been suspicious about getting Chinese in Noe.  But my sister swore it was good.  I wouldn't say she is a Chinatown kind of girl; she's more the Marina/ Pac Heights type.  Anyhow, we ordered things like fried rice, kung pao chicken, and other things I can't recall.  It was decent Chinese food, but nothing memorable.  The restaurant was really cute, however, inside and out.  Um, a Chinese restaurant cute?  Well, this one way.  But again, we were in Noe for Chinese!
author: Sarah F.

description:
If you like sweet brown sauce, you will LOVE this place....

Years ago, a trip to Erics was a culinary adventure with interesting, unique dishes with creative and fresh ingredients.  Recently, I have had takeout from there several times.  Where did all the brown gunk come from?  We ordered what were described as 4 distinct dishes, but they all ended up being X and Y a la Brown Gunk (where X = rubbery meat and Y = boring vegetable such as carrot or celery).  
The dishes were overly sweet, goopy, and bland.  So disappointing.  There is much much better Chinese to be had elsewhere and better food right nearby in the 'hood.  Yikes!  I took the food to a friend's house for movie night and it was embarrassing.
On the bright side, the vegetable dishes were very LARGE so you get LOTS of goop.
author: Trecker J.

description: I use to love this place when it first opened. The last few times it got very bad over the years. I went there on Friday only, because I found a good parking spot. The meat I had...was NOT meat. I have no idea what the hell it was!! I only ate the veggies. OMG!! I knew not to go back, but I wanted to give them another chance! I can't believe this place gets awards! Too bad they choose not to serve real beef instead of that mystery meat.
author: jen v.

description: I love Eric's.  The food is consistently fresh and delicious and the service is quick.  Once again, I will note that my Mom loves Eric's and since my Mom is very picky, it must be good.  Their postickers are really yummy.
author: Landy G.

description: I had always heard such great things about Eric's. So when we moved to Noe, I was excited to finally try it. What a disappointment. The food is absolutely flavorless. I can understand that some people are into Americanized Chinese restaurants...but there is just no excuse for flavorless food.
author: Lee S.

description: I have been to Eric's twice now and both times they have been absolutely delicious. I definitely recommend the Mu-Shu vegetable, Sesame beef and Shanghai chicken. These dishes are the best! The only down side is that I drink a lot of water and they aren't very good at filling water glasses. Other than that, it was great. I've been there on a Wednesday night and a Sunday night and both times they have been full. They seem to be doing a great business. And they are only about 6 blocks from Mitchell's Ice Cream!
author: Rachel F.

description: I don't know what all these other yelpers are talking about. I ordered the appetizer platter. The egg rolls were exceptional, crab rangoon not so much. The General Tso's chicken was awesome. I loved it. My girlfriend had the Shanghai chicken and it was pretty tasty as well. I did feel slightly rushed by the wait staff, but it wasn't obnoxious. I may be from Florida, and yes, the Chinese food in Florida sucks, but I thought Eric's was delicious. The most disappointing thing was that I didn't get the uneaten egg rolls when I asked for my uneaten food to be boxed.
author: Brett B.

description: fyi, they don't do lunch specials on Sunday.  all other days until 3pm.
author: cheryl f.

description: High Four Stars. I like Eric's cause the food's great and served quickly. The place could be bigger but that's because they're mostly busy. My favorite dishes are the walnut prawns and the shanghai chicken with brown rice. But most of all, I like Eric's because it's not as greasy as other Chinese restaurants.
author: Nicole O.

description: Really good, clean, tasty Chinese food.  I actually believe it's better than most genuine mom and pop Chinese food joints. But I'm just a white guy, so what do I know?
author: Scott S.

description: The lunch special here cannot be beaten. For $6-7 you get the best chinese lunch in town. also the walnut prawns are to die for! good food, fast service and reasonable prices.
author: nick h.

description: This is the best Chinese take out place in the city (okay, I haven't eaten at every Chinese take out place in the city).  What makes it better is that the food is not overly oiled.
author: Lin N.

description: The food is cheap and good.  Can't say it's the most authentic Chinese cuisine around, but who doesn't enjoy some delicious sesame beef once in a while?  Also try out the eggplant and prawns.
author: Sushant P.

description: I took the daughter and her friend here for dinner and we loved it! The potstickers are super hot and crispy and the sesame chicken is so good- it was sauteed chicken in a black bean sauce and then topped with toasted sesame seed but the best part was the addition of squash-it was so good. The serves was excellent-warm and very friendly. We will go back to try more dishes.
author: Mary E.

description: Excellent Chinese-American fare. Tasty, fresh, clean food.  Good service.
author: Brian S.

description: Decent food, fast service - we went late and were seated immediately, and the bill for my wife and I was under $30 including tip.  Unbeatable.
author: Fiid W.

description: Yummy. When I lived in Noe I went here all the time.  Sometimes I still get takeout from here.  Often crowded with a long line for dinner.
author: Fred C.

description:
I love it and every month we feel the need for Eric's ! 

Its clean, not too hard on the pocket,the service is quick and the food is yummy - love the Shangai Chicken, Mango Prawns, Veggie Fried Rice and Spicy Eggplant.   Fridays and weekend evenings it gets crowded but the wait is usually not more than 10 minutes.

OK - so the diehards will probably say that it is not the authentic Chinese you get in the crowded alleys of Shangai or Hong Kong but hey it is tasty and the closest to Indian Chinese outside of India.
author: mihir m.

description: Excellent, clean, yuppie-style Chinese food in outer Noe Valley. Great atmosphere too.  Not terribly authentic food... but I can dig yuppified Americanized versions of food too, if it's done well.
author: Matt W.

description: I use to really enjoy eatting at Eric's.  For Chinese food for the Americanized palate, it is my favorite place to eat lunch and bring family to.  But the service changed since those days of enjoying eatting at Eric's.  Bad service... as a matter of fact, service please... hello?!  Lucy B would have given it 4 stars but lack of service (not simply lack of attention - actual service)  to the customer brings it down to 3.  Oh and thank you for making sure my party of 1 sat behind the big screen when there were nice open tables for two up front near the windows.  3 stars.
author: Lucy B.

description:
I've been a customer at Eric's quite a few of times over the past year, and I probably would've given this place three or maybe even four stars six months ago.  But man, I just got takeout tonight and it was salty beyond belief.  After I ate their food I literally had to chug an entire Brita pitcher full of water.  What happened?  MSG overload?

I used to think that this place was solid, but not outstanding.  The cooking was only above average, but I could always count on them to use lean cuts of meat and fresh veggies.  I can make this judgment call because my parents used to run a successful and critically-acclaimed Chinese restaurant in Chicago where my dad was the head chef.

Anyways, Eric's is really close to my apartment, and not too expensive for San Francisco standards.  I would always get takeout on days I was too lazy to cook, and even took a few dates there.  But after tonight, I'm left confused and disappointed.  I might give it another try, or hopefully find another decent spot for Chinese around my place.
author: Alan C.

description:
After hearing about this from my work mate i decided i had to go since i do love chinese food, its taken a while to get used to it over her im starting to love it again.
I went here with my boyfriend after a long day shopping and we both enjoyed it...we shared erics spicy chix and mongolian beef.  Its one of the nicest ive had in the city although i thought the portions were small im sure there not i just love my food!!
I will definitely go again.
author: aislinn m.

description:
The previous post "I love PF Chang's." says it all.

Points for perfecting American food in the "Chinese" style. If you appreciate real Chinese food, however, walk on.
author: Raul J.

description:
Awesome!  My family and I swear there's heroin in this food because we're addicted!  (For serious foks - I''m just kidding!).

The Shanghai Chicken, General Tso's chicken, Walnut prawns, potstickers and won ton soup are my favorites!!  

We've been going for 11 years and the service is quick and efficient and the food has never lagged.  

Yum-yum... now I'm "jonesing" for a fix!
author: M M.

description: I was really disappointed with this since all I had was sesame chicken and chow mein.  The chow mein was really bad and the noodles were almost mushy and didn't have much flavor besides salt (or msg??).  The sesame chicken was just okay.  I will probably not return here since I'm sure I can find better Chinese food options in the City.
author: Michael S.

description:
Easily my favorite neighborhood restaurant! I brag about this place and have all of my friends hooked. Excellent food, amazing service and a lovely location on Church Street.

I can't say enough good things, but you should try it for yourself!
author: Haley H.

description: Good if not authentic Chinese food.  The interior and setting is nice than most places, make you feel like eating is more an event than just a meal. If you like mu shu, theirs is worth checking out.
author: Vincent V.

description: I was told by friends that Eric's had fantastic Chinese food. After eating at Eric's, I was highly disappointed. The food is bland, boring and not authentic. The best part of the meal was the white rice and  7-Up that I ordered.
author: Julianna C.

description: Eric's is a great place for a quick cheap lunch (bowl of soup and a huge plate of food for around $6).  I usually order the Hunan Fish which is very tasty.  Also, the eggrolls are fantastic here.  I give it four stars for the yummy food and clean nice ambiance but the service is really hit or miss.
author: M K.

description: Yummy food.  I really love the sizzling rice soup and the green beans with tofu.  If you get it to go get be sure to ask for extra rice. They are very nice and the price is right for the amount of food and the quality.
author: Christina C.

description:
Long, long ago, Eric's actually used to be a sort of Noe Valley's "Best-Kept-Secret" Chinese restaurant.  It's staff, while surly, was efficient. 

On a recent trip, I was deeply disappointed when we arrived to a crowded restaurant and prpomptly whisked away to a tiny table stuffed behind a huge screen with a plant sitting atop me and another table slammed into the overdrowded spot. Most of the tables are like that - so it's tiny, jam-packed with lots of noise and, unfortunately, difficult to tune out conversations and focus on your own.  

Food is equally as disappointing - my orange beef was more like a smattering of snipped beef which had been charred to the point of resembling unidentifiable mystery meat.  It frankly reminded me of fried-cum-burned beef intestines. YUK!  The potstickers had an unusual taste and to this day I still can't say what it was.  

When I pointed out that the beef was nothing more than the badly remains of an airliner accident, the waitress insisted that I had never ordered this dish here before or even that I had ever been to Eric's.  Wrong on both counts.  She did however take the item off my tab, seeing that I opted to keep my full set of teeth.

It's buh-bye to Eric's!
author: King K.

description: Do not go here for the ambiance or the service (Its not bad, just ok).  If you want descent Chinese food at an affordable price, then you'll be satisfied with Erics.  Not the best Chinese I've had, or the worst either, just OK.
author: Noel S.

description: i used to like erics, but i went there last week, and it was the most horrible service and bad food.  i will never go there again.
author: discerning p.

description: This small neighborhood joint serves some of the best Mandarin & Hunan food in the city.  It is a clean atmosphere with friendly service at reasonable prices.  The pot stickers are crispy golden with a wonderful ground pork, cabbage, and ginger filling; perfect with a little soy sauce.  The green onion pancakes are crispy and greasless with a wonderful peanut sauce that not too peanuty and not too thick or runny for that matter.  The appetizer sampler has rangoons which are crispy and greasless won tons filled with a well balanced crab meat and cream cheese mixture, egg rolls with wonderful vegetarian filling, crispy drums of heaven (chicken wings,) and wonderful fried prawns.  The Eric's chow mein is excellent with succulent prawns, tender barbecued pork, chicken, beef, and vegetables with soft noodles that are not too oily and wonderfully seasoned.  The hunan lemon prawns are the only true disappointment thus far as you can expect a mild lemon sauce like with lemon chicken.  The sesame beef is tender and crispy, flash fried in a spicy Szechwan sauce perfect over rice.  The orange beef is crispy and flash fried with chilies and orange rinds in a light orange flavored sauce; a wonderful spicy number.  The Shanghai chicken is tender diced chicken with seaweed and pine nuts in a light sauce.  The steamed rice is firm and not soggy.  Round it off with a cold Tsing Tao and you will not be disappointed.  So, for excellent Mandarin & Hunan cuisine at reasonable prices with friendly service in a casual atmosphere, Eric's cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.

description: good Chinese food served California style...love the sesame beef and the walnut prawns....the chicken and seaweed dish is also great...but i love the avocado rolls!  yum
author: A P.

description: Szechuan Pork is my favorite dish here.  Clean with quality, and quick for a table service lunch or dinner.  I have gone many many times and never been disappointed.
author: Jack M.

description: hey guys, i did love this restaurant until recently. the last two visits had bad food and horrible service. im giving it three stars because i know its potential to be super yummy with their delicious orange peel beef, mango chicken and erics cakes...oh yes and the avocado roles!! the washroom is super clean so thats good and parking is not so bad. saying all this, the waiter the last two times literally threw our food at us...and we had to wait super long. giving a tip was really a toss up.
author: Naureen H.

description: i'm sorry, but if you have to KNOW what to order to get great food at a restaurant, it's just not a great restaurant.  the thing to order is the shanghai chicken. everything else is mediocre. jasmine tea house is just as good or better and they deliver.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I'd give it zero stars if I could. Honestly... went there with my g/f and both came out with queasy guts. The sauce used in all their dishes (which taste pretty much same) is best described as brownish burnt sauce. Don't go there unless you live in Noe Valley (sorry).
author: Shwin S.

description: This is my go-to place for Chinese.  It's nearby and fast. Go for the walnut prawns and the sesame beef- yummy!
author: Nadia T.

description:
on a wednesday afternoon, three of us went to Eric's because we had heard how clean and fresh Eric's was.  however,  their practice of setting up tables with teacups rim-down on the bare table was a turn-off.  people put purses, small packages or other items which often have been sitting on a floor, public restroom sink or floor,  or other germy surface, such as a MUNI seat, on the table.   it is not appetizing and unsafe to drink from a teacup where the rim has been sitting on  an unsanitary surface.  people can have diseases like hepatitis, TB,  flu or cold germs, etc., and not know it, but "germ up" the table surface.   some people don't wash hands after using the bathroom and then put those hands on the table.  the restaurant doesn't sanitize the table after customers leave; they  wipe it with a wet rag that they carry around.  you can pick up an illness drinking from a cup sitting rim-down on  such a  surface.

 one of us was a tofu lover, ordered a common tofu dish, but even she couldn't stand to eat it.  after one bite none of us would even touch it, it was so very salty and strangely horrible.  fried appetizer chicken wing drumettes, while burned a little on the outside, were actually bloody within. the rest of the food was okay.  we gave no clue as to any displeasure and tipped the  unsmiling, not friendly young waiter $10 on a bill of 45.   we had a very simple order, didn't really require anything much of the waiter.  he didn't  acknowledge the tip, say thank you when we paid the bill or anything at all.  The place was almost empty when we left.  The waiter saw us leaving, but ignored us.  No "goodbye," "come again,"  "thank you" or anything.  We usually say something complimentary when we are leaving, but in this case all we would have had to say was "thank you" and "goodbye."  Since he made no effort to even acknowledge us, we left silently.  The owner or manager should brief the wait staff on simple common courtesy.
author: jean w.

description: Not the old Eric's I use to know. Maybe they changed owners? This was truly disappointing. The food just wasn't good.
author: Erik B.

description: I'm so surprised they have fairly decent ratings!!  Their lemon chicken was dry, too hard and chewy, and mostly dough and not chicken. We got another specialty dish of theirs that was drowning in salty "brown sauce." Looking at the other dishes people were eating, they looked very unappetizing and similarly discolored brown with the same sauce. We were very disappointed as we had heard great things about Eric's (from a friend who is from the midwest, and does not eat Chinese food often...should have known)! If you want westernized, MSG-laden food, come here. If you want real Chinese food, you're going to have to go elsewhere!
author: E M.

description: Always great, Have never had a bad meal there. Spicy eggplant is my favorite. The place is always busy dosn't matter what day of the week you go, so that also says something about the quality of the food.
author: Mark M.

description: I am sad because this place used to really great.  The times they have absolutely changed.  I get the feeling they care more about serving as many tables as possible than the quality of the food.  Just remember their rating from the health department.  That says it all.
author: Rona M.

description: i love this place! fried rice rocks and walnut prawns are the best! :D
author: Bernadette B.

description: The food here is moderately priced.  The best chinese food i have found in Noe Valley so far.  They are usually rather quick getting the food out too.
author: Scott H.

description: This place has yummy Cal-Chinese. I've been here a bunch of times and usually like what I get, although many of the dishes are salty (which I guess is typical of Chinese food). The wonton soup is good but on the spicy side- not a good substitute for mom's chicken noodle when you're sick! The only thing I haven't liked is the rainbow fish (sauteed diced rock cod with bell pepper & pine nut in white garlic sauce). The sauce was goopy and there weren't very many pine nuts. The decor is very trendy with lots of orchids, but beware that it gets very loud (even thought they don't play music).
author: Laura B.

description: Very convenient, basic Chinese restaurant.  I like the short wait times, friendly service, abundant natural light, and reasonable prices. Sometimes the sauces on different dishes taste the same, though.
author: Jay B.

description: My friend F recommended Eric's Restaurant, a Chinese restaurant in Noe valley. I like Chinese food, but I don't love it. I do love dim sum, kind of dislike take out type, and regular is just fine. This was a regular food type place. I had Eric's spicy eggplant dish, which has chicken and shrimp. I didn't used to like shrimp, but I do now. There was a lot of shrimp in the dish, and they were nice and plump, but hardly any chicken. The eggplant ( I LOVE eggplant) was really good, but there was too much sauce, and by the end of the meal, everything was a bit drowned in the thick sauce. F and R got the spicy chicken dishes, which they liked, and J got the mango chicken dish, which he thought was good, but not great. Overall, this was one of the best Chinese food places I've been to in a long while. Nothing was friedy, the service was good, and the dcor was nice. I'd probably go someplace else before I went to Chinese, but if I were, I'd go here.
author: Merredith L.

description: Eric's has to pass for a neighborhood Chinese food joint in yuppieville Noe Valley so therefore it has to charge a price that reflects the tony 'hood and cover the rent. The food was ok at best. Someone earlier talked about the monotonous gravy... it's true. Overall, quite bland. Authentic? Ehhhhh not quite. Did I mention it was in Noe? Not exactly Chinatown.  Oh. And the worst of it all? You had to PAY for the rice. Outrageous!!!
author: Erick K.

description:
one of my fav's.  we've been coming here for over 5 years, since a friend introduced me to it.
the food changes slightly with the different chefs, but so far, the variations are all fab!
try the avocado rolls, walnut prawn, and shanghai chicken
author: Mom Of Three L.

description: Maybe I did not order the right dish. Had high expectations as I kept hearing how terrific this place was. Found the food to be either bland and tasteless or over the top salty. Felt sick pretty shortly after the meal was over. 3 stars because it is close to work and they offer brown rice.
author: Lux P.

description: eric's restored my faith in chinese food. i had been on hiatus for such a long time after poor, near-MSG coma experiences, but eric's...YUMMMMMM. mu shu vegetable was delicious!! the wait staff was super courteous and super quick. therefore, my experience was SUPER-B.
author: Joanna M.

description: after seeing decent yelp reviews and a bunch of people crowding this place for dinner each night, i had pretty high expectations.  but then i got two dishes here, mango chicken and sesame beef, and both were not really good.  in fact i should give one star.  the sesame beef was dry, overcooked, and bitter.  the mango chicken just didnt look good.  picture brightly colored chunks of mango with this sour brown sauce all over.  not that great, and kind of expensive!  please tell me the -good- things on the menu here.
author: Robert S.

description:
Wow, huge disappointment.
I went there with three other people today and this is how it went-
      First, we went in and were asked to sit at a table for four in the very back, right next to the loud kitchen, and bathroom.( Note that it really was not crowded and there were other tables open) So, we asked if we could be seated at the table next to the window, since the people sitting there had just left. After some serious eye rolling, sourpuss faces, and looks as though they were being asked to do harsh labor, we were seated at the table next to the window. When my friend apologized about the HUGE inconvenience, I mean please, (even though we told her not to), and the waiter just bunched up his eyes and gave us a whine. 
      Then the waiter came over and asked us if we were ready to order after we had been seated just five minutes before. Lucky for him we were ready to order. When we said we were, he said, ''oops, i forgot my pen.''
      Okay now i just found this part the most just down right rude of them all. The waiter gave us the assorted vegetable soup. After we were done, most of us didn't eat ours, the table thought that the broth was barley warm, and the vegetables were over cooked, and it had the most disgusting looking color, it was brown with little shreds of orange in it. Okay so the waiter starts clearing our bowls, and he says, ''well it didn't look like you liked it that much.'' in a really rude way. We just didn't know what to say it was just the rudest comment.
      One of us had ordered Eric's Cake's, so the waiter put it on the table, and passed out four plates for us to eat it. We had already stacked up the plates when we were done, but when the waiter came to collect the plates, he carefully looked at each one in the stack. It was really weird, and we don't know why he did that, but based on what happened before, he could have been checking to see if we had all tried it, but we will never know.
       When the check came we were all fed up about the service that we left a two dollar tip.
       As far as the food goes, I had the lemon chicken, which was fine, but I haven't had their food for a while-I think, and I feel like it has gone so downhill since I used to go there.
       If this review were based just on service, I would give them one star, but since the food was OK, I'll throw them another star.
       If you are in the mood for some disrespectful, and rude service, then this is the place for you! Personally I enjoy friendly, polite service, which you will definitely not find here.
 P.S. does anyone know the city health rating for Eric's now?
author: P R.

description: use to be good years ago. now i go once every other year when invited. oily, spices are off and heavy. take a pass. get a chinese recipe from the net and try ur own, it will turn out close.
author: ray c.

description: eric's is some damn good chinese , chinese food can be tricky u could never know what kind of meat they could use , but this one u can trust , , they are fast too since the place is a little small and they are always busy . very clean as well
author: NAEL K.

description: Eric's food has a unique flavor that you either like or you don't.  Not very authentic, but good in it's own way.  My favorite is the drums of heaven.  It's always crowded and the atmosphere is somewhat hurried, but the great food makes up for it.  Far better than the typical neighborhood chinese joint.
author: Anonymou S.

description: there is nothing wrong with this place.  good enough food, great prices, decent decor, clean.  very close to my house so i will be back.  after all the raves i thought it would stand out a little more as special, but it doesn't.  right there with eliza's and such.  see you soon for takeout.
author: e w.

description: if you have not had the mu-shu pork from eric's, you are really missing out.  seriously - next time you're getting take out, call eric's and order the mu-shu pork. it will be ready in 10 minutes max, and it truely is one of the greatest take out dishes in the city.  the rest of the menu is pretty tasty, too.
author: Erin C.

description: Great food, very innovative Chinese food!  Great seafood specials and very affordable.   The wait can be long so make reservations but they do take out.    Not exactly the friendliest staff but the food makes up for it.
author: Kilian M.

description: Amazing Chinese food- my favorite in the city.  General Tso chicken and mango shrimp are to die for.  And whereas most fortune cookies taste like styrafoam, theirs are actually really good.
author: Molly C.

description: I remember going here many years ago and really enjoying the food, but not this time.  Maybe it's because we went for lunch, or maybe because it's been about 8 years later and things have changed, but the food seemed just O.K.  The women serving us all seemed upset at something (it wasn't us) which didn't add to the experience.  Things like dishes tossed on the table and not one smile make you just want to leave...and not return.  The General's Chicken was not at all krispy and pretty blan.  The "crab meat " appetizer was terrible and made with that redish/pinkish fake crab meat (and something that tasted of mayonaise)...ewwww!  The spring rolls had fresh vegetables that weren't over cooked, however, they still weren't all that great.  I was hoping to like this place as it's close to where I live, but I think if I do go again it will be for dinner and see if that can restore my faith in this restaurant.
author: Sean M.

description: This used to be the only place in San Francisco where we would go out for Chinese food. It's pretty crowded and I'm not sure whether they take reservations, so be prepared to wait. The service is good and the food is quick. It's a little off the beaten path, but definitely worth the trip.
author: Avid E.

description: Best genral chaw chicken
author: Nadav N.

description: Has this place changed owners recently (11/06)?  I have been getting takeout from here for years and it was always ready in a flash.  This last time they quoted 20 minutes wait ( yeah, right I said), but they were right - it did take that long.  Also, I did not recognize any of the staff. The manager is definitely new.  Anyone know for sure?  The food was still good though!
author: Kevin O.

description: Simply incredible, amazing, delicious, superb - this is heaven on earth.  I know I sound like I'm exaggerating, but it truly is the best chinese I've had in San Francisco.
author: Michael S.

description: Best Chinese food in Noe Valley.  Maybe even San Francisco.
author: B P.

description: love the spicy eggplant with shrimp and the won ton soup.  in a word - yum!
author: elle b.

description: excellent chinese food "western style." sizzling rice soup is light and clear. good vegetables. service is fast and efficient, atmosphere is ok. 3.5 stars.
author: Y W.
